 You nod slowly. Losing this close—right at the finish lines—somehow stings far more than if it had never been in reach at all.

 The stadium noise starts to fade as the students begin shuffling out, their excitement drained. Some people stay back to talk, but most head toward the parking lot. The entire school looks deflated. 
 
 The game didn't go how you wanted it to. Not at all.
 

[Choice: Go find Luke]

passages.name: Day 12 - Game Spectator 7
passages.text:
The energy in the stadium has completely shifted. There's just a dull murmur of voices as people start filing out, none of the deafening cheers and pounding drums there were moments earlier. The opposing team is still celebrating, their players hugging, jumping, and throwing their helmets in the air. Meanwhile, the Pacific Crest Panthers walk off in silence, their exhaustion and disappointment weighing down every step.

You and Samantha make your way down toward the locker rooms, weaving through the dispersing crowd. The buzz of post-game chatter surrounds you but for you and Samantha, there's only one thing that matters.

Luke.

Samantha lets out a heavy sigh, stuffing her hands into her hoodie pocket. "Ugh, I hate this part. The whole awkward conversation where we have to reassure the guy."

You glance at her. "We don't have to talk to him if you don't want to."

She snorts. "Yeah, like we're going to let him mope alone. Come on, [name]. You know Luke would do the same for us."

You can't argue with her sound logic.

By the time you reach the locker room entrance, the players have already gone inside, venting their frustration to each other.

Luke is leaning against the wall just outside the entrance, still in his uniform, his helmet resting on the floor. He hasn't even taken his gloves off yet. He stares at the ground, jaw clenched, expression hard to read.

Samantha steps forward first. "Alright, before you say anything, I want you to know that that was not your fault."

Luke lets out a humorless chuckle, finally looking up. "I didn't say it was."

"Luke, I know you're thinking it," she says, crossing her arms. "And I'm shutting it down."

Luke exhales sharply. "I should've made that. We should've won."

"You almost did," you correct.

Luke presses his lips into a thin line. "Almost doesn't win games."

Samantha groans. "Luke, shut up. Do you want me to start listing all the insane catches you did make tonight? Because I will. Each and every one. Do keep in mind I will be obnoxious about it."

Luke snorts, shaking his head. "Please don't."

"Oh, thank God, you're still capable of human emotions."

That finally gets a real laugh out of him, even if it's small. Luke sighs, finally pulling off his gloves. "Thanks, guys. Really."

You nod. "That's what we're here for."

Luke leans back against the wall, tilting his head up toward the stadium lights still shining overhead. "Fuck, I just wanted to win this one," he mutters. "First game of the season, home crowd, everyone watching... it sucks to come up short."

You and Samantha exchange a glance, both knowing this loss stings a hell of a lot more than he's letting on.

"Yeah, it sucks," Samantha admits. "But it's one game. Not to mention you did your best. The season's not over."

Luke nods slowly, letting the words sink in.

Samantha nudges Luke's arm. "So, are you gonna sit here brooding all night, or are we gonna do something stupid to get our minds off this?"

Luke raises an eyebrow. "Define 'stupid.'"

Samantha grins. "Hmm, I don't know. Something fun. Something reckless."

"I feel like your definition of reckless is very different from mine," you say, sighing.

Samantha completely ignores you, snapping her fingers suddenly. "I've got it," she says, spinning to face both of you. "You know the Sycamore Park? You know how they have a giant jungle gym?"

Luke squints at her. "What's your point, Samantha?"

She throws up her hands. "We climb it."

You stare at her. "That's your idea of reckless?"

"[name], [name], [name]. We are technically too old to be climbing playground equipment. Which makes it forbidden. Pretty reckless if you ask me."

"This conversation is stupid, and we have a lot of stupid conversations."

Luke shrugs, smirking now. "I don't know, man. Climbing sounds kinda fun."

You blink. "You're agreeing to this?"

"I need to move and sitting here thinking about the game isn't going to help at all." He looks at Samantha. "Race you there?"

Samantha's eyes light up. "Oh, fuck yes."

And just like that, they take off, sprinting like two kids on a sugar rush.

You groan and begin reluctantly jogging after them. "Why do I know one of us is gonna break something."

Samantha cackles over her shoulder. "That's what makes it fun!"

You can't help but laugh as the three of you run, the loss already starting to feel a little less heavy.

[Choice: Run!]

passages.name: Day 12 - Game Spectator 8
passages.text:
The playground looks smaller than you remember.

It's funny—when you were kids, this place felt huge. The jungle gym was a towering fortress, the swings sent you flying higher than you ever thought possible, and the metal slide felt like it went on forever. Now, under the flow of the streetlights, it's just an empty playground in a quiet park. The wood chips are scattered unevenly and the paint on the monkey bars is slightly faded.

But none of that really matters.

Not to you.

Not to Luke.

Not to Samantha.

Luke and Samantha don't slow down as they reach the jungle gym. Samantha jumps onto the first platform without hesitation, gripping the bars like she's a kid again. "Alright, losers," she calls over her shoulder. "First one to the top wins. Last one there is a rotten egg."

Luke doesn't hesitate before climbing up after her. "You didn't say go."

"When did I say I play fair?" Samantha replies, already scrambling up another level.

You shake your head, but a grin tugs at your lips as you follow. The bars are cool under your hands and the structure creaks slightly under your weight, but there's something oddly familiar about the movement. Something that feels easy.

Luke is already near the top, moving with the kind of effortless coordination you'd expect from an athlete. On the other hand, Samantha is struggling to pull herself onto the highest platform, legs kicking as she struggles to get enough momentum to swing herself up.

Luke watches her for a second before leaning over and extending a hand. "Need some help?"

"I got it, don't worry," Samantha insists, twisting awkwardly as she tries to hoist herself up. She finally manages to flop onto the top platform, landing flat on her back. She stares up at the sky, panting. "I totally meant to do that."

You make it up last, pulling yourself onto the top level and settling into a sitting position, legs dangling over the edge. Luke stretches his arms over his head, looking out at the empty park. "Man. When's the last time we even came here?"

Samantha sits up. "Middle school?"

"Yeah, middle school," you repeat. "Back when we thought staying out past sunset made us cool."

Luke laughs. "Hey, that did make us cool."

Samantha nudges him. "Yeah, until we got yelled at for it."

There's a comfortable pause.

The kind that settles deep in your bones, stretching across the years like a bridge back to simpler times. The three of you sit there, side by side, looking out over the quiet streets. The distant hum of cars, the occasional flicker of a porch light, the warm glow of the streetlamps—it's all so familiar, yet just far enough to feel like another lifetime.

A cold breeze drifts through the playground, rustling the trees and stirring up the scent of wood chips. You breathe it in, and for a second, it feels like nothing's really changed at all. Like you're all kids again, back when nights like this stretched on forever, back when time didn't feel like it was slipping through your fingers.

Luke resists his arms on his knees, starting out at the park with a small, wistful smile. "Remember when we used to play freeze tag here?"

Samantha snorts. "No wonder that's the game you remember, you always won."

Luke shrugs. "I was fast."

"You weren't just fast, you were insanely fast," you say. "I remember you sprinting across the entire playground in, like, two seconds."

Samantha points at him. "You do realize it was a playground game, right? Not the Olympics."

Luke chuckles. "You're just mad I never let you win."

Samantha scoffs. "One of these days, I'm tripping you."

You all go quiet again, listening to the wind and the distant sounds of the world. You remember how this place used to be everything—how a jungle gym could be a castle, how the swings could make you feel like you were flying, how the sandbox was a battleground for the most intense imaginary wars. You remember staying out until the streetlights flickered on, pretending not to hear your parents calling you home just so you could have one more second of freedom.

Samantha sighs, stretching out and staring up at the night sky. "Man. Why did growing up ruin this?"

"What do you mean?" Luke asks, leaning back on his hands.

"This," Samantha says, gesturing vaguely at the playground. "Just... being here. It used to be the best thing in the world. We'd come here after school, after practice, after whatever, and just run around like idiots for hours. Now we don't really get that before we start thinking about all the stuff we have to do."

You let her words settle and realize she's right. There was a time when everything you have to deal with now didn't matter. When nights like this were endless and when the biggest problem in the world was deciding who got to seek in hide-and-seek.

Luke exhales, staring up at the stars. "Hell, maybe we just forgot how to enjoy it."

Samantha hums thoughtfully. "Yeah, maybe."

You close your eyes and let yourself feel it—the wind on your face, the scent of the night air, and the metal bars cool against your skin. You let yourself believe, just for a moment, that you're still ten years old, that tomorrow isn't waiting with responsibilities and expectations. That the only thing that matters is this—the three of you, together, on an old jungle gym under the stars.

.

.

.

You open your eyes.

The world hasn't changed. But somehow, you feel just a little bit lighter.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

 
 
 
 
 

[Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 12 - Game Spectator 9
passages.text:
Eventually, the silence is broken by the creak of shifting metal as Luke lets out a deep breath. "Alright," he says. "As fun as it was to reflect on our childhoods, I think my legs are starting to go numb."

"Ugh," Samantha groans dramatically. "Moving? Sounds fake."

Luke smirks. "You can stay up here if you want. But if you get stuck, I'm not going to help you down."

"Coward," Samantha says, clicking her tongue.

Still, she's the first to move, swinging her legs over the edge and carefully maneuvering her way down the jungle gym's bars. Luke follows soon after, his descent effortless.

You take a second longer before climbing down, letting your fingers trail along the cool metal, committing the feeling to memory. It's stupid, sure, but a part of you wants to hang onto this moment just a little longer.

By the time you reach the ground, Luke has already dropped onto one of the wooden benches near the swings, stretching his legs out in front of him with a sigh. Samantha flops onto a different bench a few feet away, dramatically sprawling out with her arms thrown over her head.

"I'm going to live on this playground now," she announces. "Tell my family I love them."

Luke snorts. "How about you tell them yourself, drama queen?"

"I can't, Puke. This is who I am now."

You shake your head and smile. You glance at Luke, who's tilting his head back and watching the sky. He looks lost in thought, his usual easygoing demeanor has dulled a little, like he's still working through the game in his head. Samantha, on the other hand, looks completely at ease, arms crossed behind her head, eyes half-lidded like she might fall asleep right there.

Now, standing between them, you have a choice.

[Choice: Sit with Luke]
[Choice: Sit with Samantha]

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout
passages.text:
The drive to Jessica's house is filled with chatter and laughter, the kind of energy that only really comes from a team riding the high of a big win. When you finally arrive, Jessica pulls into the driveway of a large, modern house that practically screams comfort and style. The front yard is meticulously kept, with soft outdoor lights illuminating the stone pathway leading to the door.

"Alright, everyone, welcome to my humble abode," Jessica says, stepping out of the car. She unlocks the front door and pushes it open, revealing an inviting interior with high ceilings, plush furniture, and warm lighting.

"Wow," you murmur, stepping inside.

"Make yourselves at home," Jessica says, tossing her keys onto a nearby table. "Living room's straight ahead. I'll grab the snacks."

As you step into the spacious living room, you notice a massive couch in front of a huge flat-screen TV mounted on the wall. A soft throw blanket is draped over the back of the couch.

"This place is as insane as I remember it being," Mia says, plopping down onto the couch and stretching out. "Jess, I'm officially moving in."

"You'll have to fight me for it," Ashley jokes, settling onto the other end of the couch.

Jessica reappears a few minutes later, her arms laden with snacks: bowls of chips, cookies, candy, and a few cans of soda. "Here we go!" she announces, setting everything down on the coffee table.

Tori grabs a can of soda and cracks it open. "Alright, so, what's the game plan for tonight? Are we doing movies, games, gossiping? I'm down for all of the above."

"Hmm, [name]," Jessica says, turning to you with a teasing smile, "Since this is your first official team hangout, you get to pick what we do first."

 
 
 
 
[Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout 1
passages.text:
You think about what activity you want to do.

 
 [Choice: Play truth or dare]
 
 
 [Choice: Get into some gossip]
 
 
 [Choice: Play spin the bottle]
 

 
 You decide to finish up for the night.

 [Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout 2
passages.text:
As the night winds down, the energy shifts to a relaxed buzz. The remnants of snacks are scattered across the coffee table—empty soda cans, crumpled chip bags, and an empty bowl of popcorn. The group sprawls lazily across the sectional couch, completely at ease.

Jessica stretches her arms over her head, letting out a small yawn. "Alright, team, I hate to say it, but I think we've officially partied ourselves out," she says with a laugh.

"Speak for yourself, Jess," Mia replies. She tries to sound energetic but she's lying flat on her back, head resting against the couch arm. "I could do this all night."

"Sure, you're the one who started nodding off first," Ashley teases.

"Look, Ash, I was just resting my eyes."

"Alright, let's start cleaning up," Jessica says. "My parents will kill me if they come home to this mess, even if I tell them it was for the sake of team bonding."

Everyone groans and gets up, starting to gather up the empty bowls and trash. One girl gathers the cans and throws them away while others wipe down the coffee table. Jessica grabs the throw blanket draped over the couch and folds it before throwing it back into its spot.

"You good, [name]?" Jessica asks, giving you a smile as you collect the last of the popcorn.

"Yeah, I'm alright," you reply, feeling oddly at peace. For all the chaos you went through today, it's hard to believe the night has ended on such a comfortable note.

"Thanks for coming, by the way," Jessica adds. "It really wouldn't have been the same without you. I think the team's better with you on it."

You blink, surprised by her sincerity. "Thanks. It means a lot to hear that from you."

Once the squad finishes cleaning up, everyone gathers near the door, exchanging hugs and goodbyes. The night air feels cool as you step outside, the world quiet now.

"Carpool's heading out!" Tori says, jingling her keys. "Hop on, I'll give you a ride."

You nod, grateful for the offer, and soon find yourself riding in the back of Tori's car as she drives through the streets with a few other girls. By the time you're dropped off, the house is dark, save for a single porch light. You sigh, placing your head on the doorknob and pushing it open.

[Choice: Finish up after a long day]

choices.text: Finish up after a long day

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout Gossip
passages.text:
You settle into the couch, grabbing a handful of popcorn as the others dig into the snacks. You glance around the room and decide the vibe is just right. "Okay, hear me out," you say, drawing their attention. "What if we just... talk? You know, catch up on the latest gossip?"

Mia perks up immediately, launching forward. "Yes! Finally, someone who gets it. Gossip is the best part of nights like this."

"[name]'s throwing us straight into the deep end, huh?" Jessica says, raising an eyebrow in amusement. "But we need to set some ground rules if we're doing this. No spreading anything mean or serious, alright? Only fun stuff."

"Yeah, obviously," Ashley says. "We're not just your run-of-the-mill teenage gossips. We're classy gossips."

"Classy?" a girl laughs, nearly choking on her drink. "Aren't you the one who tried to spread the rumor that the new girl was actually an alien last year?"

"You can't blame me, she did give off alien vibes," Ashley responds, completely unbothered. "Anyway, we've got to focus—who are we dishing about first?"

Everyone turns to you, waiting for you to pick the target of the night's playful interrogation.

"It's your call, [name]," Jessica says, reclining back into the couch. "You started this, so you've got to pick who we're talking about."

You decide you want to gossip about one of your best friends first.

[Choice: Luke]
[Choice: Samantha]

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout Gossip 1
passages.text:
You pop a chip into your mouth, leaning back with a grin. "Alright, what about Luke?" you say, glancing around the room to gauge their reaction.

 "Luke?" Mia repeats, tilting her head. "You mean, like, the wide receiver Luke? Tall, goofy, always smiling?"

 "Yeah, that's my best friend, alright," you reply. "The really chill one."

 Jessica lets out a laugh, shaking her head. "Luke's the human equivalent of a golden retriever. What's there to gossip about? He's just... Luke."

 "Exactly!" you say, sitting up. "That's exactly why we should talk about him. He's so happy all the time, I feel like there's got to be something interesting beneath it all that he's not telling me. There's no way someone's that perfect, right?"

 Ashley snorts. "Oh, [name]. Sweet, naïve, [name]. There's nothing beneath Luke's golden retriever energy because that's literally all there is. I mean, don't get me wrong, the guy's great—but he's about as deep as a kiddie pool."

 "Hey, don't be mean," Tori chimes in. "He's a sweetheart."

 Mia grins, nudging you. "You know he talks about you constantly, right? He likes you. The guy probably thinks you walk on water or something."

 "I don't know about that," you say, rolling your eyes. "Luke probably likes everyone that isn't horrible."

 Jessica taps her chin thoughtfully. "I feel like we're missing an opportunity here. Maybe, just maybe, Luke's got a dramatic backstory. Like, what if he's pretending to be all cheerful because... his dad was not a good guy. And he's trying to make everyone happy."

 Ashley raises an eyebrow, smirking. "What, like he's going around saving people because he couldn't save himself as a kid? That's way too deep for Luke. The only secret he's hiding is probably how many burgers he can eat in one sitting. He's not exactly layered, you know?"

 The group falls into giggles, the conversation spiraling into increasingly crazy theories. At one point, Mia suggests he's a Russian spy, while Tori insists he's a secret billionaire.

 Jessica shakes her head. "You know, I think Luke's simplicity is part of his charm. he's not some complex character or a walking enigma. He's just... happy. And honestly? That's kind of refreshing."

 "Yeah," you say with a laugh, realizing the conversation has went from gossiping about Luke to roasting his one-dimensionality. "Sometimes a golden retriever is just a golden retriever."

 
 You lean forward, resting your elbows on your knees as a sly smile creeps onto your face. "Alright," you say, glancing around the room. "What about Samantha?"

 The room goes silent before breaking into a mix of laughter and surprised exclamations.

 "Samantha?" Jessica says, her eyebrows shooting up. "[name], you've got guts to gossip about your own best friend. Also, she's the most un-gossipable person ever. What's the tea?"

 "No one ever talks about Samantha because she's so... she's such a... Samantha," Mia says. "She's got that sarcastic, too-cool-for-drama vibes."

 "That just makes her more interesting," a girl adds. "[name], why don't you spill. You know her better than any of us do—what's she been up to?"

 "I mean, we're friends, but she's not exactly forthcoming about her life, you know?" you say. "She acts like nothing ever gets to her, but there's got to be something going on beneath the surface. I've known her for ages now but I still don't feel like I truly know her."

 "Totally," Jessica nods thoughtfully. "I've always wondered what her deal is. She's really closed off."

 "She's probably too busy coming up with snarky one-liners," Tori says with a laugh, popping a chip into her mouth. "Seriously though, how the hell does she do it? It's like she has a database of insults ready to go at all times."

 "Right?" you laugh. "She's too quick sometimes."

 Mia rests her chin in her hand. "Do you think she's hiding something big? Like a secret crush or a double life?"

 Ashley gasps dramatically, clapping her hands together. "Oh my God, I knew it! She's like Hannah Montana or something. Or maybe she's secretly in love with someone, and that's why she's so prickly. Who do you think it could be?"

 "Okay, let's not turn this into some soap opera," Jessica says, rolling her eyes. "But still... she's always so quick to call other people out. I wonder if she's afraid of letting people call her out for once."

 You think back to all the times Samantha has deflected attention away from herself with a well-timed joke or sarcastic remark. "She's definitely got walls up," you say. "But I don't think it's about being mean or catty. She's just... careful."

 "I mean, you're her best friend, [name]," Tori says. "Don't you know anything about her home life?"

 "I'm not... sure?" you say, realizing you know a lot less about Samantha than you thought you did.
 

As the laughter dies down and the conversation wraps up, Jessica stretches out on the couch. 

"That was fun but we're not done yet," she says. "Come on, [name], you're on a roll tonight. Who's next on the Pacific Crest gossip chopping block?"

The rest of the squad leans in eagerly, their eyes sparkling with anticipation. You glance around, feeling the squad's excitement radiating toward you. There's a pause as you think about who to bring up next.

[Choice: Jordan]
[Choice: Vincent]
[Choice: Aurora]

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout Gossip 2
passages.text:
"Okay," you say with a grin. "What about Jordan?"

 That gets a reaction. Jessica raises an eyebrow, while Mia lets out a small laugh.

 "Jordan?" Mia asks. "Jordan the quarterback? Mr. Stoic himself? Oh, this should be good."

 A girl crosses her arms. "Honestly, I don't think I've ever seen him talk to anyone unless it's about football or telling someone to move out of the way."

 "Exactly," you say. "Doesn't that make him more interesting to talk about? He's the best player on the team, but does anyone actually know anything about him? Like, what's his deal?"

 "Didn't you talk to him once?" Mia asks as she nudges Jessica with her elbow. "During that team dinner thing?"

 "I tried," Jessica says, rolling her eyes. "He just kept giving me one-word answers. Not exactly a bonding moment."

 "Maybe he has a tragic backstory," Tori says, shrugging. "I mean, have you seen the guy? He always looks like he's thinking about the meaning of life or something."

 You laugh softly. "Yeah, he's definitely carrying something. He's usually not rude, but there's this... distance, you know? Like he doesn't want anyone getting too close."

 "I've heard rumors that his parents are super intense," Jessica says, a flicker of understanding crossing her face. "Like, former athlete intense. If they're the kind of people who think losing is unacceptable..."

 "That would explain a lot of his behavior," a girl adds. "It's like he doesn't let himself enjoy anything because he's too busy trying not to screw up."

 "I guess that's the downside of expectations," Jessica says, letting out a small sigh. "Everyone wants something from you, and no one stops to ask what you want."

 The room falls quiet for a moment as the lighthearted energy gets replaced by a more reflective mood. You feel a strange sense of curiosity about Jordan, wondering just how much he's not revealing about himself.

 Tori breaks the silence with a small laugh, trying to lighten the mood. "Well, if anyone could crack him, it'd probably be you, [name]. You've got this way of getting people to talk without them realizing it."

 You chuckle, though part of you wonders if she's right. Maybe there's more to him than anyone realizes.

 
 You tap your fingers on your knee as you think until a name pops into your head.

 "What about Vincent?"

 The reaction isn't as loud or excited as before. Instead, there's a pause as the squad processes the name.

 "Vincent?" Mia repeats, furrowing her brow. "The kid with glasses? Quiet guy? Barely talks to anyone?"

 "Yeah, that's him," you say, nodding.

 Jessica raises an eyebrow, intrigued. "Huh. That's... different. Not gonna lie, I don't think I've ever heard anyone say his name during a gossip session."

 "Exactly!" a girl says. "Like who even is Vincent? I don't think I've ever seen him hang out with anyone. He's just kinda... there."

 "Yeah," Tori chimes in. "I mean, I see him in the hallways sometimes, but he's like a ghost. Doesn't talk, doesn't make eye contact, doesn't exist outside of class."

 "I didn't even know about him until a couple of weeks ago," you shrug. "He's in my gym class."

 "Wait, you actually talked to him?" a girl asks, her eyes wide. "What's he like?"

 "He's a good guy. A little shy, but solid."

 Jessica raises an eyebrow, intrigued. "Gym class is an odd place to start a friendship with someone like him. He doesn't really scream 'team sports'."

 "He doesn't," you agree, a small smile tugging at your lips as you recall how that first interaction went. "We played pickleball against these assholes who were being rude to Paige."

 "Who would be rude to Paige?" Tori asks, annoyance in her voice. "What happened?"

 
 "We won, obviously," you say, a smile on your face. "We shut them up."
 
 
 "I messed up and we lost," you say, sighing as you recall that moment.
 

 "It sounds like Vincent warmed up to you pretty fast though, don't you think?"

 "Pretty much," you say, nodding. "I think he's just... looking for someone to talk to. Someone who doesn't make fun of him or blow him off. He started treating me like we were friends after, like, two conversations. It caught me off guard at first, I'll admit, but..."

 "But it's kinda sweet, isn't it?" Mia finishes for you.

 "I guess, yeah," you admit. "I think he doesn't really have many people he can trust, so when he finds someone who's nice to him, he clings to it. He has been a really good friend so far though."

 "Well, I'm glad he's found you," Jessica says. "You're probably exactly the type of friend he needs right now."

 As the conversation shifts and the squad begins chatting about something else, Vincent lingers in the back of your mind. Whatever his story is, you know he deserves at least one person in his corner. For now, maybe you can be that person.

 
 You lean back into the couch, smirking as the name comes to you. "Alright," you say, lowering your voice to match the mood you're about to create. "What about Aurora?"

 The room falls silent almost instantly as if the name itself has power over everyone present.

 "Oh, now you're just being bold," Ashley says. "Like, Aurora? The Aurora? The girl no one ever talks to unless they absolutely have to?"

 Jessica raises an eyebrow, clearly intrigued. "That's an interesting choice, [name]. To be honest, I've been curious about her too. She's... I don't know, kind of fascinating in her own way."

 "Fascinating? More like terrifying," Mia interjects. "That girl gives me chills. She's so quiet and serious all the time, and she's always reading those weird-ass ancient books. Like, what even are those? Grimoires?"

 "Alright, [name], you brought her up—spill," Jessica says, a knowing smile on her face. "What do you know about Aurora? You don't just pick someone like her at random."

 You hesitate for a moment, wondering how much to say. You know Aurora isn't just some mysterious girl—she's someone who knows about your curse.

 "She's... different," you say carefully, trying to find the right words. "I feel like she knows things—things other people don't."

 Ashley snorts. "Yeah, like how to freak people the fuck out by just standing there."
 
 "You don't think she's actually into magic, do you?"

 Jessica tilts her head, considering it. "All I'm saying is that it wouldn't surprise me. She has that kind of presence like she's always one step ahead of everyone else. She's said some freaky stuff too."

 "She's intimating too, but not in an obvious way," a girl says. "You just know not to cross her. You just feel like she's got something up her sleeve."

 You nod slowly, remembering the way Aurora had looked at you once. Her piercing purple eyes seemed to see straight through you, like she was looking into you rather than at you.

 "I don't know, I've talked to her a couple of times, she's not what you'd expect, you say. "She's not mean or anything. Just... different."

 "Different how?" a girl asks. "Like, does she actually do magic?"

 "Oh my God, she's a witch," Mia says, her eyes practically bugging out of her head. "She's an actual witch. [name], what's going on? Did you get hexed?"

 "Calm down," Jessica says, snickering. "You guys are going way too far."

 For now, you laugh along with the squad. You are a little disappointed that they don't know more though. Aurora will remain an enigma—for now.
 

[Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout STB
passages.text:
You glance around the room, noticing how comfortable everyone seems right now. The vibe is perfect—light, fun, and just a little chaotic. "What if we play spin the bottle?"

The room goes quiet for a second, and then Jessica raises an eyebrow. "Oh, so that's what you want to do, [name]?"

"[name], I didn't know you had it in you!" Mia says dramatically, clutching her chest. 
 
 "Choosing the game where you get to kiss a bunch of girls. Smooth move, rookie."

 
 "You just finished up your first game as a cheerleader and now you're trying to charm half the squad."
 

"You know what?" one girl says, nudging another. "I'm in. Let's do it."

"Why not, right?" Ashley shrugs, a small smirk tugging at her lips. "It'll certainly make things interesting."

"Alright, Pacific Crest High Cheer Team!" Jessica says, clapping her hands together. "Rules are simple—you have to kiss whoever the bottle lands on. And no chickening out. Are you sure you're ready for this, [name]?"

"I suppose we'll find out," you say, a nervous laugh escaping your lips.

The group shuffles into a loose circle on Jessica's living room floor, clearing space on the rug. The bottle is placed in the center, and everyone watches as it wobbles slightly.

"Alright, [name]," Jessica says, gesturing toward the bottle with a flourish. "Since this was your idea, you go first."

You reach for the bottle, your palms slightly clammy. The whole squad watches you intently, their expressions ranging from intrigued to mischievous. With a quick flick of your wrist, you spin it, watching as it slows down gradually before coming to a stop.

 
This is RNG!
 

[Choice: Who does it land on?]

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout STB 1
passages.text:

 The bottle slows to a stop, its neck pointing directly at Jessica.

 "Well, well," Jessica says as the room erupts. Her voice carries an almost theatrical air of amusement, but there's a faint flush in her cheeks that she's not able to hide fast enough. Her eyes flick to you, narrowing as if she's trying to size you up.

 "Guess it's your lucky day, [name]," she teases, her smile curving just enough to seem playful, though her gaze lingers on you a little too long.

 The others start egging her on, cheering and clapping as she leans just the slightest bit forward. You're not sure if it's the lighting or your own nerves, but you think that her expression softens as she gets closer.

 You're aware of how close she is, her blue eyes locking onto yours for a moment that feels far longer than it actually is. Her gaze bores into you, almost as if she's searching for something. Maybe she's looking to see if you're nervous too. Or maybe she's just as unsure as you are.

 Then, before either of you can hesitate any longer, she closes the distance.

 Her lips brush against yours, soft and warm, lingering just a moment longer than they should. The room erupts into cheers and laughter around you, but it all fades into the background. For that fleeting moment, it's just you and her. Jessica and [name].

 When she pulls back, her cheeks are definitely flushed, but there's a shy smile on her face that's completely unlike her usual confident smirks. She looks away for a second, running a hand through her ponytail before locking eyes with you again.

 "Well," she says, her voice quiet. "You're not bad at this, huh?"

 The others are still joking and teasing but Jessica seems to tune them out, her gaze lingering on you for just a beat longer. There's something unreadable in her expression before she laughs quickly and leans back. "Alright, who's next?" she asks, reclaiming her usual composure. Her tone is light and playful but her fingers fidget briefly with the hem of her skirt as the bottle spins again.
 <<elseif [feminineLooks] > 59 or [d12makeup] > 0>> 
 As the bottle slows, your heart thuds in your chest. It finally slows to a stop pointing directly at Jessica.

 "Well, well, well," Mia says. "Our fearless leader is up first. This should be good."

 Jessica raises an eyebrow, her expression caught somewhere between amused and resigned. She flicks her ponytail over her shoulder and sighs dramatically. "Alright, rules are rules," she says, a teasing lilt in her voice. "But don't get any ideas, [name]. This doesn't make us a couple or anything."

 The group laughs at the jab but you catch the faintest flicker of something else in her eyes. It's subtle, gone in a flash, but you can't help but notice it as she shifts her weight and turns toward you.

 "C'mon, [name]," she says, her tone a little too practiced. "Let's just get this over with."

 You nod as you lean in, trying not to overthink it. Your cheeks burn, but Jessica looks perfectly composed. Almost as if she's treating this like a performance. The kiss is quick—a simple peck on the lips, nothing more—but the squad cheers like you pulled off a championship-winning stunt.

 "Whoo! Look at you two go!" Tori exclaims, clapping loudly. "First game and first kiss—[name]'s having a night!"

 Jessica pulls back, a distant smile firmly in place. She wipes an imaginary smudge off her lips with the back of her hand and laughs. "Okay, that's enough excitement for one spin. Who's next?"

 The game continues but Jessica doesn't immediately rejoin the banter. She leans back on her hands, watching the bottle spin again with a calm but detached expression. It's subtle but you notice how she keeps glancing at the others instead of looking at you. She doesn't seem uncomfortable just... unaffected by it all.
 
 
 
 As the bottle slows, the group leans forward in anticipation. Your heart skips a beat when it stops, pointing directly at Jessica. Her confident grin falters for just a moment, replaced by a look of surprise. She recovers quickly, but something about the moment feels off.

 Jessica leans back on her hands, a flicker of tension in her eyes as she glances at you. "Well, looks like it's me," she says, noticeably being careful with her words. "Let's get this over with."

 Mia gasps dramatically, clapping her hands. "Oh my God, the captain and the rookie! This is so iconic!"

 "You better make it good, [name]," a girl says, winking at you. "Jessica has high standards."

 Jessica laughs at that, although it sounds forced. "Yeah, don't let me down, superstar."

 You swallow hard, suddenly feeling the weight of the attention on you. You lean in, your face inches from Jessica's, but you can feel how still she becomes when you go for the kiss. Her body tenses ever so slightly, and while she doesn't pull away outright, you can tell she's not entirely comfortable.

 The kiss itself is brief—just a quick peck on the lips that's over in a second—but it feels awkward, like something mechanical. Jessica pulls back immediately, giving you a smile that doesn't quite reach her eyes.

 "There," she says, brushing her hair over her shoulder as though nothing happened. "Satisfied?"

 The squad cheers and laughs, oblivious to the subtle undercurrent. Jessica, ever the leader, plays it off perfectly. "Your turn, Mia. Let's keep this moving."

 As the group's attention shifts, you glance at Jessica in hopes of a sign that everything's fine. But she avoids your gaze, focusing instead on the bottle as Mia spins it. Her posture is relaxed, but there's something guarded in the way she carries herself now.

 The rest of the game continues but you can't shake the feeling that something's changed. Jessica has no problem laughing and joking with the rest of the squad but doesn't address you directly.
 

 
 As the bottle slows to a halt, it lands squarely on Mia. Her bright green eyes widen slightly before curving into a playful grin. "Oh, looks like it's my lucky night," she teases.

 The squad erupts into laughter and cheers, the energy in the room buzzing with excitement. "Go on, [name]!" Jessica urges. "Rules are rules."

 You glance at Mia, your heart racing in your chest. There's no pressure in her gaze as she leans forward slightly, resting her chin on her hand. "Well? Don't keep me waiting," she says.

 You muster a grin, your cheeks warm, and lean forward across the circle. The distance between you feels like it stretches forever, and for a moment, the noise of the room fades into the background. Mia meets you halfway, her expression softening as she closes the gap.

 The kiss is quick and light—just a playful brush of lips, but that's enough to make your pulse race. When you pull back, Mia's grin returns in full force as she flops back against the couch. "Oh, [name], I think I'm swooning," she jokes, fanning herself with one hand.

 The squad bursts into laughter again. "Mia, you're such a drama queen," a girl says, tossing a pillow at her.

 "Look, I'm just living in the moment," Mia retorts, tossing the pillow back. "[name]'s a pretty good kisser. I've got to admit that."
 
 You feel your cheeks heat up again but Jessica takes control of the moment before you can respond. "Alright, alright, enough flirting. Whose turn is next?"

 
 The bottle spins and spins, wobbling slightly on the rug as all eyes are fixed on it. Your heart pounds in your chest as it slows down, inching closer to Ashley. When it finally stops, the room falls silent for a second before erupting into laughter and gasps.

 Ashley leans back on her hands, a smirk spreading across her face. "Well, well, well," she says. "Looks like someone's aiming high tonight."

 The others burst out laughing.

 "Oh my God, [name], bold move!" Mia exclaims.

 "This is about to get really interesting," Jessica adds, shooting you a sly grin.

 You feel your face heat up, but barely manage to keep your cool. Ashley watches you with a sharp gaze, clearly enjoying how flustered you are. But beneath her teasing, there's a flicker of genuine amusement in her eyes.

 "Well?" she asks, sitting up straighter. "You're not backing out, are you?"

 There's a playful challenge in her voice, like she's testing you to see if you'll rise to the occasion.

 You take a deep breath, doing your best to ignore the others' whispers and giggles. "Backing out? No way," you say.

 "Good answer."

 The room falls quiet again as everyone holds their breath. You close the small distance between you and Ashley, inching toward her. The moment feels oddly surreal, the air charged with a mix of excitement and nerves. When your lips finally meet hers, it's brief but not rushed—a light, fleeting touch.

 The second it's over, the room erupts into cheers and whistles.

 "Woohoo!" Tori says, clapping her hands.

 Mia fans herself dramatically. "Ten out of ten."

 "Not bad for a rookie," Jessica says with a laugh. "Ashley, what's the verdict?"

 Ashley leans back, crossing her arms with a mock-thoughtful expression. "Hmm... I'd say he passed," she says.

 You let out a breath you didn't realize you were holding, a mix of relief and exhilaration washing over you. Ashley's teasing smile softens and she gives you a small nod.

 "Alright, who's next?" Jessica says, grabbing the bottle and spinning it herself, sending the group into another round of excited chatter.

 
 The bottle slows, spinning lazily as everyone leans in closer. Your heart skips a beat as it finally comes to a stop, the neck pointing directly at Tori.

 Her eyes widen for a split second before she breaks out into a soft, easy smile. "Well, looks like it's me," she says, her voice calm but with a tinge of amusement. The rest of the squad erupts into playful hoots and teasing remarks.

 "Ooh, Tori and [name]!" Mia exclaims.

 Jessica smirks, nudging Tori with her elbow. "Guess we're about to see how your chemistry on the field translates to romance."

 Tori rolls her eyes at the teasing but doesn't seem fazed. She shifts her weight, turning to face you fully, her hair falling over her shoulder as she tucks it back with a quick motion. "You good with this?" she asks like she's giving you an easy out if you want it.

 Your nerves are buzzing, but the way she looks at you makes it easier to relax. You nod, managing a smile. "Yeah, I'm good."

 Tori leans forward slightly, her movements unhurried. The room goes silent except for the faint sound of a girl suppressing a giggle in the background. You meet her halfway, and while the kiss is quick and soft, it leaves your cheeks warm all the same.

 When you pull back, Tori's smile grows. "Not bad," she says.

 Before the teasing can go any further, Tori reaches for the bottle and spins it, smoothly redirecting the attention away from the moment. You appreciate her good-natured vibe and the way she made you feel comfortable, though.
 

[Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout TOD
passages.text:
You suggest playing truth or dare, and the room immediately lights up.

"Yes!" Mia exclaims, almost knocking over a bowl of popcorn as she sits up straight. "It's been forever since we played that."

"Forever as in, what, a week?" Tori teases, grinning as she grabs a soda.

"Oh it's on!" Jessica exclaims. "Get ready, [name]. We don't play nice in this house."

"Yeah," Mia adds with a wicked grin. "No wimpy truths or lame dares. We're going all in. No mercy."

Jessica grabs a soda bottle from the table, plopping it in the center of the group. "Let the madness begin!" she declares, spinning it with a flourish.

The bottle lands on a girl you don't know first.

"Truth or dare?" Jessica asks, a scary grin on her face.

The girl smirks. "Dare, obviously."

Jessica's eyes light up. "Alright. I dare you to go out in your uniform, run outside, and do a cartwheel in front of the neighbor's house while doing the school chant at the top of your lungs."

The room explodes with laughter, and the girl groans, throwing her head back. "You're evil. You know that, right?"

Jessica just shrugs. "Rules are rules, girl."

The girl mutters a string of curses under her breath as she marches off. A few moments later, she's outside, spinning and chanting at full volume while you all peek out the window, nearly crying from laughing so hard.

"Let's fight, Panthers! Blue and white, we own the night!"

When she comes back, red-faced and panting, she collapses dramatically onto the couch. "You all are the worst," she says.

The bottle spins again and lands on Mia.

"Truth or dare?" a girl asks.

Mia doesn't even hesitate. "Dare. Bring it the hell on."

"I dare you to call Jordan and tell him you think he should try out for the cheer squad because he'd totally rock a skirt."

"Fine," Mia says, grabbing her phone. "But if he thinks I've lost my mind, I'm blaming you."

You all fall silent as she dials Jordan's number, putting the call on speaker. When he picks up, his voice is as cold and serious as ever.

"What is it?"

"Hey, Jordan!" Mia says, her tone overly chipper. "So, we were all talking, and I just know you'd kill it as a cheerleader. Like the skirt? That would totally fit your vibe."

There's a long pause on the other end, and then Jordan hangs up without a word. The room explodes into hysterics.

The bottle spins again and lands on Ashley.

"Truth or dare?" Jessica asks.

Ashley smirks. "Dare."

Jessica taps her chin, clearly plotting something outrageous. "Okay, I dare you to text your ex and ask if you want to get back together. Right now."

Ashley's jaw drops. "Jessica, are you kidding me?! No way!"

"You said dare!" another girl chimes in. "Rules are rules."

With a dramatic groan, Ashley picks up her phone and starts typing, her face twisted in horror. When she presses send, she gasps.

"He read it, he read it!" Ashley says. "He's replying right now!"

"What is he saying?" Jessica asks, as all of you lean in. Ashley's phone buzzes, a response coming in. Jessica reads it out loud. "'Ashley, what the fuck?'"

"I HATE YOU ALL!" Ashley yells as the room dissolves into chaos.

Finally, the bottle spins and lands squarely on you.

All eyes turn to you, their collective grins pure mischief. Jessica rubs her hands together like a cartoon villain.

"Truth or dare, [name]?" she asks, her voice dripping with anticipation.

You hesitate, knowing you're about to walk into the lion's den either way.

[Choice: Dare]
[Choice: Truth]

 The room erupts into cheers and cackles of delight. "Oh, this is going to be amazing," Jessica says, her face lighting up.

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout TOD 2
passages.text:
You cross your arms and glare at Jessica, though the heat creeping up your neck and face probably ruins the effect. "No way. I'm not wearing that," you declare, shaking your head. "It's way too... frilly."

 Jessica raises an eyebrow, clearly unconvinced. "Oh, come on, [name]. Don't be a baby. It's just a dress—it's not going to kill you."

 "Yeah, what's the big deal?" Mia adds. "You'll look adorable."

 "I don't want to look adorable!" you sputter, your voice cracking slightly. The room bursts into laughter, and you feel your protests are only making your situation worse.

 "You're so bad at this, [name]," another girl says, smirking from the couch. "The more you fight it, the more obvious it is that you're curious. Just admit it—part of you wants to try it on."

 "What? No! I don't!" you insist, taking a step back as Jessica moves closer with the dress.

 "Oh, really?" Jessica teases. "Then why are you blushing so much? Not to mention you're stumbling and tripping all over your own words. Look, you've got two options: put it in yourself, or we'll help you. Your choice!"

 Tori cackles. "You know we're not bluffing."

 You hold up your hands defensively, but the squad is already closing in. "Okay, okay!" you shout, your voice cracking again. "I'll... I'll do it. Just stop looking at me like that."

 Jessica smirks triumphantly and tosses you the dress. "Good choice. Now, the bathroom's right down the hall. Go on. We'll wait."

 You glance down at the dress in your hands, the soft fabric fluttering slightly as if taunting you. For a split second, you consider booking it for the door—but the squad would probably tackle you before you made it anywhere close.

 "Take your time!" a girl calls after you. "We'll be here, imagining how cute you're going to look."

 As you close the door behind you, you can hear the giggles echoing through the hallway. You glance at yourself in the mirror, then back at the dress. Despite your protests, you can't help but feel curious. You've never worn anything like this before, and you're not sure if you're more embarrassed by the idea of it... or the fact that part of you actually wants to see how it looks on you.

 "Here goes nothing," you mutter to yourself.

 [Choice: Continue]
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You take a step back, holding up your hands as if to physically shield yourself from the dress. "Nope. No way. Absolutely not," you say, your voice firm and unwavering. "You can't make me wear that. I don't care how cute it is."

 The cheerleaders all freeze for a moment, Jessica still holding the dress in mid-air. The room, which had been buzzing with excitement just seconds ago, suddenly feels a lot heavier.

 Jessica's grin falters, her arms slowly lowering the dress as she glances between you and the rest of the squad. "Oh," she says, a hint of awkwardness creeping in. "I mean... it was just for fun."

 Mia looks at you, her expression dimming. "Hey, no big deal," she says, trying to shrug it off. "We get it. If you're not comfortable, it's totally fine."
 
 Jessica quickly folds the dress, trying to smooth things over. "We'll just do something else," she says. "It's not a big deal, really."

 You can tell the group is trying to move past it, but the energy in the room has definitely shifted. The teasing and laughter that filled the air just a minute earlier have been replaced by a slight tension like everyone's trying to figure out how to reset the mood without making you feel worse.

 [Choice: Continue]
 
 
 
 
 You glance at the dress a moment longer, feeling your face heat up as everyone waits for your answer. Then, before you can even stop yourself, you blurt out, "Alright, fine. Let's do this."

 Jessica raises an eyebrow, her grin widening. "Wow, no hesitation, huh?"

 "Yeah, no need to twist his arm," Mia says, laughing as she nudges the cheerleader next to her.

 "I mean, if it's for the dare, right?" you stammer, trying to sound nonchalant but failing. "rules are rules."

 Jessica's eyes narrow playfully as she hands over the dress. "You're surprisingly eager, [name]," she teases.

 "Don't read too much into it," you mutter, though the truth is you're struggling to hide your curiosity. There's a strange flutter in your chest as your fingers brush the soft fabric.

 "Uh-huh," Ashley says. "Just admit it—you're kinda into it."

 You shake your head. "I just don't want to lose the game, alright?"

 There's a hum of excitement in the air, the squad exchanging knowing looks as you grip the dress a little tighter than you mean to. For a moment, it feels like they're all in on some joke you haven't caught up to yet. For some reason though, you can't help feeling a bit... excited yourself.

 "The bathroom's down the hall, good luck!" Jessica exclaims.

 [Choice: Continue]
 

 
 
 
 
 You glance around the circle, feeling the weight of their expectant stares, and you decide to be honest. You take a breath and nod slightly. "Yeah, I do," you say, keeping your voice steady. "And... it's a guy."

 There's a pause for a moment as if the whole squad is processing what you just said. But then Jessica grins, clapping her hands together.

 "Yesss, I knew it!" she exclaims. "I mean, come on—look at [name]. He's got taste!"

 Another girl squeals, leaning forward with her elbows on her knees. "Okay, this just made the game so much better. You're not getting out of this without giving us some hints."

 "Alright, spill," one says. "We don't need a name but what's he like? Is he on the football team? Is he cute? Is he tall? Give us something, [name]!"

 You laugh, feeling the heat rise in your cheeks at their relentless enthusiasm. "Look, I'm not giving you any details," you say firmly. "I'm already regretting picking truth."

 "Come on, you're killing us here," Mia adds. "Just one tiny hint? Like, does he at least know you exist?"

 "Or is this a secret crush situation?" Jessica presses.

 "You all are relentless, you know that?" you say, shaking your head. "No, I'm not giving you anything else."

 "Ugh, you're no fun!" a girl yells out.

 "But [name], if you ever need someone to hype you up or help you make a move, we're here," Jessica says, nudging you with a grin on her face. "You've got the whole cheer squad on your side. You're basically unstoppable!"

 "Yeah, you've got a team of wingwomen now," Tori adds with a wink. "Not to brag, but we're very good at matchmaking."

 You can't help but laugh, their acceptance making you feel lighter than you expected.

 "Thanks," you say. "I'll keep that in mind... maybe."

 "Maybe?!" Jessica says. "More like definitely. There's no 'maybe' about it."

 The squad continues tossing out ridiculous guesses and half-baked theories about your mystery crush, but it's all in good fun. Even as the game moves on, you can feel their support lingering in the air, making the night feel even more special.
 
 
 
 
 You hesitate, your heart thudding in your chest as all eyes stay locked on you. Finally, you nod slightly, a small smile tugging at the corner of your lips.

 "Yeah," you admit, your voice soft but steady. "It's a girl."

 The reaction is instant.

 "Oh my God, I knew it!" one girl shouts.

 "Who is she?!" Mia blurts out.

 Another girl practically squeals. "This is huge! Okay, you don't have to tell us her name, but we need some details."

 Jessica tilts her head slightly, her lips curling into a teasing smile. "So, what's she like? Cute? Smart? Both?"

 You laugh nervously as the whole squad starts firing off questions like it's an interrogation. "Alright, alright, calm down," you say. "I'm not giving you anything more than that."

 "Nooo, come on!" Ashley groans. "You can't just drop a bomb like that and leave us hanging."

 "You're lucky we don't force you to tell us," Tori says. "But seriously, give us something. Like, does she at least go to Pacific Crest?"

 <<if [jessicaRomance] > 9>> 
 Jessica leans back against the couch, her smile softening as she watches you. "Leave him alone, guys," she says, her tone light. "If he wants to keep it private, that's his choice. Right, [name]?"

 You glance at her, surprised but grateful for the rescue. "Yeah," you say. "Thanks."

 There's a flicker of something in her expression—just for a moment, so brief you might've imagined it. A little spark in her eyes, a slight shift in her smile. But before you can dwell on it, she shrugs, tossing a handful of popcorn into her mouth. "Don't get too comfortable, by the way. I'm still going to figure it out eventually."
 
 
 Jessica, who's been quieter than usual, leans back against the couch. "Fine, we'll back off—for now," she says, holding up her hands to call a truce. "But don't think you're off the hook forever, [name]. I will figure it out eventually."

 The rest of the group groans but takes Jessica's lead. Jessica winks playfully before popping a piece of popcorn into her mouth, clearly satisfied with her declaration.
 
 
 
 You shrug, feeling the weight of everyone's expectant stares. "Honestly?" you begin. "I'm not crushing on anyone right now."

 "What?! No crush? Not even a tiny one?" Mia groans, flopping dramatically onto the couch as if she's just heard the most tragic news of her life. She grabs a pillow and throws it at you, although it ends up landing harmlessly at your feet.

 "That's so boring," Ashley agrees, shaking her head with mock disappointment. "You're telling me there's not one person at school who's caught your eye? Like, no one?"

 You laugh nervously, holding up your hands defensively. "What can I say? I'm too focused on cheerleading."

 Tori giggles, reaching for a handful of popcorn. "Alright, that's fair. But there's got to be someone you think is cute. Even if it's just a random celebrity or something."

 Jessica waves them all off, rolling her eyes but smiling. "Hey, leave [name] alone! Not everyone has to be crushing on someone 24/7. Maybe [name]'s just too mature for us and has other things to worry about."

 "Or," a girl interjects, "he's secretly crushing on someone and is just too scared to admit it."

 "You guys are relentless," you say, shaking your head as the room bursts into laughter.

 "Of course we are," Jessica replies, grinning as she tosses a piece of popcorn at you. "You should've known this would happen when you joined the squad. Welcome to the chaos."

 "Ugh, fine," Ashley says. "Hey, he gets the pass—for now. But we will revisit this."

 Jessica leans forward, spinning the bottle again to move the game along. "Okay, next victim!" she says with a wicked grin.

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout TOD 3
passages.text:
Jessica Dress Achievement Unlocked! 
 
 
 Standing in front of the mirror, you hold the dress up. For a moment, you hesitate, staring at your reflection. The pink fabric looks almost out of place compared to what you usually wear, but there's something about it that pulls you in.

 You sigh, your face already burning with embarrassment. "They're never going to let me live this down," you mutter, pulling the cheerleading top off.

 The dress feels impossibly soft as you pull it over your head, the cool fabric brushing against your skin. You fumble with the straps a little, adjusting them so they fit properly on your shoulders. The bodice hugs your torso in a way that feels foreign but not uncomfortable. You smooth the skirt down, the layers of fabric settling around you like a gentle cloud.

 <<if [transgender] > 9>> 
 Stepping back, you glance at yourself in the mirror, and your breath catches.
 
 You look different.

 The floral pattern, the puffed sleeves, the delicate bows—its just all so far removed from anything you'd normally wear. The dress transforms your reflection into something more whimsical, almost like you've stepped out of a fairytale.

 Your hands nervously smooth the skirt again, feeling the lightweight layers sway with even the slightest movement. It's... cute. You hate to admit it, especially to yourself, but it's really cute.

 You turn slightly, examining yourself from the side. The way the skirt flares out when you move makes you feel oddly graceful, like you're floating. For a moment, you forget about the squad waiting outside and the teasing that's bound to follow. All you can think about is how strange—and fun—it feels to see yourself like this.
 
 
 You glance at yourself in the mirror, and your breath hitches for all the wrong reasons.

 The floral pattern, the puffed sleeves, the delicate bows—it all feels so alien, so out of place on you. It's like staring at someone else entirely, someone you don't recognize and definitely aren't sure you want to meet. The dress doesn't just feel wrong—it makes you feel wrong.

 You shift uncomfortably, tugging at the straps and fidgeting with the skirt. The lightweight fabric sways with every movement, reminding you of just how out of your element you are.

 For a brief moment, you consider taking it off, storming out of the bathroom, and declaring the dare a bust. But it's just a dare, right? It doesn't mean anything.

 "It's fine," you mutter to yourself, forcing your hands to stop fidgeting. "It's just a stupid dress. It doesn't matter."
 

 A sharp knock on the door makes you jump.

 "[name], you alive in there?" Tori calls out.

 "I'm fine!" you shout back.

 "Better hurry!" Jessica teases.

 [Choice: Step out]

 
 The bottle spins again, and this time, it lands squarely on Jessica. The room goes wild with cheers and laughter as everyone leans in, eager to see what'll happen.

 "Alright, bring it on," Jessica says, grinning confidently. "Truth."

 The squad looks at each other, murmuring ideas, but you clear your throat first. 

 "Hold up," you say, feeling a grin of your own creeping onto your face. "I'm asking this one."

 The room erupts in "ooohs" as all eyes turn to you. Jessica arches an eyebrow, her smirk unwavering. "Alright, [name]," she says, resting her chin in her hand. "Let's see what you've got for me."

 You pause for dramatic effect before offering up the question.

 [Choice: If you had to date someone on the football team, who would it be?]
 [Choice: Did you ever crush on a cartoon character as a kid?]
 [Choice: Have you ever had a crush on anyone on the cheer squad?]

passages.name: Day 12 - Hangout TOD 4
passages.text:
<<if [transgender] > 9>> 
 The moment you step out of the bathroom, the room explodes.

 "Oh. My. God," Jessica says, her hands flying to her face in astonishment. Her wide grin shows she's absolutely thrilled with the result. "[name], you look... adorable. Like, ridiculously cute."

 Mia claps her hands together, bouncing in place. "I knew it! I called it! I knew you'd look amazing in that dress. Like, look at you—it's like you were made to wear this."

 You groan, trying to play it cool as you awkwardly tug at the hem of the dress. "Alright, alright, you've had your fun. Can I take it off now?"

 "Absolutely not," Jessica says firmly, stepping forward and gently swatting your hands away from the skirt. "You're not taking it off yet. It looks way too good on you."

 Another girl crosses her arms, her expression amused. "It's unfair how cute you look right now. I don't know if even Jessica can wear it after this."

 Your face burns as you throw your hands up in frustration. "Okay, enough with all the 'cute' stuff, alright? This is just for the dare."

 "Oh yeah, of course," Mia says, her tone dripping with sarcasm. "It's just for the dare, right? Nothing to do with how amazing you look or how much you're secretly enjoying it. Right?"

 You shoot her a glare, but before you can say anything, Jessica steps in. "Come on, [name], you've got to admit it—you look amazing," she says. She takes a second, studying you with an approving smile. "Actually, you know what? You should keep wearing it. It suits you."

 "What?" you say, blinking at her in disbelief. "You seriously want me to just... stay in this?"

 "Why not?" Ashley asks, shrugging. "You've already got it on. Might as well own it."

 Another girl giggles, wanting to join in the teasing. "You know, you could totally pass for a princess in that dress. [name], the royal cheerleader!"

 "Stop!" you groan, burying your face in your hands as the squad erupts into laughter. Despite the relentless teasing, there's no malice in their voices—just a playful warmth.

 Jessica pats your shoulder, her tone gentler now. "Relax, [name]. You're rocking it, I swear. No one here's going to make you feel bad about keeping it on."

 Her words calm you slightly, and you exhale, letting your hands drop. "Fine," you say, rolling your eyes. "I'll keep it on. But only because you're all forcing me to."

 "Sure, sure," Tori says. "Whatever helps you sleep better."

 You settle back into the group, still acutely aware of how the dress swishes with every movement, but the atmosphere is so welcoming that you let yourself relax a little. For now, you'll let them have their fun—and, if you're being honest with yourself, you might even be having a little fun too.
 
 
 As soon as you step out of the bathroom, the squad bursts into laughter and cheers.

 "[name], oh my God," Jessica says, doubling over as she claps her hands. "You look so cute!"

 You groan, tugging at the hem of the dress awkwardly. "Alright, you've had your fun. Can I take this off now?"

 "No way," Mia says. "You have to at least keep it on for a bit. Rules are rules. And honestly? You're rocking it."

 "I hate this," you mutter, crossing your arms.

 "Oh come on, it'll be fine," Jessica says, patting your shoulder.

 You huff, feeling heat crawl up your face as the squad laughs and teases you. Despite their energy, you're counting the seconds until this dare is over.
 

 
 
 "If you had to date someone on the football team, who would it be?" you ask.

 Jessica's grin falters for the briefest of moments when you ask the question. Her confident posture shifts slightly as she bites her lip. The rest of the squad erupts into laughter and squeals of anticipation, clearly thinking you've just thrown her the curveball of the night.

 "Oh my God, [name]," a girl gasps, clutching her stomach as she laughs. "That's brutal."

 Ashley fans herself dramatically. "This is about to be good. Spill, Jess."

 Jessica forces a light laugh. "Wow, you really went for it, huh?" she says.

 "Come on, Jess, you have to answer," Tori says, leaning forward eagerly. "it's the rules!"

 Jessica hesitates, her eyes darting around the room. Finally, she leans back, crossing her arms in mock exasperation. "Alright, fine. If I absolutely had to date someone on the football team..." She pauses dramatically.

 "Probably Luke," she blurts out finally, sounding forced.

 The room explodes with laughter and cheers.

 "Luke?!" a girl shrieks. "Oh my God, you'd destroy him! He's, like, the goofiest guy on the team."

 "Yeah, but he's, like, sweet," Jessica says quickly. "And funny. I think."

 Mia giggles. "Okay, but can you imagine Luke trying to have a deep, meaningful conversation? So, uh, do you like... football?"

 The room dissolves into another round of laughter, and the entire squad teases Jessica. Jessica takes it for a while, but eventually leans over to grab a handful of popcorn, clearly trying to signal the end of her turn. "Alright, can we move on now? Or are we going to keep psychoanalyzing my nonexistent football romance?"

 "Fine, we'll move on," Mia says, rolling her eyes.
 

 You grin mischievously, the perfect question forming in your mind. Jessica narrows her eyes at you, sensing trouble.

 "Alright," you say, trying to sound as casual as possible. "Did you, Jessica Sanders, ever have a crush on a cartoon character as a kid?"

 The room bursts into laughter and excited reactions.

 "Good one, [name]!" a girl exclaims.

 Jessica freezes for a moment, caught off guard, before leaning back and putting on an air of confidence. "Oh please. Like I'm going to get embarrassed by that question. Everyone crushed on a cartoon character as a kid."

 "Well, then spill!" Mia urges. "Come on, Jess. Who was it?"

 Jessica rolls her eyes and crosses her arms. "Okay, fine, but don't laugh," she starts. "When I was, like, seven, I might've had a tiny crush on... Starfire. From Teen Titans."

 The room goes quiet for a moment and then erupts into playful chaos.

 "Starfire?!" a girl laughs. "Oh my God, I can totally see that."

 "Well, she is pretty cute, though," Ashley says, nodding thoughtfully. "I mean, she's got the whole sweet, bubbly thing going on. i get it."

 Jessica's rambling starts before she realizes what she's doing. "Right? Like, she was so nice and kind of innocent but also badass when she needed to be. Plus, her hair was amazing, and she had that cute way of talking with, like, the weird phrases and—"

 She stops mid-sentence, her eyes going wide as she realizes how much she's just said. The room falls into a brief, stunned silence, and you can see the faintest flicker of panic on her face.

 "Uh, I mean... who didn't have a crush on Starfire, right?" she blurts out, her voice suddenly louder and overly casual. "She's, like, objectively cool, and, um, it's not weird or anything. Everyone thought she was cute, no?"

 Jessica fumbles with a piece of popcorn, popping it into her mouth as if that will somehow erase the last 30 seconds.

 Ashley raises an eyebrow, a smirk playing on her lips. "Jessica, you just talked about Starfire like she was your soulmate."

 "Yeah," Mia chimes in, her grin mischievous. "Is there something you wanna share with the class, Ms. Sanders?"

 Jessica laughs—too loudly—and waves them off. "No, no, no. You guys are just reading into things way too much. It was just a dumb childhood thing."

 She looks around, her smile strained, but nobody presses her further. The teasing simmers down, though you notice her glancing around nervously. For a moment, you think about saying something, but the game spins on, and the attention shifts to the next person.
 
 
 You try your best to keep your expression neutral, though you're grinning on the inside. "Alright, Jessica," you say, locking eyes with her. "Have you ever had a crush on anyone on the cheer squad?"

 <<if [jessicaRomance] > 9>> 
 Jessica's grin falters ever so slightly, and she doesn't look quite as confident as she usually does. The room erupts in gasps and laughter at your question, with Mia practically falling off the couch.

 The queen bee laughs nervously, brushing a stray strand of blonde hair from her face as she straightens up on the couch. "Wow, [name]," she says, keeping her tone light. "Way to hit me with the big guns, huh?"

 You shrug, trying to maintain an innocent facade. "You said to bring something juicy."

 The group is fully focused on her now, their anticipation thick in the air. Jessica shifts slightly, her fingers fidgeting with the hem of her sleeve.

 "But no, I don't have a crush on anyone here," Jessica says, her voice having the slightest tremble.

 "Lame," Mia complains.

 "Hate to break it to you, but I'm enjoying the single life," Jessica says. "Hey, blame [name] for asking a bad question. He should've known I'm immune to this."
 
 
 The room explodes immediately as the squad whoops in excitement.

 Jessica, to her credit, keeps her cool. "First of all, no," she says, holding up a hand like she's silencing a courtroom. "I've never had a crush on anyone on the squad."

 The room groans in exaggerated disappointment.

 "Lame," Mia complains.

 "What do you guys think this is, some kind of soap opera?" Jessica snorts. "Like I'm secretly pining over one of you? Please. As if. Like, the squad is family. Do you have a crush on your cousins? No? Exactly."

 "You're letting us down, Jessica," Tori jokes, shaking her head in disappointment.

 Jessica shrugs, grinning as she grabs a handful of popcorn. "Hey, blame [name] for asking a bad question. He should've known I'm immune to this."
 
 
 

[Choice: Continue]
