The curated calm of NovaTrend and the sensory overload of Threadz made you feel like you were on two completely different planets, and now you're back in neutral territory.

Jessica takes a moment to smooth her hair. "Okay," she says. "That was... productive. But we're not done. There are still options."

Samantha falls into step beside you, sticking her hands deep into the pockets of her baggy jeans. "Define 'options,'" she says, drawing out the word like she already knows she's not going to like half of them.

Jessica ticks them off with her fingers. "ShatterBox, Blink + Shine, StepUp Footwear, and Cuddle Creations."

"Okay, so, let's translate that," Samantha says. "Dark-and-edgy emo cave, a glitter bomb disguised as a store, the shoe maze, and a place where you'll drown in stuffed animals."

"Or, if you wanna be less dramatic, stylish alt fashion, a fun accessories spot, a versatile shoe store, and, yes, a plushie haven."

Samantha grins. "I can't tell the difference."

"Look, I'm still trying to process how I survived the last two stores," you say. "Maybe let me breathe before we sign me up for more rounds."

"Survived?" Jessica repeats with a smirk. "Come on, [name]. You thrived."

"I tolerated," you say.

Samantha leans a little closer, squinting at you like she's trying to read your mind. "You're not actually dreading this, are you? Come on, you've got to admit it—you're kinda having fun."

"You got me there," you reply, chuckling.

"StepUp is a solid choice," Jessica comments. "We haven't even discussed shoes. Trust me when I say the right pair can make or break an outfit. According to Sam, you've been wearing those ragged Converses since, what, middle school?"

"They're comfortable," you protest.

"I'm sure they are," Jessica says. "But more options never hurt."

You glance between the stores, the options swirling in your head. There are four stores with four completely different vibes. And you have to choose.

ShatterBox has dark walls, racks of fishnets, studded belts, combat boots, and merchandise from bands you don't even recognize. Mesh sleeves and eyeliner are practically required.

Blink + Shine is so sparkly it's practically vibrating. Hair clips, lip gloss, and enamel pins shaped like raccoons are on display.

StepUp Footwear, a staple of the Crestview Bay mall, has so many shoes it nearly makes you dizzy.

Cuddle Creations has so many adorable stuffed animals that the cuteness might just overwhelm you.

You take a deep breath, scanning the glowing signs ahead, and make your decision.

 
 
 
 
 
 
[Choice: Head to ShatterBox]
[Choice: Head to Blink + Shine]
[Choice: Head to StepUp Footwear]
[Choice: Head to Cuddle Creations]
[Choice: Head to the changing rooms]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 17
passages.text:
Broke Achievement Unlocked! 
 
 
 

The walk back through the mall is a mosaic of shopping bags and tired feet, storefront windows still doing their best to lure you in even though you've both hit your browsing limit. You end up in the center of the mall, where there's a big fountain that you've passed at least six times today. It feels weirdly like coming full circle.

Samantha immediately collapses onto the nearest bench like she's been mortally wounded. She flings some shopping bags onto the ground with an exaggerated sigh. "Oh my God," she groans, slumping back like the bench has become her deathbed. "This is it. My final resting place. Tell the world I died bravely in the battle of Retail Armageddon."

Jessica sits down more gracefully on the other side, smoothing her skirt with one hand while balancing some shopping bags in the other. "You're so dramatic," she says lightly, though her tone carries just enough warmth to soften the jab. "We barely walked a mile, Sam. You didn't even try anything on."

"Yeah," you add, taking the spot in the middle. "You did a whole lot of sitting and judging, which I'm not sure counts as cardio."

Samantha tips her head toward you, squinting one eye. "Listen, [name]. I walked emotionally. That burns more calories than you think."

Jessica rolls her eyes but grins. "You know that's not a thing, right?"

"It is now," Samantha replies, folding her arms like that ends the debate.

"You two are ridiculous," you say as you stretch out your legs.

Jessica glances at the bags in your lap. "You actually found some good stuff today, though. I'm impressed."

"Yeah," you say. "I guess I did."

Samantha sits up a little. "You definitely did. Even if I can't relate to half of it. I mean, look at me." She gestures to herself. "Do I scream 'soft pastels' to you?"

"Not even a little," you say, smirking.

"Exactly."

Jessica leans in conspiratorially, pointing a manicured finger at Samantha. "You'd look good in pastels. Admit it."

"Blasphemy," Samantha says immediately. "I'm a dark creature of hoodies and sarcasm. You can't just... pastel-ify that."

"You're just scared of a little color," Jessica singsongs.

Samantha pretends to gag. "And glitter. Don't forget glitter."

You laugh. It just all feels so easy. Lighter than most of the day.

Samantha suddenly lets out another loud groan. "Okay, but for real? I'm starving. Like, I could eat the entire food court. Even the cardboard pizza and weird smoothies."

Jessica perks up at that. "Oh, finally. I was wondering how long it would take for you to say that. I've been thinking about those pretzel bites since we walked in here."

"I mean," you say, gesturing vaguely toward the escalator, "we could go to the food court?"

Samantha lifts her head slowly. "Could we? Dare we? Will our weary legs carry us that far?"

"You were literally fine two minutes ago," Jessica points out, standing and slinging her bags over her arm. "Come on. It's food. That's all the motivation you need."

You stand too, offering Samantha your hand. "Come on, my overworked friend. I promise there'll be carbs."

She takes your hand and stands up. "Ugh. If I collapse on the way there, just roll me in the direction of carbs."

And with that, the three of you march onward toward your well-earned nourishment, your bags swaying gently with each step.

[Choice: Food!]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 18
passages.text:
The food court is buzzing with the usual chaos—laughter, trays clattering, the hum of soda machines, and the comforting scent of everything fried, grilled, or baked in bulk. You, Samantha, and Jessica push your way through the flow of shoppers until you spot a table near the center—close enough to the food counter but far enough away from the kids. The table wobbles a little as you touch it, and the plastic chairs are unforgivingly hard.

Classic mall food court.

"Finally," Samantha says, throwing herself into a chair like she's just finished an Olympic event. "If I had to endure one more boutique, I was gonna pass out."

"You survived, though," Jessica says, sitting next to her. "And for what it's worth, you don't exactly seem like you hated it."

"You saw me in Blink + Shine, I looked really out of place," Samantha deadpans.

You plop down across from then, letting your shopping bags settle around your feet. "To be fair, you didn't exactly try to blend in."

"Anyway," Jessica says, segueing the conversation. "Before one of us dies from hunger, what do you want? My treat."

You blink. "Wait. What?"

Jessica digs into her purse and pulls out a card, sliding it across the table toward you. It's sleek, shiny, and way too fancy for this mall. A bright, silvery-blue thing with embossed letters.

It takes you a second to process. "Is... is this a American Distress Platinum? Holy shit."

"Yep," Jessica says, but there's no real shine behind it. "It's my dad's account, but... it's basically mine. Perks of being an only child."

The words feel like they should be smug, but she delivers them with the energy of someone reciting a fact. Her fingers drum against the table once before going still.

You tilt your head. "That... sounds nice?"

Jessica shrugs, her ponytail shifting with the movement. "It's... whatever. They don't really care what I spend, as long as I don't do anything 'embarrassing.'" She says it with a mocking little air-quote gesture, but it doesn't land like a joke.

Samantha eyes her. "So, they just give you free rein on a platinum card and call it a day? That's kind of wild, Jess."

Jessica gives a small, brittle smile. "That's just how it is. They're busy. Always have been. You learn to, you know..." She waves her hand vaguely, like she's brushing off smoke. "Handle yourself."

There's a pause that feels heavier than it should.

You shift in your seat. "That sounds like a lot."

Jessica meets your gaze for half a second, then looks away, like you caught her saying too much. "It's fine. I'm used to it. Anyway, go get your food. Pick whatever you want."

Her voice lightens, but only on the surface.

You glance down at the card in your hand, its metallic sheen reflecting the mall's bright food court lights. It suddenly feels heavier than it should.

You clear your throat. "Alright. Guess I'll... figure out what I want."

You scan the nearby stalls, where a number of choices are spread out in front of you.

Pizza Hüt is a proud European chain that acts like putting an umlaut in the name makes their pizza cultured. The pizza's fine, but the crust is oddly sweet and the pepperoni looks like it was printed on. It's the kind of spot you eat at and then wonder if maybe you were just really hungry.

Loud branding, flat burgers, and enough sauce to coat your soul. That's Burgur Kween. The combo deals are suspiciously cheap, and everything comes wrapped in foil with marketing slogans like "SLAY THE CRAVE." It doesn't help the fact that their burgers look like they've been sat on, though.

Kansas Fried Poultry is the home of greasy chicken and coleslaw no one ever finishes. It was founded by General Thatch, whose portrait still hangs in every location—white suit, bolo tie, and a thousand-yard stare. They swear by their "Legendary Eleven-Dust Blend™"—you're pretty sure most of the taste comes down to the MSG though. No one knows what's in the gravy, but you eat it anyway. General Thatch would want you to be brave.

Tacko Bong is Tex-Mex, but barely. You order it because it smells good, then immediately question your decisions mid-bite. It's fast, cheap, and tastes decent going in. But let's be honest here—you know what happens next. There's a reason why every bathroom stall near a Tacko Bong is mysteriously out of order.

Koala Express is an aggressively average Chinese fast-food chain that's somehow in every mall, airport, and food court, even though no one remembers it actually opening. The food is comforting in a suspiciously consistent way. The real mystery is the mascot: a grinning koala in a silk robe, holding chopsticks. No one knows why exactly an Australian marsupial is representing orange chicken, and the brand has never explained it. You're not here for the authenticity though—you're here because it smells good and hits the same way every time.

You weigh your options.

[Choice: Pizza Hüt]
[Choice: Burgur Kween]
[Choice: KFP - Kansas Fried Poultry]
[Choice: Tacko Bong]
[Choice: Koala Express]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 19
passages.text:
You approach the glowing red sign of Pizza Hüt—"Est. in Düsseldorf" printed beneath it in proud serif font. It's like you're entering enemy territory. The whole stall has a certain... vibe. Cold efficiency. The staff wear crisp red aprons and stare at you like they've been trained in the harshest of kitchens.

 The guy at the counter is tall, severe, and looks like his soul was forged in a bread oven. His name tag just reads GÜNTER.

 "Willkommen to ze Hüt," he says, with zero inflection. "You vill be having ze pizza, ya?"

 You blink. "Uh... yeah. Just a slice of pepperoni—"

 "Peperoniwurst."

 He types something with aggressive precision.

 You look at the menu. It's technically in English, but every word has been rebranded into something that nears parody. Zauce, Krustenplatte, Mozarrella der Schmeltz. There's a combo meal called "Die Trilogie der Käse." It's just a three-cheese pizza.
 
 "What drink comes with it?" you ask.

 He doesn't answer. He just slides you a room-temperature orange soda with the label peeled off. You're not convinced it's carbonated. Or legal.

 Five minutes later, your slice arrives in a little cardboard tray printed with the phrase "Life ist kurz. Eat die Hüt." There's a parsley leaf on it.

 You carry the tray back through the chaotic food court, the scent of your slice trailing behind you like a warning.

 Jessica spots you first, leaning forward in her chair as you approach. "Finally," she says, glancing at the tray. "Oh my God, you actually went to Pizza Hüt?"

 "I wanted pizza," you state simply, setting the little tray down on the table with a quiet thud.

 "Eat die Hüt?" Samantha reads aloud, making a face. "That sounds like a threat, [name]. Did you just buy food or enlist in the German military?"

 You plop into your chair. "Both. Probably."

 Jessica leans over the table to get a better look. "Is that parsley?"

 "Apparently," you say, gesturing vaguely to the lone, limp leaf perched on your slice like an afterthought. "The guy at the counter, Günter, gave it to me. He didn't smile. Didn't blink either. I think he was judging me for existing."

 "It's just Pizza Hüt, I guess," Jessica says, laughing.

 "No," you state. "This is not 'just' pizza. This is... a cultural exchange program disguised as a fast-food chain. Everything on that menu sounded like it was crafted by a mad linguist. Do you know what a three-cheese pizza is at Pizza Hüt? 'Die Trilogie der Käse.'"

 Samantha snorts. "Sounds like an avant-garde art piece."

 "Exactly." You nod gravely. "And they didn't even ask what drink I wanted. Günter just slid me an orange soda. Room temperature. Label gone. Like it was contraband."

 Jessica tilts her head, intrigued despite herself. "Are you still gonna drink it?"

 You pop open the soda and take a long sip. "This is diplomacy, Jessica."

 Samantha leans back, smirking. "So what's the verdict?"

 You take a bite of the pizza. It's chewy, sweet-sauced, faintly peppery, and inexplicably... orderly.

 You swallow, then meet their eyes with the gravitas of someone who has stared into the abyss and found mozzarella. "The Hüt delivers," you say simply.

 "It's just mall pizza!" Jessica says, bursting out laughing.

 "Mall pizza with structure," you correct.

 Samantha gestures at the tray. "You know what? This is your villain origin story. Next week you're showing up to school in a red apron, talking about 'ze discipline of ze crust.'"

 "Meh," you say, holding the slice and taking another bite. "If that happens, it'll be worth it."

 "Honestly? I kind of want to try it now." Jessica says.

 "Don't," you respond solemnly. "You're not ready."

 Samantha cackles. "Oh my God, this is amazing. [name]'s been converted. Pizza Hüt is a cult, and we've lost him."

 "If this is a cult, at least the pizza's decent," you state, shrugging.

 
 The scent of flame-grilled something smacks you the moment you pass under the neon crown-shaped sign. Burgur Kween isn't quiet. The whole place radiates confidence, hot grease, and glittery chaos. Purple lights frame the menu board. The soda machine's blasting music. And the staff? They are living in the moment.

 Behind the counter stands a tall server with long acrylic nails, gold hoop earrings, and a perfectly tied apron that looks more like a fashion statement than a uniform. Their name tag reads "Miss Patty", in Sharpie, with a tiny lipstick kiss drawn next to it.

 "Well hellooo, look who just stepped into the best restaurant in town, honey," they say, leaning dramatically on the counter. "What's your vibe today? Feeling crunchy? Crispy? Or just extra?"

 You blink. "Um... just a cheeseburger?"

 Miss Patty places one hand on their hip and gasps. "Just a cheeseburger? Baby, no. We don't do 'just' here. We do bold, juicy, life-changing."

 Someone in the back yells, "Drop a royal patty and crown it, darling!"

 Patty turns back to you. "That's for you, sweetness."

 You look up at the menu, which is a fever dream of specials with names like "The Glam Stack," "Double Drama," and "The Untucked Combo." You order a single burger and fries, and Patty nods like you've chosen your house for the season.

 "Ooh, a classic. Simple. Confident. I respect it. You don't need the extra sauce—you are the flavor."

 They slide your receipt across the counter with a wink. "Grab a straw with attitude, not one of those flimsy basic ones."

 You return to the table with a tray that looks like it just walked off a stage. Even the burger is wrapped in paper that says "SLAY ALL DAY" in all caps with glitter-print ink.

 Jessica's the first to notice when you sit back down. Her eyes eventually land on the crown. "Oh my God," she says, breaking into a grin. "They gave you a hat. Did you just get knighted or something?"

 "Uh, no," you reply. "I got crowned. There's a difference. Burgur Kween doesn't serve food. They serve an experience."

 Samantha leans forward, resting her chin on her hand, grinning like she can't wait for this. "Oh, this I've gotta hear. What happened?"

 You unwrap the burger. "I walked in, and the cashier—Miss Patty—looked at me like they could see into my soul and asked if I was feeling crunchy, crispy, or extra."

 Jessica giggles. "So which one are you?"

 "Well, I was hoping I'd be something fun, but I ended up with a classic," you say.

 Samantha bursts out laughing. "Shit, [name]. They saw you and decided to do a character assessment?"

 "Pretty much," you say, biting in the burger. It's perfect—messy, greasy, and way better than it has any right to be. "Also, someone in the back yelled 'Drop a royal patty and crown it, darling!' while they made my order. I think that might just be the best thing I've ever heard."

 "I love this place," Jessica exclaims, clapping her hands together. "I used to come here after shopping. They hype everyone up like they're about to walk a runway instead of just... sitting in a food court."

 "Exactly!" you say. "I didn't just buy a burger. I ascended."

 Samantha side-eyes the crown on your tray. "Yeah, and then they gave you a paper hat like you're five. Truly majestic."

 "Don't disrespect the crown," you reply. "It's a symbol of power."

 "Just eat your royal meal, Your Highness," Samantha states.

 You take another bite of the burger. Maybe, just maybe, you belong in the Kween's court.

 
 The smell hits you before the sign does—grease, salt, black pepper, and a kind of smoky defiance that makes it clear you didn't come here to be healthy.

 Kansas Fried Poultry squats in the corner of the food court like it owns the mall. The logo's just a silhouette of the state of Kansas wearing a cowboy hat, and the man behind the myth—General Thatch—is everywhere. His framed portrait hangs behind the counter, squinting like he's seen combat and invented cornbread in the same week. His statue holds a chicken drumstick like it's the Declaration of Independence. There's even a tattered American flag above the counter.

 The counter girl's leanin' on the register like it owes her money. Her faded name tag just says Mary-Beth and her apron's got cornbread batter scars.

 "Well, hey there, sugar," she drawls, voice slow as sweet tea left out in August. "You look like somebody with a deep hunger and questionable judgment. Lemme fix that fer ya."

 You open your mouth to ask a question, but she's already shaking her head.

 "Nuh uh. We don't do menus. We do chicken. Hot, proud, and real enough to bring a tear to your meemaw's eye."

 She turns and bellows into the back without looking. "Drop two thighs in the fire! And throw a mercy biscuit in there too, bless their heart!"

 She slaps a bucket on the counter with a thud that feels spiritual.

 "Y'all enjoy now," Mary-Beth says, wiping her hands on a rag that might've fought in the war. "And if it don't light a fire in yer chest, we'll bury ya with honor."

 You carry it back to the table like it's holy.

 Jessica's eyes widen immediately. "Oh my God. You didn't just get food, [name]. You got... something special."

 "That smell is illegal," Samantha states, taking a deep breath. "You walk past other people with that bucket and they're gonna start floating like cartoon creatures when they smell pie on a windowsill."

 You pull out a drumstick, the crispy skin glistening, and hold it up solemnly. "The woman at the counter, Mary-Beth, called me 'sugar,' insulted my life choices, and then blessed me with this. I think I might be baptized now."

 "Did you even get to order?" Jessica asks, leaning forward on her elbows.

 "No, 'cause she decided for me," you say, shaking your head in awe. "I tried to ask what combos they had, and she literally waved me off and yelled at someone in the back to 'drop two thighs in the fire and throw in a mercy biscuit.' I didn't even know what a mercy biscuit was."

 Samantha squints at the bucket. "A mercy biscuit sounds like something you eat after signing your last will and testament. Like, asking for mercy for what you're about to do to your arteries."

 You take a bite of the drumstick, and the skin cracks like a gunshot. It's spicy in a way that feels personal. "Holy shit," you manage. "This isn't chicken. This is... like... history. General Thatch didn't just fry a bird. He created a movement."

 Jessica snorts. "Okay, relax. It's just fried poultry."

 "You don't understand," you say. "There's a tattered American flag hanging in that place. And a statue of General Thatch holding a drumstick like it's the Constitution. They don't serve chicken. They serve patriotism in a bucket."

 "I bet patriotism tastes pretty damn good," Samantha says.

 "It's definitely worth the calories," you say, taking another bite.

 
 The closer you get to Tacko Bong, the more it smells like a college dorm microwave and the inside of a tortilla chip bag. Not bad, necessarily—just chaotic. There's a faded mural on the wall of a cactus wearing sunglasses and a beanie, holding a burrito like it's the Holy Grail. A little sign on the register reads: "Now Hiring. No Snitches."

 The guy behind the counter has half-lidded eyes and a name tag that says "Chaz", drawn in Sharpie. He's got a bandana tied around his head and a string of hot sauce pockets clipped to his belt like ammo.

 He stares at you for a long second after you approach. Almost as if he's buffering.

 "...Yo," he says finally. "You, uh... hungry?"

 You nod.

 He nods too.

 "That's sick. Me too, man."

 There's no real menu—just a few laminated photos taped crookedly to the sneeze guard. Cruncho Loco Supreme, Nacho Nacho Situation, and the Mystery Quesadilla (No Refunds).

 "I can, like... throw some stuff in a tortilla?" Chaz offers. "We got beans. Probably."

 A second guy appears from the back. You didn't hear him come out. His name tag says "Spoon", and he's holding a ladle full of neon-yellow cheese like it's a sacred artifact.

 "Dude, you want the drip?" he asks. "We got the drip."

 You pause. "What exactly is the drip?"

 He gestures at the ladle. "This. This is the drip."

 Chaz nods solemnly behind him, "It's, like, spiritual."

 You order something that sounds vaguely like a taco, hand over the card, and watch as they begin to construct your meal with an intense focus. There's a lot of unlabelled containers. You choose not to ask.

 Minutes later, you're handed a loosely wrapped bundle of tortilla, heat, and vibes. It drips. You're not sure what. But it drips.

 You return to the table holding your food carefully. The wrapper is already translucent from whatever's inside it—steam curling upward like it's trying to escape. It smells like melted cheese and danger.

 Samantha looks at it. Then at you. Then back at it. "[name]... what the hell did you just buy? That looks like it's been legally classified as a biohazard in at least a few states."

 "Oh my God, is that from Tacko Bong?" Jessica asks, grinning. "I've always wanted to try it, but like... I didn't want to die young."

 You peel back the wrapper, revealing a structurally unsound tortilla filled with... stuff. "I don't know what this is," you admit. "The guy who made it called it 'a transcendental bean event.'"

 Samantha blinks. "...He said that out loud?"

 "Yes," you say, nodding seriously. "And then his coworker asked if I 'wanted the drip.' I still don't know what that means. I just said yes."

 Jessica's laughing now, covering her mouth with her hand. "The drip. You just let them put mystery drip in your food? [name], that's how urban legends start."

 You lift the wrap slightly so they can see the neon-yellow ooze pooling at the bottom. "This is the drip."

 Samantha leans away like it might jump at you. "That looks like what happens when you leave nacho cheese out in the sun for a week. [name], I mean this in the kindest way possible, don't eat that. You have so much to live for."

 You take a slow bite.

 Both of them just stare at you, waiting for your reaction like you're a science experiment about to explode.

 It's hot. It's gooey. It tastes like every processed impulse you've ever had at midnight, wrapped in a tortilla and blessed by a divine entity.

 You swallow, staring down at it with a kind of distant respect. "...This is incredible."

 Jessica leans in. "You're kidding."

 "No," you say, taking another bite. "It's comfort food."

 Samantha squints at you. "You're gonna regret that in like four hours. Maybe less."

 "Probably," you agree, taking another bite anyway.

 Jessica laughs and grabs a napkin from the dispenser, tossing at at you. "At least don't drip 'the drip' on yourself. That stuff doesn't look like it comes out of clothes."

 "I doubt it would," you say. "I just didn't ask too many questions. Tacko Bong isn't about answers. It's about the journey."

 "You're braver than I am," Jessica says. "Or dumber."

 "Why not both?" you say before taking another bite.

 And even as Samantha mutters something about you being a lost cause, you can't help but think: she might be right. But you also can't stop eating.

 
 You spot the waving golden cat before anything else—perched proudly on the counter of Koala Express, its paw moving in slow, hypnotic arcs like it knows something you don't.

 The menu board glows red and gold, slick with laminated sheen, listing a staggering number of combos and sides. Every single one comes with two entrées and a side. The trays are already stacked, wide enough to double as life rafts.

 The server behind the counter doesn't look up as she greets you. "Hi, welcome to Koala Express. Do you want a combo or box today?"

 You glance down at the steam table. There's orange chicken glistening like a sunset, beef and broccoli soaking in sauce, and fried rice piled so high it's got elevation. Everything smells like soy sauce and sugar.

 "A combo?" you offer.

 "Good choice. Two entrées, one side. Orange chicken?" She's already spooning it into your tray before you nod.

 You pick a second dish. It doesn't really matter what you choose, they all look like they've been prepared by someone who knows what your soul needs and doesn't believe in small portions. The food is heaped on like gravity's on break. By the time she finishes adding a scoop of chow mein, your tray weighs more than your dignity.

 She throws in a crushed fortune cookie and an extra packet of soy sauce for "flavor insurance." Then comes the plastic lid, taped shut with serious intent. It barely fits. You nod your thanks, hand sinking under the weight as you turn to head back.

 You return to the table like a weary traveler dragging home his spoils, the Koala Express tray balanced in your hands like a brick of hot, edible treasure. The lid is puffed up like it's trying to escape the contents, held together by one brave piece of tape and sheer determination.

 You set the tray down with a thud that makes Samantha jump.

 "Holy—" Samantha leans forward, eyes wide. "[name], did you just order for the entire football team? That tray has its own gravitational pull."

 You peel the plastic lid back, steam billowing upward like you're opening a portal to another realm. "It's a combo meal," you say, as if that explains the absurd mountain of food. "Two entrées. One side. They didn't warn me it'd come with an existential crisis."

 Jessica leans in from across the table. "Oh my God, that looks amazing." She tilts her head, frowning thoughtfully. "But also... that is so much orange chicken. Are you even allowed to take that much in one sitting? Isn't there a law or something?"

 "If there is, they don't enforce it," you say, blowing on the chicken carefully. "Koala Express has no laws. Only portions."

 Samantha squints at the chow mein piled so high it could qualify as a small mountain. "That noodle mound has altitude. I think it's staring back at me."

 "Good," you say between bites. "That means it respects you."

 Jessica giggles, poking the fortune cookie toward you. "What does it say?"

 You unwrap it, crack it, and fish the crumpled paper from the rice. "Let me see," you say. "It says 'You are full of potential. And also rice.'"

 "That's not a fortune," Samantha says. "That's a cry for help."

 You shrug. "Well, it is accurate. I am currently about 80% rice."

 Jessica shakes her head, laughing. "At least they're honest. You basically have a week's worth of meals in there. You could survive an apocalypse with that tray."

 "Yeah, but I wouldn't survive long," you say. "I'd eat in all in one sitting and be too bloated to move."

 "I am not carrying you out of here when you slip into a food coma," Samantha warns. "Jessica can, though. She's tall. Built for it."

 Jessica tosses a crumpled napkin at her. "That's now how it works."

 You lean back in your chair. "If I pass out, just leave me here. This is where I live now. Among the chow mein."

 "Well, at least you're happy about it," Jessica comments.

 And honestly? You are. For all its chaotic energy and the sheer volume of food staring you down, Koala Express delivers. It's too much at once in the best possible way.
 

[Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 2
passages.text:
You slip your phone into your pocket and take a deep breath.

The house is quiet in that soft way it gets in the afternoon—sunlight filtering through the windows, the hum of the dryer spinning low in the background, and the faint scent of fabric softener floating in from down the hall. You head toward the laundry room, where you can already hear the familiar rustling of folded towels and the occasional thunk of the basket being adjusted on top of the dryer.

Your mom's standing there, sleeves pushed up, folding a warm pile of towels with practiced ease. There's a little smudge of something—probably flour—on her cheek from earlier, and her hair's tied up in a messy bun, a few strands curling loose at her temples.

She looks over when she hears your footsteps. "Hey, sweetie. Need something?"

You hesitate in the doorway for a second, then step inside and lean against the wall, watching her work. "Kind of. I, uh... was thinking of going shopping."

She raises an eyebrow, folding the towel in her hands into a perfect rectangle. "Shopping?" There's a flicker of surprise in her voice, though not in a bad way. More like someone just heard a cat bark.

"Yeah," you say, rubbing the back of your neck. "Like, for clothes. Stuff that fits better, maybe."

"Hmm." Another towel joins the stack. "Okay. And who's dragging you out for this mission?"

<<if [jessicaRomance] > 9>> 
 "Samantha," you say automatically, then add, "and... Jessica."

 Your mom pauses just enough to let you know she caught the difference in your tone. "Jessica?"

 "Yeah," you say, trying to sound casual, though you can feel your face warming a little. "Jessica Sanders. She's the cheer captain—you know, from school."

 Her eyebrows lift slightly. "Ah. So this is a new development."

 "Not really new," you say quickly, leaning against the doorframe. "We've been talking ever since we became partners in homeroom. She's actually... really easy to hang out with? Like, she's super nice. And funny. You'd think someone that popular would be, I dunno, stuck-up or fake, but she's not. She's actually really down-to-earth. Like, she actually listens when you talk."

 Your mom glances over her shoulder, smiling faintly. "Sounds like you think pretty highly of her."

 You rub the back of your neck, staring at the floor. "I mean... yeah, I do. She's just cool, you know? Not just, like, 'queen of the school' cool. More like she makes you feel comfortable. It's hard to explain."

 Your mom's smile softens, though she doesn't say anything to tease you. Instead, she folds another towel, stacking it neatly on top of the others. "Well. That sounds like a good addition to your shopping trip."

 "Yeah." You shift your weight, trying to keep your voice level. "She knows a lot about clothes too, so... she'll probably save me from whatever nightmare Samantha was gonna put me in."

 Your mom chuckles. "Now that, I believe."

 "Hey," you protest halfheartedly.

 "She's the cheer captain, you said?"

 "Yeah." You can't help but perk up a little. "Everyone knows her, obviously. But she's not just all image. She's been under a ton of pressure this year—like, way more than people realize—but she still makes time for people. Like, she'll stay after school just to check in on someone. I don't know how she does it."

 Your mom glances at you again, but she doesn't say what you can tell she's thinking. Instead, she reaches for her phone on the little shelf by the detergent.

 "What are you doing?"

 "Sending you some money," she says simply.

 "You don't have to—"

 "[name]." That's her don't-even-bother tone, and you shut up. "You're growing, you're figuring out what feels good for you, and you deserve clothes that actually fit that."

 
 You lean against the doorframe, fiddling with the hem of your shirt. "Samantha," you say first, because that's the safe, obvious answer. "And, uh... Jessica."

 Your mom freezes mid-fold. Not dramatically—just enough that you notice. "Jessica?"

 "Yeah." You nod. "Jessica Sanders. She's the cheer captain. You know, from school."

 "I don't think I've heard that name before," your mom says, her brows knitting.

 "That's because I've... probably never mentioned her," you admit, scratching the back of your neck. "She's usually being swarmed by, like, half the school."

 Your mom's face softens, curious now instead of questioning. "So... she's popular."

 "Yeah, she's one of those people everyone knows," you say with a shrug. "But she's easy to be around, not over-the-top or anything."

 Your mom gives you a small smile. "Sounds like a good addition to the trip."

 "Definitely," you say, leaning against the doorframe. "Figured it'd be fun to have her along. She knows clothes way better than I do, that's for sure."

 Your mom chuckles. "Sweetie, I love you, but that's not a high bar."

 "Wow," you say, pretending to be offended.

 "Well, you're going to have quite the crew," she says. "Samantha and... Jessica the cheer captain. I'm trying to picture how that dynamic's going to go."

 "Probably loud," you respond. "But manageable."

 "Mhm. Loud I can believe." She picks up her phone from the little shelf by the detergent.

 "What are you doing?"

 "Sending you some money," she says, like it's the most obvious thing in the world.

 "You don't have to—"

 "[name]." Her voice has that tone that implies you shouldn't bother arguing. "You're growing up. You deserve to have clothes that make you feel good in them."
 

A second later, your phone buzzes in your pocket. You pull it out and check the screen: [100] transferred. She even put a note in the memo: For cool outfits and snacks. Don't blow it all on something weird.

"Thanks," you say, grinning despite yourself.

She shrugs, tossing another folded towel onto the stack. "You can pay me back by not leaving your dirty clothes on the floor for me to pick up."

"No promises."

She points a finger at you in warning, but she's smiling.

You start to back out of the room, still glancing at your phone like the number might vanish. [money] USD. That's the most you've had in your account in a while. Before you're fully in the hallway again, you pause. "Hey, Mom?"

"Hmm?"

"Thanks. Really."

She doesn't look up from the laundry this time, just nods and says, "Have fun. Be safe. And tell Samantha I said hi."

"Will do."

"And Jessica, too. Even if she has no idea who I am."

You laugh under your breath, already backing toward the hallway. "Yeah, sure."

"Have fun," she calls after as you leave, and you can still feel the little bit of warmth in her voice as you head upstairs.

[Choice: Where's Sam and Jess?]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 20
passages.text:
Samantha plunks her tray down with a loud clatter that makes the flimsy table tremble, and you swear the smell of whatever she got could clear sinuses from ten feet away. It's fried. It's bright red. It's steaming like a warning sign.

"Behold," she says, gesturing to the pile of food like a magician unveiling their greatest trick. "The pinnacle of human achievement: food that's 80% grease, 20% pure malice."

You raise an eyebrow. "What even is that?"

She tabs a fork into one of the spiky fried things, sauce dripping off the edge. "I don't know, but it's spicy enough to kill me, and I respect that."

Jessica slides in next to Samantha, setting down her own tray with much more grace. Where Samantha's plate looks like it might start a bar fight, Jessica's is a neatly arranged bowl—greens, grilled chicken, and dressing on the side. Even her water bottle looks like it's judging you for your choices.

"Wow," you say, peering at it. "That's... surprisingly normal."

Jessica shrugs, picking up her fork. "It's all about balance. If I eat like this here, I can justify ice cream later."

"You do realize this is a mall food court, right?" Samantha says, staring at her bowl like it just insulted her family. "You don't come here for balance. You come here to gamble with your arteries."

"Some of us don't want to feel like death after lunch," Jessica says lightly. "Not everything has to be a dare, Sam."

Samantha takes a huge bite of whatever unholy fried object she's eating and talks through the chew. "Cowardice. That's what this is."

You shake your head. "She's going to combust halfway through that meal and try to blame us."

"Worth it," Samantha says without hesitation.

The three of you eat in comfortable chaos for a bit—Jessica stealing some of your food without asking (and giving you a very unapologetic smile when you notice), Samantha making exaggerated faces every time the spiece hits her tongue, and you alternating between your own food and watching them argue.

The fighting dies down eventually, replaced by that kind of comfortable quiet that only comes after a long day of doing a little too much. Samantha leans back in her chair, tossing her fork onto the tray like she's conquered the food, while Jessica picks at the last of her salad.

Then, softly, Jessica says, "I really appreciated today."

You glance up, a little surprised at the sudden sincerity at her tone. "Yeah?"

"Yeah." She nods. "I know it wasn't about me, but... I don't know. It was nice."

Samantha raises an eyebrow. "What? You're not even the one we dragged around shopping. Shouldn't [name] be the one giving emotional speeches?"

Jessica smirks at that but doesn't fire back right away. She takes a breath, tucking a strand of blonde hair behind her ear. "I guess I just... got to be myself today. Like, really myself. I wasn't worried if people were staring or if I said the 'right' thing. i just... hung out. Looked at ugly clothes. Laughed too much."

You exchange a glance with Samantha, and she's watching Jessica with a rare kind of seriousness.

Jessica shrugs like she hasn't just said something heavy. "I don't get to do that a lot, you know? Everyone always expects me to be so much. Friendly. Popular. Whatever. Today was just fun."

You and Samantha stay quiet for a beat, the clatter of the food court filling the space instead. Jessica doesn't usually open up like this. She's the one who keeps it together, who knows how to say the right thing at the right time, who makes everything look effortless. But now, at this moment, she's just... Jessica.

Samantha leans forward, resting her chin in her hand. "Well," she says, surprisingly gentle, "you don't have to do all that here. Not with us."

"I just appreciate it," Jessica says, her blue eyes bright but calm. "For letting me just be me today."

You shift in your seat as the words hang there.

[Choice: It's alright. I love you for you]
[Choice: You don't need to thank us. We like you for you]
[Choice: Well, you were still kind of perfect today]

choices.text: It's alright. I love you for you
You don't need to thank us. We like you for you
Well, you were still kind of perfect today

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 21
passages.text:
<<if [transgender] > 14 and [acceptance] > 19>> 
 
 "It's alright," you say, trying to play it casual even though you feel the words coming out of your mouth like you've crossed some invisible line. "I love you for you."

 It's supposed to sound offhand. A throwaway. Something people say when they're being reassuring.
 
 It doesn't.

 Jessica freezes mid-sip of her water bottle. "Wait," she says, tilting her head with an incredulous little half-smile. "You... love me for me?"

 You lift your hands in mock defense. "Not like that. I mean, like—'love' as in, you know, love. Not, like, love-love. Just—ugh, you know what I mean."

 Jessica sets her cup down, but her eyes don't leave yours. There's a small laugh in her throat, but it's softer than usual. "Do I?" she teases.

 You rub the back of your neck, heat creeping up your face. "I mean it in the way you say you love pizza or... sleep. Like, casual love. Friendly love. Don't get weird about it."

 She raises one perfect eyebrow. "Mhm. Sure. Casual love. Totally normal." 

 "Exactly," you say quickly. "See? You get it."

 She tilts her head and leans forward onto the table, resting her chin on her hand. "But still. You don't usually just say that kind of thing, you know? Like... 'love you for you.' It's kind of..." She trails off, lips tugging into a faint smile. "It's kind of nice to hear."

 You blink, unsure how to respond for a second. "Well, good," you say finally, deciding to lean into it. "Because I meant it. You don't need to perform or whatever. Not for me. You're just... Jessica. And that's more than enough."

 Her smile deepens. "You're kind of full of surprises, you know that?"

 You smirk, acting nonchalant though your heart's hammering. "I try."

 From across the table, Samantha's eyes dart between the two of you, wide and unblinking, like she's watching a live soap opera unfold. After a few seconds, she finally breaks the silence. "What the hell just happened?"

 You glance at her innocently. "We were talking."

 Jessica laughs, a little too pleased with herself. "Don't worry about it, Sam. We're just bonding."

 "Bonding," Samantha repeats flatly, rolling her eyes. "That's one word for it."

 As your eyes meet Jessica's, you can tell you're both thinking the same thing. The conversation wasn't as casual as you both pretended it was.
 
 
 
 
 "It's alright," you say, aiming for casual reassurance as you lean back in your chair. "I love you for you."

 Jessica blinks. Her expression flickers—surprised, maybe a little caught off guard—before she lets out a small laugh that doesn't quite reach her eyes. "Wow," she says. "That's a lot."

 You rub the back of your neck, suddenly hyperaware of how warm your face feels. "I didn't mean it, like—love love," you clarify quickly, flailing your hand a bit like that'll erase the weight of your words. "I meant, you know... just as a friend."

 She studies you for a moment—longer than feels comfortable—then gives a little nod, her smile polite but careful. "Yeah. I get it," she says softly, then adds, almost like she wants to make sure you really hear her: "And you're a really good friend, [name]. I don't want you to forget that."

 Something in the way she emphasizes "friend" lands like a soft thud in your chest.

 You laugh, but it comes out thinner than you intended. "Yeah. Right. Friends. That's... exactly what I meant."

 "Good. Because I appreciate it a lot. You're sweet, it's just that I..." she pauses, searching for words that don't quite show up, then settles on, "You know. I've got a lot on my plate. But it means a lot you said that."

 You nod quickly, not sure what else to do. "Yeah. No worries. I didn't mean anything by it."

 There's a stretch of silence before Samantha leans across the table, whispering with zero tact, "That was brutal, man."
 

 
 
 You don't even have to think about it.
 
 "You don't need to thank us," you say, leaning forward slightly. "We like you for you. That's... kind of the point, isn't it?"

 Jessica blinks, caught off guard, but a soft smile forms on her face. "That's really nice to hear," she says, her voice quiet but steady. "I don't know if I'll ever really be able to believe that, but that still means a lot."

 Samantha, who's been uncharacteristically quiet for the last thirty seconds, immediately cuts in, though her tone lacks its usual bite. "Okay, fine," she says. "I'll admit it. I liked hanging out with you today too, Jess."

 Jessica raises an eyebrow in amusement. "Oh? That almost sounded like a compliment."

 "Don't get used to it," Samantha fires back instantly. "But seriously. I kind of... thought wrong about you. Like, I figured you'd be a little shallow. Not in a mean way! I just mean—popular girl, perfectly styled hair, never a single thing out of place? You gave off 'too good for mall chaos' vibes."

 "And yet here I am," Jessica says with a smirk. "Eating in a mall food court with you two and somehow surviving."

 Samantha shrugs. "Yeah, well, turns out you can hang. Plus, you roasted me back a couple times today. I respect that. Most people just get steamrolled."

 You nod in agreement. "She really did. You got Samantha to shut up for a whole five seconds once. That's an achievement."

 "Bold words from the kid who nearly cried after scraping his ankle when we were kids," Samantha shoots back, smirking.

 "Oh, come on. That was ages ago," you protest. "And I did not nearly cry."

 Jessica laughs again, and for a moment it feels like you're all just kids with no stakes. When life was just simple.

 
 
 You grin, trying to lighten the mood. "Well, you were still kind of perfect today."

 Jessica's expression changes almost instantly. Her smile falters, the warmth in her eyes cooling to something distant.

 "Oh," she says after a moment, quiet and clipped. "Right. Perfect."

 The words lands like a brick.

 You want to take it back immediately, to explain that you didn't mean it like that, but she's already shifted her focus back to her bowl. Even though there's nothing left, she scrapes at the sides halfheartedly, her shoulders hunching just slightly.

 The worst part is she doesn't correct you. Doesn't joke it off. She just goes quiet, retreating into herself like the moment's been ruined.

 Samantha raises an eyebrow at you, silently asking what the hell you just did.

 The rest of the mall stretches on, heavier than before, the easy flow of conversation gone.
 

[Choice: All done!]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 22
passages.text:
Samantha wipes her hands on a napkin and leans back with a satisfied sigh. "Alright," she declares. "The next mission: ice cream."

You blink at her. "Ice cream? We literally just ate. Like, just now."

She stares at you like you've just spoken heresy. "And? Dessert is a separate stomach event. It's science, [name]. Look it up."

You raise an eyebrow. "Science?"

"Yes. Science. You think humanity just invented dessert for fun? No. We evolved to need it." She's already gathering her trash like the conversation is over. "We need balance. Salt, grease, then sugar. That's how you achieve true harmony."

You glance at Jessica for backup, but she only laughs, dabbing her fingers with a napkin. "Honestly? She's not wrong," Jessica says with a little shrug. "I could go for some ice cream. Sounds nice."

"See? Jess gets it." Samantha grins. "And you, my dear [name], are outnumbered."

You sigh. "Fine. But if I pass out from sugar overload, that's on you two."

"Great," Samantha says brightly, tossing her trash into a nearby bin. "I'll buy you a little cone. One scoop. Perfect."

You laugh as you stand, grabbing all the bags. "You're unbelievable."

"And yet, you follow me anyway," she says. "It's called charisma."

The three of you weave through the thinning food court crowd and make your way to the ice cream parlor. Samantha walks a few steps ahead, humming some unrecognizable tune under her breath, while Jessica falls into step beside you. The smell of waffle cones and vanilla hits first—sweet and warm, with that distinct promise of a sugar rush.

Samantha practically presses her face to the glass display. "Oh my God," she says with reverence. "Look at them. Look at all those flavors. They're beautiful."

"You're acting like it's art," you say.

"It is art," she shoots back, not even glancing at you. "Edible art. Art you can smother in sprinkles."

Jessica lingers near the menu on the wall. "Okay, but do we go classic? Or do we commit to one of these crazy flavors?"

"Do I dare mix the cookie dough with the cotton candy again?" Samantha mutters to herself.

"Didn't that give you a stomachache last time?" you ask.

"Yes," she says gravely. "And I learned nothing."

You step forward as the server behind the counter glances up with a smile, ready to take your order.

 
 You glance over the rows of colorful options, each more swirled and sprinkled and unique than the last... and go for vanilla.

 Classic. Safe. Uncontroversial.

 The moment the scoop hits the cone, Samantha lets out a slow, theatrical exhale.

 "Vanilla?" she says, eyebrows climbing. "Really, [name]? In a place that sells 'Cereal Killer Crunch' and 'Unicorn Tears Surprise,' you picked vanilla?"

 You shrug. "It's good."

 "Yeah, so is water," she mutters. "And that has no personality."

 "I think vanilla and water are underrated," Jessica says. "IT's kind of comforting. Like... dependable."

 "Do not justify this flavor cowardice, Jess," Samantha says.

 "I'm just saying that sometimes simple is nice," Jessica continues, ignoring her.

 "Simple is what you settle for when you give up on life," Samantha replies.

 "Well, this simple vanilla is going to taste amazing, so I win," you say.

 "Sure, champ," Samantha mutters. "Live your boring life."

 
 You don't hesitate. One scoop of rich chocolate, no frills. Reliable and an easy win.

 Samantha raises an eyebrow. "Chocolate, huh?" she says, giving a small nod. @.samantha;"Can't go wrong with chocolate."@@

 "Did you just... approve of my choice?" you ask.

 "No, of course not," she responds, clearly holding back a smirk. "Just very... childish."

 You look at her flatly. "It's chocolate. Everyone likes it."

 "I'm with [name]," Jessica says. "Chocolate's always a good choice. It's like... timeless."

 "And that's the problem," she says. "It's too safe. It's 'timeless' because there's nothing to it."

 "I'm the one with the ice cream, you're the one with opinions," you respond.

 "Hey, I never said it was a bad pick," Samantha says.

 
 You lean forward and point decisively. "Cookies and cream, please."

 The worker nods and scoops you a generous swirl, speckled with crumbled cookie bits. Just the right amount of crunch and cream.

 Samantha watches it and hums approvingly. "Ah, yes. The indecisive person's favorite. 'I want cookies, but also... milk? but cold. But frozen. But not too adult.'"

 Jessica laughs softly. "Honestly, I like cookies and cream. You can't go wrong with cookies in ice cream. It's like getting a bonus snack."

 "Thank you," you say. "Finally, some respect."

 "It's just too good," Samantha says, like she's making some great point. "Everyone likes it. That's what makes me suspicious."

 You raise an eyebrow. "Are you seriously gatekeeping ice cream right now?"

 "Yes," she says solemnly. "I'm morally obligated."

 
 You point to the strawberry. It's pale pink with little bits of fruit tucked inside.

 Sure enough, Samantha glances over and raises both brows. "Strawberry?"

 "What?" you say, taking a bite. "It's good."

 "Oh, I'm not judging," she says, sliding her hands into her pockets. "It's just kinda sweet. Unexpected."

 "Am I not sweet?" you ask.

 She laughs under her breath. "Let's not get into that."

 "I think [name]'s sweet," Jessica chimes in.

 "Then you don't know him well enough," Samantha murmurs.
 

Samantha stares down the row of ice cream tubs with her arms crossed. Her weight is shifted to one hip and her lips are pursed.

"No," she mutters at mint chip. "Too toothpaste. No," again at rainbow sherbet. "Not eating something that looks like it was sneezed out by a unicorn."

"Want some privacy?" you ask, deadpan.

She shoots you a glare, then points at a tub toward the end. "That one, please. Triple Fudge Frenzy. It speaks to me."

The worker gives her a nod and starts scooping.

Jessica steps up next, casual as anything. "Neapolitan," she says.

Samantha turns on her like she just confessed to a crime. "Neapolitan? Really? What are you, an ice cream sampler plate in human form? That's three flavors."

Jessica arches an eyebrow. "And Triple Fudge Frenzy isn't also three flavors? Lemme think. Fudge, fudge, and... oh, more fudge?"

Samantha opens her mouth like she has a retort, then shuts it down with a glare. "...I don't like your tone."

"That's what I thought."

The three of you move toward the checkout counter. When you make your way there, Samantha turns and stares wordlessly at the pile of shopping bags looped around your arm and cradled against your hip. Her gaze travels from the patterned handles to the glossy branded logos. Her eyes narrows. Her expression goes blank.

You don't even need to say it.

"I—" you start.

She cuts you off with a heavy sigh, like she's just aged five years. "[name]. My sweet, dumb shopping casualty. Do you have any money left?"

"I have emotional gratitude," you say, shrugging sheepishly.

"That won't pay for dairy, buddy."

Jessica leans over to peek at your haul. "Honestly? I'm impressed. You did quite a bit of damage in this mall."

"Yeah..." you say, voice trailing off.

Still grumbling, Samantha pulls her phone out and taps it against the reader before you can argue. A chime sounds, confirming the payment.

"Thanks," you murmur, already guilty.

She hands you your cone like she's bestowing you with a cursed heirloom. "You owe me."

"Fair," you reply, nodding solemnly.

"No, like—you seriously owe me," she continues, pointing a dramatic finger at your face. "Next time we pass a store that sells squishmallows, you're buying me the dumbest, biggest, ugliest one they have. I want it to ruin my bed aesthetic."

"You know what?" you say, laughing. "Deal."

With cones in hand, the three of you shuffle toward a nearby bench that's somehow both sticky and cold at the same time. You manage to arrange your bags into a neat little fortress on the floor before sitting. Jessica perches next to you, daintily eating her ice cream, while Samantha's already halfway through her triple-fudge monstrosity.

"So," Samantha says, licking a glob of chocolate off her thumb. "Now that [name]'s officially bankrupted himself and expanded his wardrobe... what do we even talk about?"

[Choice: If you could swap bodies with anyone for a day, who would it be?]
[Choice: If you could disappear for a week and go anywhere, where would you go?]

choices.text: If you could swap bodies with anyone for a day, who would it be?
If you could disappear for a week and go anywhere, where would you go?

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 23
passages.text:
You lean back against the bench, letting the ice cream melt lazily on your tongue, and glance between Samantha and Jessica.

 "So, if you could swap bodies with anyone for a day, who would it be?" you ask, breaking the comfortable silence.

 Samantha doesn't even hesitate. "Luke."

 You blink. "Luke? Like... our Luke? All-brawn-no-brain Luke?"

 "Exactly," Samantha states. "Surely there's gotta be something in that brain of his, and I want to know what it is. Like, does he think in full sentences? Or is it just vibes and offensive linemen? He's basically a human Labrador with a football scholarship. Can you blame me for being curious?"

 You snort. "You could just ask him what's going on in his head, you know."

 "Dude, I have asked," she says flatly. "His answer was, and I quote, 'Mostly just chicken nuggets and game strategy.'"

 Jessica giggles behind her cone, shaking her head. "Honestly? That tracks."

 Samantha leans back dramatically, holding her triple fudge cone like it's a microphone. "But imagine living in Luke's body for a day. No stress. No overthinking. You get to run fast, eat whatever you want, and everyone cheers when you throw a ball. It sounds like a vacation."

 "Until you have to play in an actual game," you point out.

 "Yeah, but in his body, I'd actually be good at it," she counters. "Do you know what I'd do with that kind of power? I'd get so smug. And tall. Oh my God, I'd be tall for a day."

 "That's your big dream?" you ask, raising an eyebrow.

 "Look, don't knock it 'til you've spent your whole life looking up at people in crowded hallways," she says.

 You laugh, shaking your head, then turn to Jessica. "What about you?"

 Jessica pauses.
 
 .

 "Jordan," she says finally.

 You and Samantha share a glance. "Jordan?" you ask.

 "As in, Jordan Jordan?" Samantha adds. "Icy Quarterback Jordan? The Jordan that doesn't talk to anyone?"

 Jessica nods, unbothered by her tone. "That's the one."

 "Why him?" you ask.

 Jessica shrugs, but there's a hint of thoughtfulness in the motion. "He's... different. Closed off, yeah, but there's more there. You can just tell. He doesn't open up to anyone. Even when he's surrounded by people, it feels like he's somewhere else."

 "So you want to swap bodies with him just to... solve the mystery?" Samantha asks.

 "Kind of." Jessica smiles faintly. "I've been trying to figure him out for months, and I haven't been able to. He's like this puzzle nobody else realizes is there. If I could just be him for a day, maybe I'd get it. Maybe I'd finally understand what's going on in his head."

 "Or maybe it's just chicken nuggets and game strategy in there too," Samantha says with a smirk.

 "I doubt it," Jessica says. "But at least I'd know."

 "That's actually kind of interesting," you admit. "You can't ever actually know what someone else is thinking."

 "Man, you guys are making me sound shallow," Samantha says. "You're out here talking about deep emotional connections and I'm over here like, 'Give me Luke's tall body and let me dunk on people.'"

 "Wrong sport," you state. "Also, you wouldn't be able to."

 She glares at you. "I'd figure it out."

 
 You lean back against the bench, letting the ice cream melt lazily on your tongue, and glance between Samantha and Jessica.

 "If you could disappear for a week and go anywhere, where would you go?" you ask, glancing between them. "No explanations, no responsibilities, no one asking where you were."

 Samantha leans back immediately, squinting at you over her cone. "Disappear? Like... no contact, no talking to anyone? For a whole week?"

 "That's the idea," you state.

 She shakes her head. "Hard pass. I'd last, like, a day. Maybe two if I had internet. I like people too much to be alone that long. If I disappear for a week, I want to disappear into a festival. Or a party. Or—oh!—a convention with free snacks. Not some wilderness trip."

 You can't help but laugh. "You'd disappear into... crowds?"

 "Exactly," she says. "It was the fun kind of disappearing, [name]. Not the existential one."

 "That's not really disappearing," Jessica says.

 "Sure it is," Samantha counters. "If I blend in with a thousand other people, poof—I'm gone. Unfindable. Like Where's Waldo, but sarcastic."

 You snort, shaking your head. "That's one way to look at it."

 Jessica, meanwhile, is quiet. When she finally speaks, her voice is softer. "I'd do it. Disappear for a week, I mean."
 
 You tilt your head. "Yeah?"

 She nods. "I think about it sometimes, actually. I'd rent some little cabin in the mountains or by a lake. Just somewhere green, where I can wake up and only hear wind and water. I'd turn my phone off. No texts, no notifications, no people. Just... me. Books, music, maybe a sketchpad. No expectations. No schedule. No... image to keep up."

 Her words hang there for a moment, heavy in their honesty.

 "So why don't you?" you ask, curious.

 She gives a small, almost sad laugh. "Because I can't, [name]. You know how it is. People would notice. My parents, school, the squad, everyone. And when I came back, I'd have to explain it, or deal with whatever they decided to assume. It wouldn't really be disappearing. It'd just be creating a new problem I'd have to fix later. So I don't."

 "You actually planned that all out, huh?" Samantha says, a frown on her face.

 Jessica shrugs. "I've thought about it a lot."

 "Sounds like you really need that week," you state.

 "Maybe I do," she admits.
 

[Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 24
passages.text:
The mall doors slide open with a hiss, and you step out into a different world than the one you arrived in. The sky's gone black, the streetlights are on, and the breeze that hits you is cooler now. The parking lot's half-empty, the buzz of cars replaced by the sounds of nature.

Samantha stops just outside the entrance, blinking like she's only just realized what time it is.

"Dude," she says. "It's night. Like, actual night. When the hell did that happen?"

You glance at the sky. "Uh... somewhere between the third and fourth store we visited?"

She pulls out her phone, checks the time, and groans. "Oh my God, [name]. We were in there for hours. No wonder my legs feel like I ran a marathon. How are we alive?"

"You're acting like you had to hike out of there. We were just shopping."

"'Just shopping'? I swear I walked the equivalent of a half-marathon today. And now I have to—" Samantha freezes mid-rant, realization dawning, and looks at Jessica. "Wait. Crap. I have to walk home in the dark."

Jessica blinks at her like she's grown a second head. Then she dangles the car keys in front of Samantha's face, the metal glinting under the light. "Forgot already?"

There's a beat of silence. Then Samantha gasps, grabbing Jessica by the shoulders with dramatic energy. "Oh my God. Hallelujah. I am saved." She bows her head, muttering, "Thank you, mysterious forces of the universe, for blessing me with a ride and sparing me from dying of exhaustion on the side of the road."

Jessica laughs, shaking her off. "You're welcome, but don't make it weird."

"It's too late for that," you say, adjusting the loop of shopping bags digging into your wrist.

Samantha glares half-heartedly at you, then trudges alongside as the three of you cross the lot. Jessica's car waits in the back row, tucked beneath one of the lampposts.

"Okay," Jessica says, popping the trunk open with a quick click. "Bag Tetris time. Don't crumple anything."

You load your spoils into the trunk, the bags rustling as they settle into a lumpy pile. Jessica carefully rearranges them after you toss your bags in so nothing will slide during the drive.

"Of course you're reorganizing," Samantha mutters.

Jessica shuts the trunk with a firm thud. "[name] will thank me when all his stuff isn't crushed."

You climb into the backseat while Samantha claims shotgun. Jessica slides into the driver's seat and starts the engine. "Seatbelts," she says automatically, glancing at both of you before backing out of the space.

"Wow," Samantha mutters, clicking hers into place. "Mom mode activated."

Jessica rolls her eyes, but there's a tiny smirk on her lips as she steers the car toward the exit. The mall grows smaller and smaller in the rearview mirror as the car accelerates.

You're finally out of the mall and on the road.

[Choice: Driving home]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 25
passages.text:
Jessica's car rolls to a quiet stop at the curb in front of your house. The engine hums for a moment before she cuts it, and the car settles into silence. The three of you just sit there for a moment, reluctant to move.

"Alright," Samantha finally says, stretching dramatically as she unbuckles. "Time to haul Mount Capitalism to the porch."

"Stop calling it that," you mutter.

"Tell that to your receipts," she fires back, sliding out of the passenger seat with a grunt.

Jessica steps out more gracefully, clicking the trunk open. "We'll just get everything to the porch. You can handle the rest, [name]," she says, circling to grab some bags herself.

"Thanks," you say, a little sheepishly as you take the heavier ones.

<<if [jessicaRomance] > 9>>
 "Of course," she replies.

 
 "No problem," she replies.
 

Together, the three of you make your way up to the front porch. Samantha keeps making sarcastic grunts about the "weight of retail excess" while Jessica just shakes her head with a quiet smile.

You've barely set the first pile down on the welcome mat when the front door creaks open.

"[name]? Is that you?"

Your mom steps out, sweater draped over her shoulders, her expression softening immediately when she sees the three of you standing there with arms full of bags. "Oh my goodness—" she pauses, taking in Jessica with a little spark of recognition, "you must be Jessica."

Jessica straightens up a bit. "Yes, ma'am," she says, voice polite but warm.

Your mom's smile widens. "I've heard a lot about you. Thank you for keeping my [name] company. You too, Samantha. Really, you're both such good friends for taking him shopping."

Samantha waves a hand dismissively. "Please, don't thank me. I do it out of obligation," she deadpans.

Jessica elbows her lightly. "Ignore her. It really was fun."

"Well, I appreciate you both either way," your mom says, amused.

She steps aside, pushing the door open further. "You should come in for a bit. You can rest your feet, maybe grab a snack. I can make some tea."

Jessica shakes her head. "Thank you, but it's getting late. I still need to drop Sam off before I head home."

"Yeah," Samantha agrees. "As much as I'd love tea, if I don't get horizontal on a mattress soon, I might actually die."

Your mom chuckles softly. "Well, I won't keep you then. Drive safe, alright? And thank you again. It means a lot that you're both looking out for him."

Jessica offers her a small, genuine smile. "Of course. Thank you for having us."

"We'll take good care of him, don't worry," Samantha says, giving a little salute.

"See that you do," your mom says.

With that, Jessica and Samantha turn to head back to the car. Samantha stretches her arms overhead with a groan as they walk, and Jessica tosses you a small wave before sliding into the driver's seat.

You watch the car pull away, the taillights glowing red before disappearing down the street.

Your mom exhales softly beside you, glancing at the pile of bags stacked on the porch. "Well," she says, clapping her hands once with a faint smile, "let's get all that inside now."

You step through the door, the bags rustling around you as the porch light clicks off behind you and the night returns to its quiet hum.

[Choice: Back home]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 3
passages.text:
You're halfway through tying your shoes when the doorbell rings.

You grab your phone and jog down the stairs, opening the door to find Samantha standing there, sleeves shoved up, a little windblown from her walk, and a half-empty water bottle dangling from one hand. Her hair's crammed under a beanie like usual, and she's got that wide grin that usually means trouble.

"Behold!" she announces, arms thrown wide like a magician. "Your fairy godmother has arrived. I bring fashion advice, emotional damage, and possibly foot blisters."

You grin. "You walked?"

"Of course I walked. What am I, a coward?" she says, pushing past you into the entryway. "I am committed to the cause and to cardio. Also, I don't have a car."

You laugh, shutting the door. She glances around like she's inspecting the place for changes, then squints at you.

"Wait," she says, suspicious. "We're walking to the mall too, right?"

"Yeah, of course. That's how we always go."

She groans so dramatically you're surprised she doesn't fall over. "Bro. I just walked here. That's already twenty minutes. I was not emotionally prepared for part two of this pilgrimage."

"You'll live," you say.

She takes a long swig from her water bottle, then caps it with a snap. "Fine. But if I die halfway, you have to drag me the rest of the way and tell my cat I loved her."

"You're very dramatic for someone who claims to be strong."

"Pain builds character," she says breezily. "Now, come on. Let's go buy you an identity."

You're about to reply when the low purr of an engine makes you glance outside.

A sleek, pearly-white car pulls up to the curb in front of your house, the kind that looks like it gets hand-waxed every Sunday.

Samantha follows your gaze, frowning. "Uh... who the hell is that?"

The car door opens, and out steps Jessica.

She's dressed effortlessly nice—pink jacket layered over a white top, hair perfectly straightened and tied back with a bow. You blink, because for a split second it's like she doesn't belong on your front step—Jessica Sanders, the queen bee of Pacific Crest High, standing in front of your door like this is completely normal.

She spots you through the window and waves with a bright smile, like she hasn't just caused your brain to hit a full stop.

It's only then that you realize the front door is still closed. You fumble for the handle, pushing it open just as Samantha pokes her head through the gap.

"Dude, what's taking so—"

Her words die on her lips when she sees who's standing there.

She freezes. Blinks. Then says, very flatly, "Why the hell is Jessica at your house?"

Jessica blinks too, but she recovers quickly, offering Samantha a friendly wave. "Hi," she says, like this is all completely normal.

Samantha, meanwhile, swivels toward you with a slow, deliberate look. "[name]," she says, voice low and suspicious. "Why. Is. Jessica. Here?"

You try your hardest not to laugh at how intense she suddenly looks. "Surprise?"

"Surprise?!" Samantha's voice jumps a whole octave. "No. No, you don't just do this. What is this? What is happening? Did I hit my head on the way over here? Am I concussed?"

Jessica laughs, stepping forward like she's defusing a bomb. "[name] invited me," she says lightly. "I thought it'd be fun to help out. Hope that's okay."

Samantha turns back to her, incredulous. "You what?" Then back at you: "You invited her? And you didn't tell me?"

"Yeah," you say, giving her a sheepish shrug. "I thought it might... you know. Be good to have someone else's input."

"Input," she repeats, narrowing her eyes. "Oh, sure. Nothing like ambushing me with the most popular girl at school to make this trip super chill."

Jessica just laughs again, seemingly unfazed. "Well, hopefully, I can make it worth your while."

Samantha stares at her for a beat, then mutters, "This is so weird," under her breath.

"Come on," you say. "The mall's not going to shop itself."

Jessica gives you another bright smile, stepping back toward her car. Samantha lingers for a moment, then finally sighs and trudges after you. "Unbelievable," she mutters. "You're lucky I like you."

You can't help but grin. Whatever today turns into, it's definitely going to be interesting.

[Choice: Onward!]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 4
passages.text:
Jessica leads the way toward the car, her ponytail bouncing lightly with each step, and you and Samantha follow. The car is even more impressive up close than it looked from the doorway—sleek and pearly-white, with tinted windows that catch the afternoon sun. The chrome trim gleams, and the paint is so clean it reflects the trees lining your street.

Samantha stops dead in her tracks. "Uh. Excuse me," she says, pointing like the car personally offended her. "What the actual hell is this?"

Jessica pauses, glancing back. "My car?"

"No," Samantha says, stepping closer, squinting at the vehicle as if she expects to find secret compartments. "No. This is not a car. This is... some kind of spaceship. You're telling me you drive this every day like it's no big deal?"

Jessica laughs lightly, unlocking the car with a soft beep. "It's just a newer model. My parents wanted me to have something safe. And yeah, it's nice. I know I'm lucky." She doesn't sound braggy when she says it, just like she's just acknowledging how it is.

Samantha stares at her for another moment, then huffs. "Cool. Meanwhile, I don't even have a car. I'm still living the two-leg express life."

"I mean, I used to be there too," Jessica replies easily, opening the driver's side door. "Until last year, I was catching rides with the upperclassmen. It's definitely a privilege, and I don't take it for granted. But hey, at least walking keeps you in shape, right?"

Samantha narrows her eyes and, for once, she can't quite come up with a comeback. "Whatever," she mutters before yanking open the back door.

You climb into the passenger seat, sinking into smooth leather that feels way too nice for a high schooler's car. The cabin smells faintly of leather and vanilla, and sunlight streams in through the sunroof. Jessica slides into the driver's seat and presses the start button. The dashboard lights up, and a large touchscreen on the center wakes up, immediately syncing to her phone.

Samantha leans forward between the two front seats, scanning everything like she's in a museum. "Holy shit," she says. "This thing has Bluetooth? Like, real, working Bluetooth? And a giant screen? This is ridiculous."

Jessica glances at her in the rearview mirror with an easy smile. "Yeah, it makes it real easy to call and play music. Honestly, I don't know what to do without it now."

"Wow," Samantha scoffs. "I'm over here riding in my mom's car that screeches in pain if you push it past fifty. You're out here with a rolling computer. I don't even know how to process this."

Jessica chuckles, adjusting the mirrors. "Trust me, I get that this looks like a lot. It's my first real car—before this I was just borrowing this old one to practice on. They wanted me in something safer, and... well, I'm really lucky my parents could do that for me."

Samantha studies her for a second, then flops back into her seat. "Alright. At least you're self-aware. That's points in your favor."

Jessica smiles, starting up the car. "I'll take the points."

You buckle your seatbelt, trying not to grin at the exchange. Samantha crosses her arms and mutters, "I walked here, and now I'm getting chauffeured in the presidential motorcade of Pacific Crest."

"Presidential motorcade?" Jessica repeats, giggling. "That's a new one."

Samantha shrugs. "I call it like I see it."

Jessica just shakes her head, still smiling as she eases the car onto the road. "Well, I'll try to live up to the title."

You settle back into your seat as the car glides smoothly down the street.

[Choice: The drive]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 5
passages.text:
The car hums smoothly as Jessica pulls onto the main road. The seats are so comfortable you almost feel like you're sinking into them, and the big touchscreen on the dashboard glows softly.

Jessica glances between you and Samantha in the rearview mirror. "Do you guys mind if I put on some music?"

"Depends," Samantha says from the back, arms crossed. "Are we talking actual music, or whatever Top 100 nightmare cheer captains usually listen to?"

Jessica doesn't flinch. She laughs lightly, though it's that practiced, breezy laugh you've heard her use in the hallways. "Guess you'll have to find out."

She taps the screen, and some upbeat pop starts paying. It's not bad, but not good either. Just safe. Jessica bobs her head along like it's her go-to road trip soundtrack.

Samantha leans forward, eyebrows raised. "Called it. Radio-friendly jams. You really are on-brand, Sanders."

"Hey, it's catchy," Jessica says with a little shrug. "Besides, it's hard to make everyone happy with music. This is a nice middle ground."

Samantha leans back again, clearly unimpressed but not pushing it further. You can tell she's still in that evaluating phase—deciding if Jessica is actually someone she can tolerate or if she's just going to mentally file her away as "perfect princess of Pacific Crest."

You decide to step in before the silence turns awkward. "So, Jessica, I didn't even know you drove yourself to school. I've never seen this car in the lot."

Jessica glances at you, smiling. "I try to get in and out without drawing too much attention."

Samantha snorts. "Oh sure. Because the cheer captain in the shiny new car is so inconspicuous."

Jessica doesn't take the bait. "Fair," she says, smiling a little tighter. "But I do my best."

There's a pause, just long enough for you to feel the tension creeping back in. Jessica keeps her eyes on the road and Samantha's staring out the window like she's already over it.

You clear your throat. "You know, it's funny. I think this is the first time you two have actually talked."

"Yup," Samantha says without looking away from the window.

Jessica laughs again, but it's the practiced one. "Guess we run in pretty different circles."

Samantha finally turns to look at her. "You could say that."

Another pause. And then Jessica—maybe intentionally—adds, "I mean, it's kind of nice though, isn't it? Getting out of your bubble and meeting people you don't usually get to talk to."

Samantha tilts her head like she's gauging if Jessica actually means it or if it's just one of those lines people like her say to sound nice. "Do you actually believe that? Or are you doing your, like, Miss Popular thing right now?"

Jessica's smile falters for the first time. She glances at Samantha in the rearview mirror, then back at the road. "I mean it," she says simply. "It's easy to get stuck being what people expect you to be. I like when I don't have to do that for a while."

That seems to catch Samantha off guard. "Huh."

You don't say anything, but you notice Samantha's posture ease just slightly. Her arms loosen and her voice isn't as sharp when she speaks again.

"So, wait," Samantha says after a beat. "You're telling me you don't enjoy the whole queen bee thing?"

"Sometimes? Sure." Jessica chuckles, but this time it's more real. "But it's a lot. People assume you've got it all figured out. And if you don't live up to that, it feels like you're failing at being... well, you."

Samantha studies her like she's trying to decide whether to believe her. Then she finally leans back. "That's... actually fair."

"Glad you think so," Jessica says, smiling softly.

It's quiet for a moment after that, but it's much lighter. It's as if everyone's settling in.

You glance between them, relieved. This is going better than you expected.
