[Choice: Ask Jessica what her favorite thing to do is when she's not busy]
[Choice: Ask Samantha what music she actually likes]

choices.text: Ask Jessica what her favorite thing to do is when she's not busy
Ask Samantha what music she actually likes

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 6
passages.text:
You glance at Jessica as the car hums along, watching the way she keeps her perfect posture even while driving, her hands lightly gripping the wheel at exactly nine and three. She looks composed as always—exactly the image people expect of her. But then you remember what she said a minute ago about being stuck in that image, and before you can overthink it, you speak up.

 "So, Jessica," you say, leaning back in your seat, "what's your favorite thing to do when you're not... you know, being cheer captain or busy with school? Like, actual free time stuff."

 She doesn't answer right away. You can see her expression flicker—something between hesitation and calculation. She opens her mouth like she's going to give the safe answer, the response people would expect from Jessica.

 But then she closes it again.

 "I, uh..." She exhales through her nose, shaking her head at herself, and then glances at you with a wry smile. "You guys are gonna laugh."

 "Oh, now you have to say it," Samantha pipes up from the back, leaning forward with sudden interest. "If you preface it like that, it's definitely something juicy."

 Jessica groans, but it's more theatrical than serious. "Okay. Fine. But don't tell anyone at school, seriously."

 "I can't promise anything," Samantha says immediately.

 Jessica gives her a look through the rearview mirror. "Samantha."

 "Fine, fine. Scout's honor. I won't destroy your image."

 "I..." Jessica begins. She exhales like she's bracing for impact. "I paint Waranvil minis."

 You blink. "You what now?"

 Jessica laughs—really laughs, a soft, slightly embarrassed sound. "Yeah. You know, those tiny tabletop game figurines? I don't actually play the game, but I love painting them. It's calming. Kind of my escape when everything else going on is so chaotic. And I've actually gotten pretty good at it."

 "You spend your free time hunched over a table painting tiny plastic dudes with guns?" Samantha asks, her mouth hanging open.

 "Yup," Jessica says, clearly cringing at herself. "I even have one of those lamps and a cutting mat."

 There's a beat of silence, and then Samantha bursts out laughing—not in a mean way, but genuinely amused. "Okay, that's actually kind of amazing. Like, I was expecting you to say 'yoga' or 'tennis with my friends at the country club.' Not, 'I paint tiny space knights in my room.' Respect."

 Jessica glances at her in the mirror, surprised. "Respect?"

 "Yeah, that's way more interesting than what I thought you'd say," Samantha says, grinning. "You've officially gained, like, one cool point. Don't let it get to your head."

 Jessica shakes her head, but there's a softness to her smile now. "Hopefully I can earn some more."

 You can feel the tension in the car loosening, little by little. Jessica seems more relaxed too, shoulders settled and voice lighter. She doesn't have to keep performing.

 "So, do you... collect them or just paint?" you ask.

 "Mostly paint," she admits. "I've got a little box with a whole diorama I made inside of it. Finishing one is stupidly satisfying. Plus, nobody expects me to do it, so it feels like it's just... mine, you know? No judgment."

 "That's... actually really cool," you say honestly.

 Jessica gives you a grateful smile, and for a moment, she looks less like your high school's perfect golden girl and more like an actual person—one who just happens to spend her free time geeking out over miniatures.

 "Alright, Waranvil Jessica," Samantha says, leaning back with a grin. "You're slowly convincing me you're not as insufferable as I thought."

 Jessica laughs again, shaking her head. "You know what? I'll take it. That's high praise coming from you."

 The car settles into an easy quiet after that—the kind where it feels like everyone's a little more comfortable than they were five minutes ago.

 
 You glance at Samantha in the rearview mirror. She's slouched against the window, arms crossed like she's still deciding whether this trip is a good idea or if she's going to regret letting you drag her into it. Jessica hums softly along with the safe, upbeat pop playing through the speakers, her posture perfect, hands at nine and three like she's in a car commercial. The mood's... fine, but not quite relaxed.

 Fuck it.

 "So, Sam," you say, twisting slightly in your seat to look back at her, "what do you even listen to? You've been quietly judging Jessica's playlist since we left my house. What would you put on right now?"

 She blinks at you before smirking. "Oh, you mean real music? Paramore. Linkin Park. Evanescence. You know—stuff with actual feelings. Not this bubblegum background noise."

 Jessica glances at her in the rearview mirror, still smiling. "You like Linkin Park?"

 "Obviously," Samantha says, sitting up a little straighter. "Hybrid Theory is basically therapy. You can't tell me you've never screamed along to 'Crawling' before."

 "Believe it or not, I actually have," Jessica replies, chuckling. "I used to blast that in my room when I was, like, thirteen. Felt very rebellious at the time."

 Samantha blinks, surprised. "Huh. Didn't expect that from Miss Cheer Captain."

 Jessica just shrugs, that perfect smile softening into something more playful. "There's a lot you wouldn't expect." She takes a quick glance at her phone. "Hey, Suri. Play Linkin Park."

 The speakers respond with a chime, then the quiet, melodic intro of "What I've Done" fills the car.

 "Ohh," Samantha exclaims, grinning. "Okay. You might actually live through this road trip."

 Jessica laughs as the beat kicks in. "This one's a classic."

 Within seconds, Samantha's mouthing the words, then singing under her breath. By the time the chorus hits, she's basically performing.

 Jessica surprises you by chiming in too—not as loud, but knowing every word. She doesn't hold back on the drumming either, hitting the steering wheel in rhythm like she's done this a thousand times already.

 "You know all the words to this?" you ask, blinking at her.

 "What, you think I only listen to cheer music?" Jessica asks, smirking. "Please. I had an emo phase like everyone else."

 Samantha barks a laugh. "This I respect. Didn't think you had it in you."

 "There's a lot more to me than most people think."

 "Alright, I'll give you that," Samantha says. "Bonus points for actually knowing the lyrics."

 <<if [jessicaRomance] > 9>> 
 "Come on, [name]," Jessica says, taking a hand off the steering wheel and putting a hand on your thigh. "Don't leave us hanging. You have to sing too."
 
 
 "Come on, [name]," Jessica says, taking a hand off the steering wheel and putting a hand on your shoulder. "Don't leave us hanging. You have to sing too."
 

 "Oh, I don't—" you start, but Samantha interrupts.

 "Wrong answer. You are not too cool for LP."

 "I never said I was too cool—"

 "Sing," she demands.

 And somehow, between the two of them staring you down, you do. Quietly at first, but by the second chorus, the three of you are yelling the lyrics together. Jessica's laughing between lines, Samantha's headbanging dramatically in the back seat, and for a few minutes, everything feels... easy.

 When the song ends, Samantha's still grinning, flushed from the impromptu jam session. "Okay," she says, pointing at Jessica. "You just gained, like, three cool points. Don't let it go to your head."

 "I'll try not to," Jessica says, smiling genuinely.

 The tension in the car has shifted. It's not completely gone—Samantha's still Samantha and Jessica's still Jessica—but there's a new ease between them, like the gap just got a little smaller.

 And you? You can't help but think this is going way better than you expected.
 

[Choice: Nearly there]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 7
passages.text:
Jessica takes the next turn smoothly, the car gliding like it's too good for the potholes on the street. She's leaning back in her seat, one hand on the wheel and one hand resting. Samantha's sprawled in the back, her knees propped up against the door, idly drumming her fingers on her water bottle.

 
 The ride has been quiet for the past minute—just the hum of the AC and the soft music coming from the car speakers—until Samantha pipes up with that tone you know means trouble.

 
 The ride has been quiet for the past minute—just the hum of the AC and Linkin Park playing quietly on the car speakers—until Samantha pipes up with that tone you know means trouble.
 

"Sooo," she says, drawing the word out like she's building suspense, "we're all in agreement about why we're doing this, right? This isn't just a casual trip to look around. This is a full-on intervention."

You frown, twisting a little in your seat. "Intervention for what, exactly?"

Samantha doesn't miss a beat. "For your fashion choices. Or more accurately, the total lack of them."

"Oh my God," you groan. "Not again."

"No, no, don't 'oh my God' me," she says, leaning forward so she can rest her chin between the front seats, staring at you like a disappointed parent. "You've been wearing the exact same thing for years, dude. Cargo shorts. White T-shirt. Those beat-up black Converse. It's your uniform. You're like... a video game character who doesn't change outfits."

"They're comfortable," you mutter, automatically defensive.

Jessica snickers from the driver's seat, glancing at you. "Oh, I can confirm this. I think I've seen you in literally that exact outfit at least ten times since school started."

"You keep track?" you ask.

"It's hard not to," she says with a grin, leaning her elbow on the door like she's settling in for this. "Believe it or not, I actually thought it was endearing at first. Like, you know, you're committed to a look. But then I realized it wasn't a 'look.' It's just you wearing the first few things in your closet forever."

Samantha cackles from the back seat. "Thank you. Finally, someone else gets it."

You throw your hands up. "Okay, hold on. First of all, I do wear other things."

"Do you?" Samantha says, eyebrows raised.

"Yes!"

"Like what?" she fires back immediately.

You open your mouth, then close it. You can feel both of them staring at you, waiting.

"That's what I thought," Samantha says with smug satisfaction.

You roll your eyes, but there's a small grin tugging at your lips. "Glad my wardrobe is providing endless entertainment for you two."

Jessica glances at you from the driver's seat, her teasing expression softening into something warmer. "Hey, you know we're just messing with you, right?"

"Yeah," Samantha adds, leaning forward between the seats. "If we actually thought you were a hopeless case, we wouldn't bother trying. This is how we show love."

"So I'm basically your chew toy?" you ask, chuckling.

"No, of course not," Jessica says. "You're our friend. And we like you enough to want to help you out."

"If we didn't care, we'd just let you keep rocking the same clothes forever and never say a word," Samantha jokes.

"You deserve to feel good in what you wear, [name]," Jessica states, her tone genuine. "And if you've been stuck in the same thing for years, maybe it's time to try something new. We'll help you figure out what that is. That's why you invited us, right?"

Samantha leans back into her seat again, satisfied. "By the end of today, you'll actually have options in your closet. It'll be historic."

You shake your head, smiling despite yourself. "Alright, alright. I'm trusting you two."

Jessica grins. "Good. We've got your back."

Her words feel true.

[Choice: Park at the mall!]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 8
passages.text:
The rest of the drive is easy. The conversation drifts into safer territory: little side comments about the neighborhoods you pass, Samantha's running commentary on terrible billboard designs, and Jessica humming along to the music.

Jessica turns into the mall's parking lot, easing the car into an open spot near the entrance. The glass facade reflects the late-afternoon sun, and streams of shoppers flow in and out of the big doors. She slips the car into park and exhales. "Well," she says, unbuckling her seatbelt with a click. "Here we are. Ground zero."

"Ground zero," Samantha repeats from the back, stretching her arms over her head. "Wow. You really know how to hype up retail therapy."

Jessica glances back with a grin. "I know a thing or two about it."

Samantha's lips twitch like she's about to fire off another joke, but then she hesitates. Her gaze lingers on Jessica for a moment before she leans forward between the front seats. "Hey," she says, her tone a little softer than usual, "before we get out, I just wanted to say something."

Jessica raises an eyebrow. "Oh?"

"Yeah." Samantha tugs at the hem of her beanie, clearly a little awkward. "I know I was kind of... prickly earlier. Maybe more than I needed to be."

Jessica tilts her head. "Prickly?"

"Fine, I was rude," Samantha admits with a dramatic sigh, like the confession physically pains her. "I just... I didn't really know you. And when people are all bubbly and perfect, I guess I get defensive. It felt like you weren't being totally real with me."

Jessica studies her for just a moment before breaking out into a small smile. "That's fair," she says simply. "We didn't really know each other. And... honestly? You're not wrong. I wasn't being totally real. It's kind of a habit, putting on the version of me that people expect."

"Huh," Samantha says, not expecting the honesty. "You're... not what I expected."

"I'll take that as a compliment," Jessica says.

"Don't push it," Samantha says, though there's no bite to her words now.

Jessica giggles, opening her door. "Fine, I won't."

You glance between them, a little surprised at how naturally the tension dissolved. A couple of minutes ago, you weren't sure if they'd even survive the car ride together. Now? They're starting to understand each other.

Jessica grabs her purse and steps out of the car, stretching her arms. "Come on," she says brightly. "Let's make today productive."

Jessica steps out ahead as the three of you make your way across the lot. You and Samantha trail a little behind, falling into a slower pace without even thinking about it. Samantha shoves her hands into the pockets of her jeans, glancing at Jessica's back for a moment before leaning closer to you.

"I can see why you're friends with her now," she whispers, her tone quiet enough that Jessica won't hear.

<<if [jessicaRomance] > 9>> 
 You glance at Jessica, watching the way her ponytail sways as she walks, then quickly look away before Samantha can catch you staring. "Yeah," you say, a little more thoughtful than you meant to. "She's easy to get along with. Not really what I expected at first either."

 Samantha hums in agreement. "Yup. I can tell."

 You keep your eyes fixed on the ground as you walk, a strange flutter sitting in your chest.

 You don't bother trying to name it.

 
 You shrug, kicking at a stray pebble as you walk. "Yeah. She's just nice. Like, genuinely nice. Not what I expected when I first met her."

 Samantha nods, considering that. "Yeah. Guess I judged too quick."

 "Maybe a little," you tease.

 She smirks, elbowing you lightly. "Don't get used to me admitting I was wrong, [name]."
 

Up ahead, Jessica glances over her shoulder with a bright smile. "You two coming, or are you planning on loitering out here all day?"

"Coming!" Samantha calls back, tugging you along by the sleeve. And just like that, the three of you step through the doors together, into the cool, bustling air of the mall.

[Choice: Mall time!]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica 9
passages.text:
The mall swallows you up in a rush of cool, manufactured air and the faint scent of cinnamon pretzels, fabric softener, and whatever cologne they're spraying at the men's department two stores down. It's a sudden shift from the sticky heat of outside to the sterile environment of retail therapy central. Floors polished so clean you can see the overhead lights reflecting, shoppers weaving in and out of storefronts, and ambient music pulsing softly from the ceiling.

Jessica slows her pace just inside the entrance, pulling out her phone. "Okay," she says, voice bright. "What we need is a plan."

Samantha groans dramatically. "A plan? What is this, a military op? We're just buying [name] some clothes."

"Exactly," Jessica says, smirking. "At the end of the day, it is a mission. And like any good mission, we need a strategy. If we just wander around, we'll end up with him buying another boring outfit."

"I can feel the judgment radiating off that sentence," you mutter.

"We'll start with basics," Jessica says, scrolling through something on her phone. "Stuff you can mix and match. Then maybe some layering pieces."

Samantha tilts her head. "Layering? Like scarves and jackets?"

"Exactly," Jessica says, nodding. "Things that make an outfit look intentional instead of... thrown on. We'll also have to pay attention to fit. That's half the battle. Too loose, and it looks sloppy. Too tight, and it looks uncomfortable. You need things that actually suit your frame."

"Fit," Samantha echoes, giving a solemn nod. "That's important, yeah."

Jessica keeps going like she's running a seminar. "Comfort matters too. If it doesn't feel right, you won't wear it. Which means we might need to look at thing like underlayers. Tanks, undershirts..."

"Or a bra," Samantha interjects casually, like she's listing socks or belts.

Jessica nods in agreement, not missing a beat. "Yeah, depending on how certain tops fit, that could make a huge difference."

You freeze mid-step.

Samantha notices and glances at you, one eyebrow raised. "Wait," she says, like the thought just hit her. "Do you even have a bra?"

Her tone is just curious, like she's clearly expecting you to say yes.

And suddenly, both of them are looking at you, waiting for your answer.

 
 
 You hesitate, feeling the weight of their stares. The question lingers longer than it should, and finally, you exhale. "Uh... no. I don't... I don't have one. I've been using a binder."

 That stops them both dead. Jessica's lips part in surprise, and Samantha stands up straighter like she didn't quite hear you right.

 "A... binder?" Samantha repeats, blinking. "Like... a real one? That squishes your boobs to make you flat?"

 "Yeah," you say, rubbing the back of your neck. "Coach Blake got it for me about ten days ago."

 Jessica's eyebrows shoot up, her eyes softening. "Coach Blake? Wait, the Coach Blake? The one who yells at us for not running hard enough in P.E.?"

 You can't help but huff a little laugh despite the tension creeping up your chest. "Yeah. That Coach Blake. She kind of... noticed I was having a hard time during a run. Pulled me aside and asked if I had a proper binder. I told her no. A few minutes later, she had one for me."

 "That's... actually really kind of her," Jessica says, her expression sympathetic.

 "It was," you admit quietly.

 Samantha, on the other hand, doesn't look softened at all. Her jaw tightens, and she stares at you like you just admitted you jumped out of a moving car for fun. "And you've been wearing it all the time every single day?"

 You nod cautiously. "Pretty much."

 Her face twists into disbelief, and her voice comes out sharper than you've heard all day. "[name]. How could you have done that?!"

 "I—"

 "No, seriously." She gestures at you wildly, the way she does when she's worked up. "Did you even look up how long you're supposed to wear it? How dangerous that is?"

 "Samantha," Jessica interrupts gently, her tone like a steadying hand.

 Samantha groans, running her hands down her face. "Dude, I can't believe you. You can't just put something like that on and wear it like it's a T-shirt. It's not safe. What if you hurt yourself?"

 You blink, thrown off by the raw edge of her words. She's mad—but you can tell she's not mad at you. She's just worried.

 "I didn't think it was a big deal," you say, quieter than you meant to.

 Jessica shakes her head immediately. "Look, [name]," she says softly, her voice full of kindness. "Of course it's a big deal. You've been hurting yourself just to get by. That's not okay. You shouldn't have to do that."

 You glance away, focusing on the shiny tile floor ahead. "It's just... helpful. Makes me feel better. I figured some pain was just normal."

 Jessica steps closer and lays a hand lightly on your shoulder. "It's not supposed to hurt like that. If it does, it probably means it's too tight or that you've been wearing it too long. I don't want you thinking you just have to live with pain like that. You don't."
 
 Samantha lets out a frustrated noise and crosses her arms, glaring at nothing in particular. "I can't believe you didn't say anything. You should've told me. You know I would've—" She cuts herself off, shaking her head like she's too wound up to finish.

 "Sam," Jessica chides gently, but there's no real heat in it.

 "Look, he's my best friend," Samantha says, her voice cracking. "You don't get to just... silently hurt yourself and not tell me."

 Jessica keeps her hand on your shoulder, her thumb brushing in a small but reassuring motion. "She's just worried. We both are."

 "I didn't want to make it a big thing," you murmur.

 Jessica's smile doesn't waver. "You don't have to make it a big thing. You just have to take care of yourself. That's all we want."

 "Exactly," Samantha cuts in. Her voice is still sharp, albeit less than before. "And step one of that is getting you an actual bra. One that's comfortable and doesn't hurt you. No arguments."

 "Yeah," Jessica agrees softly, squeezing your shoulder before letting her hand finally fall. "You deserve to feel good and safe in your clothes. We're not leaving until we make that happen."

 You stare at the two of them—Samantha shaking like she's ready to fight the binder and Jessica smiling reassuringly—and for the first time, it really sinks in that they're here for you.
 
 
 You freeze for a moment, feeling both their eyes on you. There's no way to make this sound good, but lying would feel worse. So you take a breath and admit it.

 "...No. I don't," you say quietly. "I've just been... using a towel to flatten my chest."

 Jessica blinks like she didn't hear you right. "A... towel?"

 Samantha leans forward between the seats, frowning. "What do you mean, a towel? Like, actually—"

 You cut in quickly. "Yeah. I just fold it and... wrap it tight. It works well enough."

 There's a pause—an awful, stretched silence where both of them are clearly processing that.

 Samantha is the first to speak, and her voice isn't as sharp as you expected. "[name]," she says slowly, like she's trying to figure out how not to shout. "You've been doing that this whole time?"

 You shrug weakly, staring down at the tiles under your feet. "Yeah."

 Jessica recovers next, and her usual energy is nowhere to be found. "That can't be comfortable," she says softly. "Doesn't it hurt?"

 "Yeah," you say, letting out a small laugh that dies almost instantly. "I mean, it digs in and it's hard to breathe sometimes if I make it too tight. But it makes me feel better. People don't stare at me."

 "[name], that's dangerous," Jessica says firmly, taking a step closer. "Towels aren't meant to do that. That can really hurt you."

 "I know," you mumble.

 Samantha groans and presses her hands to her face, dragging them down with a frustrated sigh. "God, [name]. Why didn't you tell me? why didn't you tell anyone? You can't just do stuff like this to yourself and keep it secret."

 Her words sting, but not in a cruel way. You can hear the worry in her voice.

 "I didn't want it to be a big deal," you say. "And it works. Mostly."

 Jessica meets your eyes. "You don't have to live with pain just because it makes other things easier. You deserve to be comfortable and safe."

 You glance away, unsure what to do with the warmth in her words.

 Samantha exhales, crossing her arms. "Look. I'm not mad, I'm just freaked out that you'd hurt yourself like this and not even say anything. You're my best friend. I'm supposed to look out for you, and I can't do that if you keep this stuff to yourself."

 You manage a small nod, and that seems to ease her a little.

 "Okay," Jessica states, her tone shifting from gentle to decisive. "First things first, we're getting you a bra. A proper one. Something soft and supportive that doesn't hurt you. No arguments."

 Samantha nods firmly. "Yup. That's priority number one. The towel stops today."

 "We'll help you figure this out," Jessica says with a reassuring smile. "You don't have to do it alone."

 You swallow hard, looking between the two of them. They're serious—more serious than you've ever seen them about anything. They really do care. And somehow, even with the knot in your chest, that makes you feel a little better.
 

 
 
 You shift your weight, feeling both of their eyes on you. "No," you admit after a moment, "I don't have one."

 "Really?" Jessica asks, tilting her head.

 "Really," you say, shrugging. "I just... didn't think I needed one."

 Samantha peers at you like she's trying to figure out if you're serious. "You've been going to school like this for weeks, looking like you do now, and you never thought to get one?"

 
 You shrug again, awkward but honest. "My chest is still... well, flat. Like, actually flat. There's nothing there to even need one for."
 
 
 You shrug again, awkward but honest. "My chest is still... well, flat. Like, basically flat. There's nothing there to even need one for."
 

 Jessica blinks, her expression softening as she processes that. "Oh. Okay. That makes sense."

 "Alright, fair," Samantha says. "But still."

 "Still what?" you ask, glancing at her.

 <<if [feminineLooks] > 59>> 
 She gestures vaguely toward you. "You don't exactly look like 'old [name]' anymore. You've got more of a tomboy vibe now—like, you look like a girl who just happens to dress casual. A bra might help make your outfits sit better, even if you don't need it for support."
 <<elseif [feminineLooks] > 39>> 
 She gestures vaguely toward you. "You don't exactly look like 'old [name]' anymore. You've got this really androgynous thing going on now—like, depending on the outfit, people might read you either way. A bra might help pull the look together a bit. Even if you don't need it for support, it could make your clothes fit cleaner."
 

 "She's right," Jessica says, nodding in agreement. "It's not about need—it's about comfort and how your clothes sit on you. Some tops will look a lot smoother with a bra under them, even if it's just something light and soft."

 You glance down at your top, suddenly a little more aware of how it hangs on you. "I guess I didn't think about it that way."

 "That's what we're here for," Jessica says, smiling warmly. "It doesn't have to be anything complicated. Just something simple that feels good and works with what you're wearing."

 Samantha grins. "Operation Closet Rescue expands. First stop: Bras."

 You groan lightly at the way she says it, but for the first time, the idea doesn't feel so strange. Maybe, with them, it might not be so bad.
 
 
 
 
 If Jessica is the one who gave you the bra, she won't acknowledge it. This is because I forgot to put a variable there, so there's no way to check. Sorry!
 

 "Uh... actually," you say, scratching the back of your neck, "I do have one. Kind of. A sports bra."

 Samantha pauses. "Oh?" she asks. "Where'd you get it from?"

 "Someone gave it to me," you say, keeping it vague. "It wasn't really... fitted for me or anything like that. They just thought it might help, I guess."

 "So it's just random?"

 "Yeah," you admit. "The band is a little too tight and the strap's too loose. But it works well enough."

 Jessica's brow furrows as she listens. "[name], that doesn't sound like it actually works at all."

 You glance down, suddenly feeling very aware of yourself in the crowded space. "It's... better than nothing."

 Samantha makes a face, the kind she reserves for when she's trying to be supportive but can't quite mask her bluntness. "Better than nothing isn't good enough if it's uncomfortable. You've been wearing that this whole time?"

 "Mostly," you say. "It doesn't really bother me much."

 "You shouldn't have to settle for that," Jessica states, shaking her head. "A proper fit makes a huge difference."

 Samantha nods. "Exactly, and you can't just take whatever hand-me-down someone tosses you and call it good. It's like wearing shoes that are a size too small and convincing yourself it's fine because they stay on your feet."

 You shrug again, unsure what to say. "I didn't think it was that big a deal."

 "It is," Jessica says simply, like there's no debate to be had.

 "Yeah," Samantha agrees. "We're not letting you walk around in some mystery sports bra forever. Today, we're fixing that."

 "Luckily for you, I know exactly where to go," Jessica says, already glancing toward the mall directory. "We'll find something simple, comfy, and actually fitted for you. You deserve that much."

 Samantha bumps your shoulder lightly. "Don't worry. We'll make it quick and painless. Probably. Depends on how indecisive you are."

 "And I promise it doesn't have to be anything fancy," Jessica says, giggling. "Just something that feels right."

 You look between the two of them, and the idea of actually getting one doesn't feel embarrassing or overwhelming anymore. It just feels... doable.
 
 
 You hesitate for a second. There's no easy way to say it, but you figure honesty's better than letting them keep guessing.

 "...No," you finally admit. "I don't have one. No sports bra, no anything. I just... don't wear one."

 "Wait," Samantha says, eyes wide. "Hold on. You mean to tell me you've been walking around like this with nothing? Just letting them hang there?"

 You flush, suddenly wishing you'd kept your mouth shut. "Yeah. I mean... I didn't think it was that big of a deal. They're not even that—"

 "[name]," Samantha cuts you off. "What the fuck, dude. You need support. That's, like, basic. How do you even move around without wanting to die? Doesn't that hurt?"

 You look down at your top, a little defensive. "Not... really? Sometimes, I guess. It can be uncomfortable though. I just try not to think about it."

 Jessica steps closer, her usual energy dimmed by a kind of quiet seriousness you don't see often. "[name], that's not good for you," she says gently but firmly.

 "What do you mean?" you ask, a little startled by how serious she sounds.

 "Not having any support for your chest can cause all kinds of problems," she explains. "It's not just about comfort. It can actually mess with your posture, cause pain in your back and shoulders, and even affect how your chest develops. It's really not good to go without."

 Samantha nods, crossing her arms. "Yeah, and you're not exactly flat anymore. You can't just ignore them. You need a bra. You've needed a bra for a while now."

 "I didn't know it was that serious," you admit.

 Jessica softens at that, her voice gentler now. "I know. It's one of those things no one really explains, but it makes a huge difference. Even a simple bra will help you feel more supported and make moving around wayyy more comfortable."

 "And lucky for you, we're in the perfect place to fix this," Samantha says. "First stop: bra store. We're not letting you walk around like this any longer."

 "I know it's scary," Jessica says, "but I promise it'll make a difference."

 You swallow, the mix of embarrassment and relief settling in your chest. "Alright," you say quietly. "You guys know better than I do. Lead the way."

 Samantha claps you on the back, grinning. "You're gonna thank us later. Trust me."

 And just like that, you find yourself following them. You try not to think too hard about how surreal this all feels. After all, it might just be exactly what you need.
 
 

[Choice: Bra store]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica Blink + Shine
passages.text:
As you step into Blink + Shine, it's like crossing an invisible border into a parallel dimension—one where everything is soft, glowy, and smells faintly like peach gummies. The lighting is gentle and warm, like its designed to make you feel pretty just for existing. Even the floor seems to muffle your footsteps, like the store is trying not to startle you. Everywhere you look, there are racks of neatly spaced chiffon blouses, high-waisted trousers in pastel shades, ruffled skirts, and gauzy cardigans.

Samantha comes to a halt two steps behind you, arms crossed, jaw already tense.

"Oh, great," she says flatly, voice dripping with sarcasm. "We've entered the afterlife. It's... pink. I hate it."

You glance back at her. "It's not that bad."

"No, [name]. This isn't a store," she says, scanning the frilly displays with narrowed eyes. "This is a place where they turn chiffon into clothes for girls who want to look delicate and artsy."

Jessica steps lightly past both of you, her eyes sweeping the store with an air of familiarity. "No need to be so dramatic. Blink + Shine's... fine," she says with an easy shrug. "Not NovaTrend good, but fine. Like a solid B-tier. I've gotten a couple of cute pieces here."

"B-tier?" Samantha scoffs. "It's not even on the list. Negative tier or something. There isn't a single hoodie in this whole place. That's a war crime."

Jessica doesn't even look at her, already browsing a rack of pale yellow sundresses. "That's because this isn't a hoodie kind of store. Not everything has to look like you're about to go loiter in a parking lot."

"Loitering has aesthetic value," Samantha shoots back.

You snort, unable to help it. "Do you two need me to get popcorn, or...?"

Jessica waves a hand dismissively. "This isn't a fight. I'm just saying it's nice for what it is. You just have to know what you're looking for."

Samantha mutters, "Yeah, what I'm looking for is the exit."

"Oh, come on," Jessica says with a smirk. "You act like just touching a blouse is going to kill you."

"Not kill me," Samantha replies, leaning closer to a particularly frilly display of ruffled blouses and narrowing her eyes. "But I'm pretty sure this one would insult me in French."

"I mean, maybe it'd be right," you mutter under your breath.

Samantha points at you without looking away from the blouse. "You're dangerously close to getting abandoned in here."

You step a little farther into the score, scanning the walls until something catches your eye—a softly glowing wall of accessories near the back, glimmering under the perfect lighting. Rows of earrings shaped like tiny stars, layered necklaces, glossy hair clips, and more. It's like its inviting you to look closer.

"I might go check out the accessory wall," you say, gesturing toward it.

Jessica follows your line of sight and nods. "Good choice. Honestly, their accessories are usually better than their clothes."

"Great," Samantha sighs dramatically. "We've reached the phase of the trip where [name] gets distracted by shiny things. Classic."

You glance back at her. "You don't have to come with me, you know."

"Oh, I'm coming," Samantha says quickly. "Someone's gotta supervise you. Make sure you don't walk out of here with a bedazzled belt or something. I promised to help you shop, and I take my promises very seriously."

"Sam, if he walks out with a bedazzled belt, that's between him and his new personality," Jessica says. "Let him explore."

"Explore," Samantha repeats, skeptically. "That's what we're calling it now."

You roll your eyes, but you can't help smiling as you start toward the accessories section in the back.

"I swear to God, if anything in this corner tries to sparkle at me, I'm leaving you here to fend for yourself," Samantha mutters.

You crack a grin, but your eyes linger on the wall.

Maybe you'll go take a look.

Or maybe you won't.

[Choice: Head toward the accessories]
[Choice: Decide to leave the store]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica Blink + Shine 1
passages.text:
You look at the accessories wall. It's a little less threatening from the rest of the store—less commitment, more possibilities. Everything's arranged in neat little rows: tiny hair clips shaped like fruit, sparkling pins, pastel scrunchies, earrings dangling from gold hooks. "Yeah, I have to check that section out," you murmur, already drifting toward it. "Good call," Jessica says. "Accessories make or break an outfit. It's the details people notice more than you think." Samantha sighs with all the theatrical flair of someone being led to her doom. "Of course you'd say that," she says, arms still crossed like she's bracing for impact. "Let it be known I followed you willingly into the Kingdom of Glitter. May history remember me as a good friend who died for the cause." You glance back at her. "Died?" "Spiritually," she says flatly. "My soul can only take so much exposure to fruit-shaped hair clips before it gives up and ascends." Jessica gives her a look. "You're being dramatic. It's not that bad." Samantha stares at her, then gestures vaguely toward the pastel chaos of Blink + Shine. "Jessica. There are scrunchies here that look like they belong in a dollhouse, and I think the wall of headbands is judging me. If this isn't hostile territory, I don't know what is." You pick up a lavender hairtie and give it an experimental tug. You turn your attention to the little container of hair ties. Four types sit coiled like soft spirals:
  • A plain elastic
  • A simple ribbon
  • A bunny ears ribbon
  • A scrunchie
"I don't get how people deal with long hair," Samantha mutters. "You wash it, you dry it, you tie it, you try to make it not look like a bird nestled in it overnight—and then what? Some wind comes along and ruins it in two seconds anyway." "Long hair isn't that hard if you know what you're doing," Jessica says. "It's actually pretty easy to manage once you get a routine down. Conditioner's non-negotiable, obviously, and a good scalp oil makes a huge difference." You blink at her. "Scalp oil? That's a thing?" Jessica nods like this is common knowledge everyone should have. "Oh, totally. If your scalp is dry or unhealthy, your hair's going to suffer. Oils help keep it balanced and hydrated. Plus, regular brushing helps distribute the natural oils so it stays shiny. And you have to trim it regularly. Split ends are the enemy." "Okay, but how about tying it up? Like... doesn't that just pull on it all the time?" Jessica tilts her head, reaching up to adjust the maroon hairtie holding her ponytail in place. "It really depends on how you do it. Ponytails are totally fine if you don't yank them too tight or sleep in them. I like using ribbons like this or scrunchies 'cause they're gentler on the hair. And if you braid it at night, it won't tangle as much. It's all about balance, to be honest. You're meant to treat your hair like it's delicate, but not like it's untouchable." "God, that sounds exhausting," Samantha says, pulling her beanie lower over her short, choppy hair. "I wake up, put on a beanie, and go about my day. My hair hasn't seen oil, or a 'routine,' or whatever the hell you just described in, like, ever. And guess what? It's fine." Jessica side-eyes her, not missing a beat. "It's fine because you've basically opted out of having a style. Beanies are just hiding whatever's going on under there." "They're efficient," Samantha counters. "Plus, the beanie is my style." "I mean... she's not wrong," you say. "I've never once seen Sam without a beanie." "Exactly!" Samantha beams. "It's part of the brand. No beanie, no Samantha." "You two are impossible," Jessica says, although there's a faint smile tugging at her lips. "Look, I'm not saying everyone has to have a ten-step hair routine, but even a little effort goes a long way. Long hair frames your face differently. It can soften or sharpen your features depending on the cut and color. It's way more versatile than short hair since you can experiment, change things up, play with your look, all that stuff." Samantha groans, crossing her arms even tighter. "Or you could just have short hair and save yourself the TED talk." You glance back at the wall of hair pins. "Maybe I'll just start small. Accessories seem... easy." [Choice: Try some accessories on] You glance once more toward the accessories wall. All those glittering pastel trinkets and softly glowing displays. The racks of lavender hair ties. The earrings shaped like strawberries and clouds. You take exactly one step forward. And then stop. Nope. You pivot on your heel and head back toward the entrance without a word. Samantha perks up immediately. "Wait—are we leaving? Are you leaving?" You nod. "Yeah. It's not really... for me." She exhales in exaggerated, performative relief. "Thank God. I thought I was gonna die in there." Jessica, who'd been lazily sifting through a rack of cropped sweaters, looks up immediately. "Really? You're not even going to look?" Her tone isn't judgmental, just mildly disappointed. "That's kind of a shame. They've got some nice stuff back there if you take a minute." "Just not feeling it," you say. Jessica studies you for a second longer, but eventually decides to let it drop with a faint sigh. "Fine, I guess. One day, you're going to regret walking away from a perfectly good wall of accessories." "Doubt it," Samantha pipes up. "This place is a minefield of ruffles and vibes I can't handle. I was starting to think you'd make me stand here while you tried on pearl-studded hair clips." Jessica shoots her a look. "God forbid anyone try to soften your aesthetic for five seconds." "I'll have you know, my aesthetic is perfect," Samantha says with a big smirk on her face. "Zero ruffles. Zero pastels. One hundred percent survivable." "Survivable isn't exactly aspirational," Jessica says, breezing past her toward the exit. You open the door and step out, letting the soft, peachy scent of Blink + Shine fall away as you step back into the louder, brighter expanse of the mall. Jessica glances at you as she pushes her hair behind one ear. "Still, though. Next time, you should at least give it a chance. Accessories are the easiest way to try something new without committing to a whole look." "Next time," you echo, though you're not sure you mean it. Samantha, already walking a few paces ahead, throws up a hand in mock celebration. "Victory for the hoodie-wearing population. We live to fight another day." Jessica shakes her head. "You're impossible." "And yet, beloved," Samantha quips. You chuckle under your breath as you fall into step between them. Maybe you didn't walk out with anything new, but at least you tried going inside. And right now, that feels like enough. [Choice: Make your way back to the central area]

choices.text: Make your way back to the central area

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica Blink + Shine 10
passages.text:
<<if [transgender] > 14>> 
 Maya's back at the register when you approach. Her smile blooms the second she sees the clothes in your arms—like she's genuinely proud of your picks, like she's seen this kind of decision before and knows just how much it means.

 "Ooh, good choices," she says, reaching for the items with a practiced ease. She scans them one by one, folding them gently. "You'll pull them off well, I can feel it."

 You laugh, flush warming your face. "Thanks."

 Jessica standing just behind you, nods approvingly "Honestly? You've got an eye for this stuff. Those pieces are super versatile. I told you Blink + Shine isn't that bad."

 Samantha leans an elbow on the counter, letting out a loud, fake sigh. "Don't encourage him," she says to Jessica. "Do you realize what's happening here? I've officially lost my best friend to the pastel abyss. First it was hairpins. Now it's high-waisted shorts and flowy dresses. Next thing you know, I'm gonna come over and there'll be scented candles, bath bombs, and a Pinterest board."

 Maya doesn't miss a beat. "Honestly? Sounds like a glow-up to me."

 "You are not helping," Samantha groans, but she's grinning as she says it.

 "See?!" Jessica says. "Even the staff agrees."

 You pull out your phone and tap it against the reader. The soft ding confirms the purchase with a satisfying finality. Maya slides your receipt into the bag and then passes it across the counter.

 "Thanks for trusting yourself," she says, quiet now, like it's just between the two of you. "You looked good. I hope it made you feel good too."

 You meet her eyes, and you don't need to say anything. You just nod.

 Then you're heading toward the door, Samantha trailing behind you with the most dramatic limp you've ever seen.

 "Do you feel that?" she says as you push open the door. "The tragedy? The betrayal? The estrogen in the air?"

 "Isn't there estrogen in your body?" Jessica fires.

 Samantha doesn't even bother responding.

 You laugh.

 "Look, you look happy," Jessica says. "That's what matters."

 You smile at that. "Yeah. I kind of am."

 Samantha walks a few paces ahead, then spins around to face you. "Happy? He's glowing! [name], just yesterday, you were a humble peasant in cargo shorts and a T-shirt. Today? A goddess in linen."

 "Should I be offended or flattered?"

 "Yes," she says.

 You keep going and you feel lighter, not just because of the bag swinging at your side, but because of something else entirely. Something that feels like permission. Like maybe, just maybe, you're starting to let yourself be exactly who you are.

 
 You walk up to the counter with the clothes in your arms, the folded items inside feeling heavier than they should. They're not even that flashy—just a couple of things, nothing major—but now they feel like they're glowing in the bag, practically announcing themselves.

 Maya looks up from the register with a mellow smile and reaches for your bag. "All set?" she asks.

 You nod, tight-lipped. "Yeah."

 She doesn't push, just scans the items quickly. "These are cute picks. Nice touch of colors."
 You force a little smile, the kind that doesn't quite reach your eyes. "Thanks."

 Maya slides the receipt into a bag and hands it back to you. "Hope they treat you well," she says kindly. "And thanks for stopping by."

 "Yeah," you murmur. "You too."

 You turn, clutching the bag a little too tight, and head for the exit. Samantha and Jessica fall in step beside you immediately, no hesitation.

 None of you speaks at first.

 The bright hum of Blink + Shine fades as the door swings shut behind you, replaced with the colder, wider air of the mall corridor. The peach scent and soft lighting give way to the polished tile and overhead fluorescents.

 Jessica watches you out of the corner of her eye as you grip the bag tightly, your knuckles whitening around the handle. "You okay?" Jessica asks, voice softer now.

 You keep walking a few paces before muttering, "I don't know. It just... feels dumb. Buying all that. Like it wasn't me."

 Jessica frowns, but Samantha gets there first. "You're not dumb," she says bluntly. "You tried something new. Sometimes it clicks. Sometimes it feels like trying on someone else's skin. That's just how it is."

 "That's an oddly insightful way to put it," you say, glancing at her.

 "I contain multitudes," Samantha says with a deadpan expression. "Also, you didn't burst into flames wearing it, so that's a win in my book."

 Jessica adds, "And even if it wasn't your style, that's fine. You don't have to get it perfect."

 "I guess," you say, breathing out slowly.

 "Hey, I promise, nobody's keeping score," Jessica says with an encouraging smile. "You just bought some clothes. That's all."

 Samantha smirks. "And if you ever want to ceremonially burn them, I've got matches somewhere in my pockets."

 That earns her an actual laugh from you.

 You walk a little slower as the bag swings at your side, the weight still there but not quite as suffocating. You don't know if the clothes will ever feel like you, but between Samantha and Jessica, the heaviness doesn't feel quite so unbearable.

 And for now, that's enough.
 

[Choice: Make your way back to the central area]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica Blink + Shine 3
passages.text:
You stand in front of the accessory mirror, the lavender hairpin resting between your fingers like it weighs more than it should. It doesn't, of course—it's barely a whisper in your grip. But your hand hesitates anyway, hovering just above your head, like you're waiting to be given permission.

You don't get any.

So you breathe in, tilt your head, and snap the pin into place.

The change is small—subtle enough you're not even sure it's visible. But it does something to your silhouette in the mirror. Softens it. Shifts it just enough that you pause, unsure what you're seeing. It's not better or worse, just... different.

Jessica appears at your side, catching your eye in the mirror. "Oh, that actually works," she says, smiling softly. "It frames your face in a nice way. Lavender's a good choice for you."

You glance at her, surprised by how casual and certain she sounds. "You really think so?"

"Definitely." She reaches up to adjust her own maroon hairtie, the one holding her ponytail neatly in place. "Lavender softens your features and draws attention to the eyes. I think it suits you."

Behind you, Samantha lets out a long, theatrical groan.

"Oh my God," she says, flinging her arms out like she's been hit by wave of invisible glitter. "It's over. You've crossed into the sparkle realm. I've lost my best friend."

You roll your eyes. "It's one hairpin, Sam."

"One lavender hairpin," she corrects, voice climbing half an octave in mock horror. "That's the gateway drug, [name]. Next thing you know, you're wearing flower crowns and watching makeup tutorials at 2 a.m."

Jessica laughs. "You're acting like that's a bad thing. Accessories are supposed to be fun."

"Fun for you, maybe," Samantha retorts. "I can barely keep this beanie straight on my head, let alone wear one of those dainty little ribbons."

You snort. "You literally wore glitter eyeliner to the school dance once."

"That was different," she says, tossing her head. "That was battle armor. And besides, I balanced it out with ripped jeans and, like, combat boots. It was a look."

"Not a bad one," Jessica admits, giving Samantha a half-smile.

Samantha waves her off like she doesn't want the compliment, even though she does.

You turn toward the little display beside the mirror. Four types of lavender hair ties sit in a tray: a plain elastic, a soft ribbon, one with floppy bunny ears, and a plush scrunchie. You reach out, gently poking at them one by one.

Samantha leans down to inspect the display like she's evaluating evidence at a crime scene.

"You planning to put your hair up with one of those?" she asks.

"Maybe," you say, because you honestly don't know.

She makes a noise like a dying cat. "Ugh. Long hair. Why would you want that kind of responsibility?"

 
 "I already have long hair," you remind her.

 "Yeah, and I've been meaning to stage an intervention," she shoots back. "You know how easy it is to live your life when you don't wake up with a tangled bird's nest on your head? You just exist. You just vibe. You throw on a beanie and call it fashion."

 You glance at her. "You wear the same beanie like every day."

 "Its called a signature look," she says. "Learn some culture."

 
 "I don't have long hair," you say. "It's like... medium."

 Samantha snorts. "Medium is just long that's pretending it's still low-maintenance. That stuff tangles if you breathe wrong."

 You raise an eyebrow. "I do brush it, you know."

 "Barely," she fires back. "You need a whole hair care routine and a support group just to make that length work."

 "You literally wear a beanie."

 "It's called having a brand," she says, flicking her fingers. "Try to keep up."

 
 "I don't need hair ties," you point out, brushing your hand over your head. "It's already short."

 Samantha gives you a dry look. "Yeah, but you look like you keep it short for convenience. I keep mine short for the aesthetic. Huge difference."

 You snort. "You're in a graphic tee and a beanie right now."

 "And still somehow serving," she says, striking a dramatic pose. "Minimal effort, maximum style. Meanwhile, you're out here debating hair accessories like it's a moral crisis."

 "Maybe I'm just evolving," you say, shrugging.

 "Then evolve faster," she says. "Your final form better be iconic."
 

You reach down and pick up the bunny ears hair tie. You twirl it between your fingers, letting it dangle.

"I don't know," you murmur. "It is kind of cute."

"Yeah, well," she mutters, glancing off to the side. "It's not like anyone else should get to tell you what to wear, right?"

You blink at her.

"What?" she snaps, a little too quickly. "I can be supportive."

"Sure," you say, still spinning the ribbon slowly.

"Just don't expect me to get matching ones," she says. "My hair tie phase died in elementary school."

You grin. "So you had a phase?"

"No comment."

You turn back to the mirror, the ribbon still in your hand, the lavender pin glinting faintly in your hair. The shop's lighting is soft here—almost too gentle compared to the rest of the mall. There's no pressure to do anything. But there is an invitation.

And for once, you think you might say yes.

[Choice: Time to buy!]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica Blink + Shine 5
passages.text:
You turn the little accessory over in your hands one last time—simple, small, yet somehow enough to shift something internal. Like a nudge toward a version of yourself that's been hovering just out of reach.

Samantha lingers a few steps behind as you quietly head toward the counter. She doesn't say anything at first, just trails behind with her hands stuffed into her pockets like she's forced to be here. Which, to be fair, she kind of is.

You place your choices on the counter. Whatever they are, they feel like the right ones. The sales associate, Maya, appears with a practiced ease, her bracelets giving a soft clatter as she starts scanning your items.

Jessica watches you from a few feet away, her expression soft. "That's actually cute," she says, nodding toward your choice. "It works for you. Subtle, but still makes a statement."

You glance at her. "That's a lot of thought for a hair thingie or whatever."

"Accessories are underrated," she says with a little grin. "They're like punctuation, if you think about it. Tiny, but capable of changing the entire vibe. You'll see what I mean."

Samantha lingers a few steps behind as you quietly head toward the counter. She doesn't say anything at first, just trails behind with her hands stuffed into her pockets like she's being forced to witness some great tragedy.

You place your choices on the counter. Whatever they are, they feel like the right ones.

"Good picks," Maya says with a warm smile. "You've got an eye for what works together."

You blink, unsure how to take the compliment. "Uh... thanks."

"See?" Jessica says, leaning in with a playful smirk. "Even the pros approve."

Samantha peeks over your shoulder, squinting at the counter. "Wow," she says flatly. "Look at you, [name]. Joining the ranks of the accessorized. Never thought I'd see the day."

You raise an eyebrow. "Is that your official review?"

"Hey, I'm impressed," she says, folding her arms. "It's nice."

You snort. "Thanks?"

"Don't let it go to your head," she adds, grinning. "Next thing I know, you'll be dragging me into a store full of pastel crop tops and high heels, and that's where I draw the line."

Jessica cuts in with a laugh. "Please. You'd look great in pastel. Own it."

"Absolutely not," Samantha fires back, making a face. "I'd rather get tackled by Luke than wear one of those little ruffle things."

"You'd say that until you tried one on."

"Not happening."

Maya hands you a little branded bag with your receipt tucked neatly inside. "These'll look great," she says warmly. "Sometimes small changes do the most."

You nod, your fingers curling around the handle. The bag crinkles softly, light in your hand—but heavier in meaning.

Samantha glances at it like it might combust. "You realize this is the most feminine bag you've ever carried, right?"

You look down at it. "It's paper."

"Yeah. But it feels like glitter," she deadpans. "You carry that out of here and there's no going back."

"Then I guess I'm committed."

"Good," Jessica says smiling. "Committed is a good look on you."

She throws an arm around your shoulder in exaggerated mock support. "Godspeed, soldier. May your hair clips be strong and your inner doubt minimal."

You scoff, rolling your eyes, but you don't shrug her off. Her arm's warm and familiar, and for all her dramatic flair, there's a sincerity under it that you don't miss.

Jessica glances toward the rest of the store, hands on her hips. "You know, the clothes here aren't half bad," Jessica mentions. "I've gotten some cute pieces from here before. The quality is decent."

Samantha groans dramatically. "Oh God. Here it comes. The 'let's try on clothes' speech."

I didn't say that," Jessica says innocently. "Yet."

The rest of the store suddenly feels like a different planet. The accessories wall was one thing—small, safe, optional. Clothing, though? That's bigger. You feel the weight of the moment press just a little.

"So," Samantha says, drawing the word out. "Is this the part where you walk out or do we see what fashion crimes await beyond the accessories zone?" 

You look from the racks to the exit, and the choice sits there, waiting.

[Choice: Go to the clothing section]
[Choice: Decide to leave the store]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica Blink + Shine 6
passages.text:
You hesitate for a beat, your eyes flicking toward the exit—toward safety, toward certainty, toward a version of yourself that didn't just buy hair accessories from a peace-scented boutique. But your hand tightens around the little shopping bag, fingers curling around the edge. And when you lift your chin, it's with just enough to surprise even yourself.

 "Yeah," you say, voice quiet but clear. "Sure. I'll take a look."

 Jessica grins like she just won a bet. "See? I knew you weren't going to wimp out," she says, brushing a strand of her ponytail back. "You've already gotten halfway through the store, might as well commit to seeing all of it."

 Samantha lets out a low whistle, dragging her beanie down just a little over her forehead. "Oh damn," she says. "I was 80% sure you were gonna nope out. Respect."

 You shrug, but there's a crooked smile on your face that gives you away. "Guess I'm full of surprises."

 "I like this version of you," Jessica says, teasing but genuine. "Brave enough to shop here."

 Maya reappears from seemingly nowhere, like a stylish fairy godmother who works on commission. She beams, clearly pleased, and gestures with a hanger. "This way," she says, already guiding you deeper into the store.

 Samantha falls into step beside you, casting a wary glance around the racks like one of them might try to convert her into a girly girl on the spot. "If one of these mannequins winks at me, I'm burning this place down," she mutters.

 "Relax, Samantha," Jessica says, laughing. "It's a clothing store, not a horror movie."

 "Easy for you to say," Samantha shoots back, sidestepping a rack of glittery cardigans. "This is your natural habitat. I'm out here like a raccoon that wandered into a makeup store."

 "Not everything has to be combat boots and sarcasm."

 Samantha shrugs. "Works for me."

 Maya leads you into a section lit just a little warmer than the rest, where each piece hangs with a certain amount of dignity. Not crowded, not shoved together—like the clothes are being patient. Like they're waiting for someone to notice them.

 "You see, we don't really do fast fashion," Maya explains, pausing to smooth out the hem of a skirt. "Everything's selected in small batches. If it's here, it's supposed to be here."

 You nod and scan the selection: a cream apron-style dress that whispers vintage, pleated skirts, blush pink shorts that catch the light, a denim skirt, and more. Each item feels like it's been invited here on purpose.

 "See? This isn't bad," Jessica says, looking at the selections. "You could build some really cute outfits out of this stuff."

 Samantha squints at the shorts. "These look like they require a latte and a skincare routine. Not exactly my thing."

 You snort. "Thanks for the vote of confidence."

 "I'm just saying," she says, holding up the pleated skirt with two fingers like it might bite her. "This stuff's like... fairycore. Do you get what I mean? If you come out in one of these and start talking about moon rituals, I'm leaving you here."

 "Moon rituals aren't the worst aesthetic," Jessica comments.

 "They are when you have to buy the crystals for them," Samantha fires back.

 You roll your eyes, but your grip on the bag softens. The banter somehow makes it easier. Safe, even in a place that feels so far from your usual.

 At the edge of the section, Maya hooks a few pieces onto a hangar and offers them to you. "Fitting rooms are just over there," she says. "Take your time."

 You glance over. The fitting area is cozy, even having a little bench and mirror.

 Samantha crosses her arms and leans against a rack of pants, clearly not planning to move. "Alright," she says. "Moment of truth. Show me your final form."

 "What if I come out in a full dress?" you ask, raising an eyebrow.

 She considers it for a few seconds. "Depends," she says, finally. "Do you spin dramatically? Because that would definitely earn bonus points."

 "Just try them on," Jessica says. "You don't have to spin unless you want to."

 Maya chuckles as she walks off, giving you space. "I'll be at the front if you need sizes," she calls over her shoulder.

 You breathe in and put one foot in front of the other. The door is right there, and now it's all up to you.

 
 
 There may be issues with clipping and certain assets not fitting. Please understand!
 

 [Choice: Try some stuff on]

 
 You take one last glance at the rows of feminine clothing—not harshly, just enough to make it real.

 "Not today," you murmur.

 "Bold choice," she says, grinning. "Live to fight another day, huh?"

 "Aww," Jessica says. "Not going to look at the clothes at all?"

 You offer her a small shrug. "I don't think I'm ready to."

 Her expression softens in understanding. "That's fair."

 Samantha claps her hands together once, almost like she's breaking a spell. "Thank God," she declares dramatically, spinning toward the exit. "Because if I had to stand next to another rack of pink cardigans for one more minute, I was gonna spontaneously combust."

 "You know, for the record, I still think you'd look good in some of this stuff," Jessica says. "But there's no rush. You do this at your pace."

 You nod in response.

 You, Samantha, and Jessica step out out the store, and the scent of peach and perfume fades into the natural mall air, replaced by the faint whir of escalators and some distant pop remix playing from a speaker. Blink + Shine's pink-and-gold signage stays lit behind you like it's gently judging your life choices.

 "Alright," Samantha says, exhaling like she just escaped a hostage situation. "Blink + Shine: survived, conquered, escaped."

 Jessica shakes her head, grinning. "You're impossible."

 "I appreciate it," Samantha says proudly.

 There's a smile tugging at your mouth as the two of you merge back into the steady flow of shoppers. And even though you didn't try on any clothes, you feel like you made the right call.

 At least for today.

 [Choice: Make your way back to the central area]

passages.name: Day 18 - Shopping Samantha & Jessica Blink + Shine 8
passages.text:
<<if [transgender] > 14>> 
 You hear the door's soft click as it closes behind you, sealing you into a hushed little world of your own. Inside the dim fitting room, everything feels gentler—like someone paused the noise outside just for this moment.

 On the bench lies your selection: a clean white tank top, an oversized soft sweater, and a cute blue skirt. There are a few other pieces still on their hangers—they send a flutter of anticipation through your chest.

 You sit down, your hand lingering over the sweater, feeling its weight and texture. It hums with possibility. You begin changing deliberately—the tank top slides on easily, snug but soft. The sweater settles itself just right on your shoulders. You slip into the skirt, and something settles in your chest—a careful calm that feels... correct.

 You step toward the mirror and freeze for a moment. It's not unease—it's wonder. The reflection isn't someone else. It's you, clearer and more honest than ever. Like static faded, and a deeper melody emerged.

 You do a little spin, enough to let the skirt flutter around your legs, and laugh—light and surprised. Your hands smooth the front, then adjust the folds, then smooth again. Not from doubt, but because you like this feeling. So much that your breath warms and settles in your ribs.

 Beautiful.

 You realize the word fits you now.

 You can't help but smile. Not the nervous, halfway kind you've been doing a lot lately. This one is quiet but whole.

 You stay like that for a second longer than necessary. Just... looking.

 Then, slowly, you change back.

 As you fold the clothes you won't be buying and hang the ones you will back on your arm, your fingers tremble slightly—not with uncertainty, but with something close to joy. You open the door.

 Jessica and Samantha are parked by a nearby rack, mid-conversation. Jessica's absently combing through a row of cardigans with one hand, her long blonde ponytail swaying as she turns to make some point. Samantha, on the other hand, is slouched against the wall, arms crossed, wearing the look of someone who's just been enduring a lecture.

 "—I'm just saying that good clothes make you feel different," Jessica says. "You carry yourself differently. Like, confidence isn't just internal. It's also about how things fit and how you see yourself in the mirror."

 Samantha groans. "See, this is what happens when you leave me alone with you in a pastel death trap. I get a psych lecture."

 Jessica rolls her eyes, but it's playful. "It's not a psych lecture. It's just fashion, Sam."

 Then they notice you, both set of eyes landing on you at once.

 "Well?" Jessica says, eyebrows raised. "How'd it go in there?"

 You can feel it on your face—the stupid little smile you can't quite get rid of. "Good," you say. "Really good, actually."

 Jessica brightens instantly, practically clapping her hands together. "See? I told you this place had its moments. Didn't it feel different? You're still you, but feminine."

 Samantha squints at you like you've betrayed her. "Oh no," she mutters, backing up a step in genuine horror. "No. Nooo. I've lost him. He's gone. My best friend—stolen by the dark forces of ruffles and soft lighting."

 "Dark forces?" Jessica repeats. "This store is literally the definition of bright pastel heaven. It's like walking into a strawberry milkshake. There's nothing dark about it."

 Samantha groans and slaps a hand over her face. "Oh, that's even worse! I've been dragged into the lair of the bubblegum overlords. My soul can't survive this much pink."

 You laugh, actually laugh, and that's enough to make Samantha peek at you between her fingers. "Oh my God," she says slowly, her eyes narrowing like she's studying a strange phenomenon. "You liked it. You actually liked it in there."

 You glance down at the clothes in your hands, then back up. "Yeah," you admit, with a little shrug. "I... did."

 Jessica grins, triumphant. "And that's why you trust me. Fashion enlightenment, delivered as promised."

 "Guess that's it then," Samantha says like she's in pain. "Guess that's it, then. My best friend's a girlypop now. Gonna start doing filtered selfies next, huh?"

 "Maybe I will."

 "Well, come on then," Jessica says. "Let's make it official before Samantha has a full-blown identity crisis over there."

 Samantha mutters something about "buying a coping beanie" under her breath as she follows, but you're already heading toward the counter.

 
 You push the fitting room door closed behind you—it clicks shut, cutting out Blink + Shine's gentle bubblegum pop. Here, under the harsh fitting-room lights, it's just you and the clothes.

 You glance down at what you're about to try on, resting neatly on the bench: a white tank top, an oversized sweater, a cute blue skirt—and a few other things that make your heart race. They should be safe and unthreatening. They're just pieces of fabric, after all. But as you pull on the tank top, you feel a familiar tension anchor in your chest—the question: Is this really you?

 You catch your reflection as the fabric settles on your shoulder, heart twisting slightly. The clothes fit—shoulder seams sit right, the cut flatters, the fabric flows. You're not hiding in them. But there's still distance between you and the person in the mirror.

 You stand straighter, arms folding across your chest like armor. Try your best to mimic confidence. Tilt your chin. Exhale. But every pose feels rehearsed. Distant. And inside, the question still churns: "What am I even doing?"

 You switch to another skirt. Tug it on, smooth the fabric over your waist and hips, step back. It looks... fine. But still wrong. Wrong enough to make your throat tighten.

 There's no panic, no disgust. Just a slow, hollow well of disappointment. You really wanted this to work—and you tried it. But that doesn't make it click.

 You strip the clothes off carefully, fold each one back just how they were, neat and patient on the bench. Then you slide into your familiar top. It doesn't feel incredible—it just feels right. Unremarkable, but you. That's enough.

 You pull open the door and step out.

 Jessica and Samantha are both waiting just outside, talking. Both of them look up the second you step out.

 You're back in your regular clothes.

 Jessica tilts her head, taking in your expression. "So...?" she says gently, eyebrows lifting. "How'd it go?"

 You hesitate. "Didn't work," you admit finally. "It just... didn't feel like me."

 "Called it," Samantha says. "Those pink shorts were a bad omen from the start."

 Jessica shoots her a look before turning back to you. "It's okay, [name]. You don't have to like everything. That's the point of trying things, isn't it? You figure out what feels right and what doesn't."

 "Yeah," you mutter. "Guess I'm just not the kind of person who would shop here."

 "Let's just chalk this one up as a test run and move on," Jessica says, brushing some dust off her skirt.

 Samantha drapes an arm across your shoulders, steering you toward the door with exaggerated care like you've just survived something harrowing. "C'mon. Let's escape before someone tries to sell you matching pearl earrings. We'll find you something good that doesn't make you feel like you're in girlland."

 You nod. Neither Jessica or Samantha press. They just walk with you like this was nothing more than a weird little detour.

 And honestly? You're grateful for that.
 

[Choice: Time to purchase]
