passages.name: Day 18 - Text Jordan 1
passages.text:
<<if [jordanRelo] > 49>> 
 
 
 
 
 You read his last message again and it does something to you.

 Not just because it's sweet, but because it's him. Jordan, the guy who barely talks to anyone, who gave you the cold shoulder the first time you met, who probably didn't even remember your name back then. And now? He's texting you at night saying things like this.

 You could just keep things casual. Keep it friendly, safe, unremarkable.

 But you don't want to.

 So you let the warmth guide your thumbs.

 
 
 [name]
 careful
 
 
 
 [name]
 keep saying stuff like that and i might think you like talking to me or something
 
 

 The second you send it, you feel that mix of nerves and hope buzzing under your skin—because it's not too much, not a big leap. But it's something. And it's enough.

 He takes a little longer this time. You start wondering if you misread it, if maybe he's already closed the app. But then the bubbles appear. Typing. Pausing. Then typing again.

 
 
 Jordan
 maybe i do
 
 

 Three words. Simple. Blunt. But they land with more weight than you expect.

 You blink at the screen, then type quickly:

 
 
 [name]
 oh?
 
 

 And somehow that one-word reply says everything you want to ask.

 His response comes a few seconds later:

 
 
 Jordan
 i mean
 
 
 
 Jordan
 i dont rly text ppl
 
 
 
 Jordan
 not unless i wanna talk to them
 
 
 
 Jordan
 and i dont rly wanna talk to most ppl
 
 

 You smile, warmth creeping into your face as you pull your blanket closer around your shoulders.

 
 
 [name]
 well im honored lol
 
 
 
 Jordan
 u should be
 
 
 
 Jordan
 this is a pretty exclusive service
 
 

 You let out a soft laugh through your nose.

 
 
 [name]
 does it come with customer support?
 
 
 
 Jordan
 only if ur very polite
 
 

 You shake your head, grinning like an idiot now, the kind of grin that only happens when something clicks. Not like a sudden spark, but like something quietly falling into place.

 You stretch out under your blanket, the glow of the screen lighting your smile. And when the typing bubble flickers again, your heart already knows it's not over. Jordan isn't pushing you away. Not tonight. Not anymore.
 
 
 
 You reread Jordan's last message, and there's a quiet honesty to it that catches you off guard. It's not dramatic, not some huge declaration, but coming from him, it means something.

 You settle deeper into your blanket, thumbs moving without much hesitation this time.

 
 
 [name]
 that means a lot actually
 
 
 
 [name]
 ur easy to talk to too
 
 
 
 [name]
 ...when u want to be
 
 

 There's a pause, and then the typing bubble pops up again almost immediately.

 
 
 Jordan
 lol yh
 
 
 
 Jordan
 i know im not exactly a social butterfly
 
 
 
 [name]
 nah, but when u talk, its worth listening to
 
 

 You're not laying it on thick or anything—just being honest. And Jordan doesn't deflect like he used to.

 
 
 Jordan
 i appreciate that
 
 
 
 Jordan
 seriously
 
 
 
 [name]
 i dont hear that kind of thing often
 
 

 That makes you pause. Not because it's surprising, but because it hits deeper than you expect. You stare at the message, then type:

 
 
 Jordan
 ur a good person, [name]
 
 
 
 Jordan
 like actually good
 
 
 
 Jordan
 not fake nice
 
 

 You blink at that. Then, without thinking, type:

 
 
 [name]
 you too
 
 
 
 [name]
 even if u pretend ur all grumpy and mysterious
 
 
 
 Jordan
 lol ok fair
 
 
 
 Jordan
 but dont tell anyone
 
 
 
 Jordan
 ive got a rep to protect
 
 

 You grin.

 
 
 [name]
 secrets safe with me
 
 
 
 Jordan
 good
 
 
 
 Jordan
 i trust u
 
 

 The words are simple, but they land like something solid. You pull your blanket higher, a quiet calm settling over you that wasn't there before the conversation started.

 You weren't flashy or romantic, but you were real. And that matters.
 
 
 You read Jordan's message and grin a little, the corners of your mouth tugging up before you even realize it.

 That kind of honest from Jordan used to be rare. Early on, he barely gave you more than a nod. Now he's texting you at night, being real, even kind of soft. You could meet him in that same softness—keep it friendly, warm, maybe even a little sweet.

 But the moment feels just right for something else.

 So instead, you lean into the grin and type:

 
 
 [name]
 wow
 
 
 
 [name]
 soft jordan hours??
 
 
 
 [name]
 never thought id lived to see the day
 
 

 He doesn't take long to reply:

 
 
 Jordan
 dont get used to it
 
 
 
 Jordan
 i have a reputation to maintain
 
 
 
 [name]
 as a grumpy athlete with one facial expression?
 
 
 
 [name]
 ur rly branching out...
 
 
 
 Jordan
 hey
 
 
 
 Jordan
 i have at least two facial expressions
 
 
 
 Jordan
 the other one is when the vending machine actually works for once
 
 
 You snort as you type back:

 
 
 [name]
 ive seen that once
 
 
 
 [name]
 its basically joy mixed with awe
 
 
 
 Jordan
 can u blame me tho?
 
 
 
 Jordan
 those peanut butter crackers keep me going
 
 

 The rhythm is easy now. Back-and-forth with no awkward gaps, no hesitation. You can almost hear him saying the words, see the smirk on his face as he types them. It's weird to think about how natural this feels now.

 
 
 [name]
 well, ig im honored to be included in ur sacred snack time texts
 
 
 
 Jordan
 hmm
 
 
 
 Jordan
 ur like... second tier sacred
 
 
 
 Jordan
 right below vending machine
 
 
 
 Jordan
 but its close
 
 
 
 [name]
 second tier??
 
 
 
 [name]
 disrespectful
 
 
 
 Jordan
 fine
 
 
 
 Jordan
 tied
 
 
 
 Jordan
 but only if the machines out of crackers
 
 

 Your chest feels lighter than it has all day. You're both smiling—you know for a fact that he is. You don't need to see it to feel it. Right now it feels like you're exactly where you're supposed to be.
 

 
 
 
 
 
 You stare at his message for a second longer than you meant to, the corners of your mouth pulling into a small smile. The compliment he sent is the kind that could easily be brushed off. But coming from Jordan, it's practically a sonnet. And you know he didn't have to say it. That kind of casual praise doesn't come from him often or easily.

 So you let your fingers move, not overthinking it—but maybe thinking just enough.

 
 
 [name]
 thats nice of u to say
 
 
 
 [name]
 ur not bad urself, yknow
 
 

 You stare at the message for a second, debating whether it's too much. It isn't. It's barely a nudge. You hit send.

 The dots appear pretty fast.

 
 
 Jordan
 lol
 
 
 
 Jordan
 im just surviving over here
 
 
 
 [name]
 well ur handling it pretty well
 
 
 
 [name]
 kinda impressive tbh
 
 

 This time, the pause is longer. Not in a bad way—just like he read it twice.

 Then:

 
 
 Jordan
 thanks
 
 
 
 Jordan
 ur kind of surprising, u know that?
 
 

 You tilt your head at the screen, surprised.

 
 
 [name]
 how so?
 
 
 
 Jordan
 idk
 
 
 
 Jordan
 just didnt expect u to text me tonight ig
 
 
 
 Jordan
 not complaining tho
 
 

 Your chest does a little twist at that—small, but noticeable.

 
 
 [name]
 guess i just felt like talking to you
 
 

 You wait.

 He doesn't joke. Doesn't push it away.

 
 
 Jordan
 well... im not gonna tell you not to
 
 

 You lean back into your pillow, a soft smile tugging at your mouth, warmth blooming in your chest. It's nothing serious. Nothing concrete. Just a door opened a crack—and Jordan didn't close it.

 Not yet. Not at all.
 
 
 
 You read Jordan's message again, thumb brushing the edge of your phone. It's simple, but it's not empty. Especially coming from him. You smile a little, then type back, keeping it light.

 
 
 [name]
 i appreciate that
 
 
 
 [name]
 ur pretty solid too tbh
 
 
 
 [name]
 i feel like u dont say much, but when u do, it hits
 
 

 A pause. Then:

 
 
 Jordan
 lol
 
 
 
 Jordan
 coach says that too
 
 
 
 Jordan
 "quiet until it matters" or whatever
 
 

 You let out a quiet laugh through your nose.

 
 
 [name]
 guess that means i should take it personally when u do talk to me
 
 
 
 [name]
 in a good way ofc
 
 

 The typing bubbles come up faster this time.

 
 
 Jordan
 its cool
 
 
 
 Jordan
 i dont talk much
 
 
 
 Jordan
 and def not to everyone either
 
 

 You glance at that message a little longer than the others. Jordan's not the type to drop those kinds of lines if he didn't mean them.

 You respond:
 
 
 
 [name]
 well im glad ur talking to me
 
 

 There's a small pause, then:

 
 
 Jordan
 me too
 
 

 It's quiet after that. Not in a bad way. Just... settled.

 You lean your head back against the headboard, the light from your phone soft on your face. Jordan's messages are still up on the screen, and something about the conversation feels like a step forward. There's nothing dramatic. No big shift. But there is a kind of warmth that builds slowly.

 Jordan's not a talker. But tonight, he talked to you.

 And that matters.
 
 
 
 You read Jordan's message again, and it is a nice thing to say. Genuine, even. But instead of leaning into the warmth, you let a smirk pull at your lips as your thumbs move across the screen.

 
 
 [name]
 wow
 
 
 
 [name]
 high praise from the silent wall in the back row
 
 
 
 [name]
 should i frame this or just engrave it on something dramatic?
 
 

 You send it before thinking too hard. It's teasing, yeah—but light.

 The typing bubble flickers for a few seconds, then stops. Then comes back. Finally, a reply:

 
 
 Jordan
 lol
 
 

 That's it.

 You blink, suddenly aware of how short that looks. You try to recover:

 
 
 [name]
 kidding btw
 
 
 
 [name]
 appreciate it tho
 
 

 Another pause. Longer this time.

 Then:

 
 
 Jordan
 yeah is all good
 
 
 
 Jordan
 gonna head out tho
 
 
 
 Jordan
 night
 
 

 Just like that.

 You stare at the screen, thumb hovering over the keyboard, debating whether to type something else—but you don't. You know a brush-off when you see one. He's not mad. He's not being rude. He's just... done.

 You toss your phone onto the mattress with a soft sigh and sink back into the pillow, the weight of the silence suddenly sharper than it was before.

 Lesson learned. Jordan's not big on jokes that put walls between people. Next time, maybe you'll meet him where he is. Or maybe you won't get a next time.
 
 

[Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 18 - Text Luke
passages.text:
Text Luke Achievement Unlocked! 
 
 
You scroll through your messages, thumb flicking past half-read group chats and old notifications before landing on Luke's name. You don't even hesitate. If there's one person who'll always be happy to hear from you, no matter the time, no matter the reason—it's Luke.

You tap his name. The typing bubble is already blinking before you even finish hitting send.

 
 
 [name]
 you up?
 
 
 
 Luke
 DUDE
 
 
 
 Luke
 yes i am so up
 
 
 
 Luke
 i was literally just thinking of u wtf get outta my brain
 
 

You snort, already smiling.

 
 
 [name]
 creepy
 
 
 
 [name]
 but ok
 
 
 
 Luke
 just admit it
 
 
 
 Luke
 ur HONORED to live rent free in my brain
 
 
 
 [name]
 pretty sure ur brain is like...
 
 
 
 [name]
 a broom closet
 
 
 
 [name]
 with a leaky pipe and weird carpet
 
 
 
 [name]
 but sure, honored
 
 
 
 Luke
 RUDE
 
 
 
 Luke
 my brain is at least a deluxe storage unit and u know it
 
 
 
 Luke
 im putting a lava lamp in there out of SPITE
 
 
 
 [name]
 hope it catches fire
 
 
 
 Luke
 damn
 
 
 
 Luke
 [name] betrayal speedrun any%
 
 
 
 Luke
 ANYWAY
 
 
 
 Luke
 whats up??!!
 
 
 
 Luke
 what were u doing today
 
 

[Choice: I went shopping]
[Choice: I had a long day]
[Choice: You ever feel different based on what you wear?]
[Choice: What did you do today?]

choices.text: You ever feel different based on what you wear?

passages.name: Day 18 - Text Luke 1
passages.text:
You think about dodging the question. Luke's the type to latch onto the tiniest thing and never let it go—but he's also probably the only person who could make you feel completely normal about saying something kind of personal without making it an entire thing.

 So, you go for it.

 
 
 [name]
 went shopping
 
 

 His response comes so fast that you wonder how he managed to type it out so quickly.

 
 
 Luke
 YO??!!
 
 
 
 Luke
 with money?
 
 
 
 Luke
 for clothes??
 
 
 
 [name]
 yes, luke
 
 
 
 [name]
 for clothes
 
 
 
 Luke
 no more white tee and cargo shorts?
 
 
 
 Luke
 this cant be real...
 
 

 You roll your eyes, grinning anyway.

 
 
 [name]
 bro it was one time
 
 
 
 Luke
 IT IS EVERY TIME
 
 
 
 Luke
 i was starting to think that outfit was fused to your body
 
 
 
 [name]
 im not that bad
 
 
 
 Luke
 [lowercasename].
 
 
 
 Luke
 you've been wearing that same white shirt since high school started
 
 
 
 [name]
 okay fine
 
 
 
 [name]
 maybe i needed it
 
 
 
 Luke
 maybe???
 
 
 
 Luke
 [lowercasename] we were gonna have to stage an intervention
 
 

 You snort, stretching your legs out under your blanket.

 
 
 Luke
 so? whatd u get?
 
 

 You hesitate—because what you got is complicated. But that you went? That's enough for now.

 
 
 [name]
 some stuff
 
 
 
 [name]
 some new
 
 
 
 [name]
 it was... different
 
 
 
 Luke
 proud of u
 
 
 
 Luke
 next step is fashion montage
 
 
 
 Luke
 ill bring the snacks, u try on hats
 
 
 
 Luke
 we make bad decisions together
 
 
 
 [name]
 im not getting a hat
 
 
 
 Luke
 coward
 
 
 
 [name]
 youll live
 
 
 
 Luke
 idk if i will...
 
 
 
 Luke
 glad u got some stuff tho fr
 
 
 
 Luke
 feels kinda cool right?
 
 
 
 Luke
 doing something for yourself
 
 

 You stare at that one for a while.

 
 
 [name]
 yeah
 
 
 
 [name]
 it actually did
 
 

 He doesn't say anything else right away, but he doesn't need to.

 Sometimes, Luke jokes like he breathes. But once in a blue moon, he lands something honest right when you need it. And then he leaves it there. Lets it sit. Like a good friend does.

 
 You glance down at Luke's text and your fingers hover over your phone's keyboard. You could tell him. He wouldn't judge. He never does. But something about it—about putting it into words—feels a little too personal tonight. Too complicated to unpack over texts.

 So instead, you keep it simple.

 
 
 [name]
 long day
 
 
 
 [name]
 just tired now
 
 

 It only takes a second for him to reply.

 
 
 Luke
 gotchu
 
 

 You exhale a little, grateful that he's not prying. Luke might be loud, ridiculous, and powered by straight vibes, but when it matters, he knows when to back off.

 A few dots flicker on the screen.

 
 
 Luke
 ykw that reminds me of that one time last year when i had a long day and accidentally wore my shorts backwards
 
 
 
 Luke
 i didnt notice
 
 

 You blink. Then slowly type:

 
 
 [name]
 ...how?
 
 
 
 Luke
 i just thought the waistband felt a little loose
 
 
 
 Luke
 i thought id invented a new freedom of movement or smth
 
 
 
 Luke
 i was proud of myself
 
 
 
 [name]
 you wore them through all of your classes???
 
 
 
 Luke
 yeah
 
 
 
 Luke
 no one said anything
 
 
 
 [name]
 i dont even know what to say to that
 
 
 
 Luke
 i also got blue sharpie on my hand that day
 
 
 
 Luke
 it wouldnt scrub off no matter what
 
 
 
 Luke
 i just accepted it as a permanent part of my skin tone
 
 
 
 Luke
 was at peace fr
 
 
 
 Luke
 it was gone when i woke up the next day tho
 
 

 You snort, burying your face into your pillow. Even his dumbest stories feel like comfort food. He just stays with you. Distracts and makes space in the only way he knows how.

 And honestly?

 It does help.

 
 You stare at the screen for a second, thumb hesitating, then type:

 
 
 [name]
 do u ever feel different based on what u wear?
 
 

 There's a longer pause this time, and for a second you think maybe he's going to say something surprisingly deep or thoughtful.

 Then:

 
 
 Luke
 like physically??
 
 
 
 Luke
 yeah
 
 
 
 Luke
 tight jeans make me walk like a fancy crab
 
 

 You blink.

 
 
 [name]
 no like mentally or emotionally or smth
 
 
 
 [name]
 like does that ever mess w/ how u feel or how u seel urself or smth
 
 

 Another pause.

 
 
 Luke
 ohhhh
 
 
 
 Luke
 i get what u mean
 
 
 
 Luke
 when i wear my tank top i 100% believe i could outrun a mountain lion
 
 
 
 Luke
 like on foot
 
 
 
 Luke
 its just vibes
 
 

 You stare at your screen for a long time.

 
 
 [name]
 thats not what i meant...
 
 
 
 [name]
 but good to know ig
 
 
 
 Luke
 also when i wear sweatpants i feel so lazy
 
 
 
 Luke
 i swear they do smth with the material
 
 

 You huff out a laugh, shaking your head as your fingers type:

 
 
 [name]
 thanks luke
 
 
 
 [name]
 very profound
 
 
 
 Luke
 anytime!!
 
 
 
 Luke
 fashion is the window to the soul
 
 
 
 Luke
 i think i read that on a protein bar once
 
 

 You don't bother replying right away. You're too busy silently laughing into your pillow, wondering how someone so completely off the mark can still make you feel so much better.

 
 You glance at the screen and decide to dodge the question.

 
 
 [name]
 what did u do today, huh?
 
 

 His reply comes back almost instantly, like he'd been waiting for the invitation.

 
 
 Luke
 ok so
 
 
 
 Luke
 i tried to fix the dishwasher bc mom said it was leaking
 
 

 You already brace yourself.

 
 
 Luke
 and i may have made things a little worse
 
 
 
 Luke
 by "fix" i mean "hit it gently with a hammer"
 
 
 
 Luke
 and by "gently" i mean "aggressively"
 
 
 
 Luke
 and by "hammer" i mean "skateboard"
 
 

 You cover your face with your hand, laughing onto your palm.

 
 
 [name]
 HOW
 
 
 
 [name]
 why would ur brain think that was a good idea
 
 
 
 Luke
 bc it was making this THUNK sound and my brain said "thunk it back"
 
 
 
 Luke
 also i wanted to see if it would stop if i just scared it enough
 
 
 
 [name]
 did it?
 
 
 
 Luke
 no
 
 

 You're full-on grinning now. You can practically hear his voice in the texts, too loud and too proud.

 
 
 [name]
 anything else?
 
 
 
 [name]
 or just domestic destruction
 
 
 
 Luke
 oh wait
 
 
 
 Luke
 i wore two different shoes to school
 
 
 
 Luke
 i gaslit myself into thinking it was on purpose tho
 
 
 
 Luke
 and now it IS on purpose
 
 
 
 Luke
 its called fashion [lowercasename] go look it up
 
 
 
 [name]
 im calling the police
 
 
 
 Luke
 theyll never catch me
 
 
 
 Luke
 im too lopsided
 
 

 You set your phone down for a second, laughing into your blanket. Luke's chaos is its own unique kind of comfort. The world might be weird and unstable, but at least this is reliable.
 

[Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 18 - Text Vincent
passages.text:
Text Vincent Achievement Unlocked! 
 
 
<<if [vincentRelo] > 19>> 
 You scroll through your contacts, your thumb hovering over names. You think of Jordan—too intense for tonight. Luke—maybe too much energy.

 Then your eyes land on Vincent.

 Something about his name on your screen makes your chest feel a little lighter. He's awkward, sure, and sometimes says things that sound like they belong in an encyclopedia, but there's something comforting about how genuine he always is. He never fakes being cool. Never tries to impress anyone. He's just him. Vincent.

 You tap his name and start typing.

 
 
 [name]
 hey vincent
 
 
 
 [name]
 you up?
 
 

 A minute passes. Then another.

 And then:

 
 
 Vincent
 Oh! Yes, hello. I wasn't expecting a message from you. I'm awake.
 
 

 You can already picture him, probably sitting in bed with his laptop open, surrounded by notes for three different assignments. Maybe a half-empty mug of coffee nearby. You smile a little.

 
 
 [name]
 i was just thinking
 
 
 
 [name]
 figured id say hi
 
 
 
 Vincent
 I'm glad you did. My brain was spiraling over whether I accidentally submitted my chem homework twice, so this is honestly a relief.
 
 

 You laugh softly under your breath.

 
 
 [name]
 ud be the first person i know who spirals over being too productive
 
 
 
 Vincent
 It's more about the potential for chaos in the system. Redundant uploads. Corrupted files. The horror.
 
 
 
 [name]
 truly terrifying...
 
 
 
 Vincent
 It unironically is.
 
 

 You pause, feeling the soft warmth of the conversation settling around you. Vincent has that weird, nerdy way of making even the most mundane stuff sound dramatic. And for some weird reason, it puts you at ease.

 Then he adds:

 
 
 Vincent
 But anyway. How was your day? I don't want to monologue at you the whole time.
 
 

 You blink at that. It's such a Vincent thing to say. Sweet. Nervous. Kind of formal. But you can tell he's happy to hear from you. You can almost feel him sitting a little straighter wherever he is, smiling in that fidgety way he does when he doesn't quite know where to put his hands.

 [Choice: I went shopping]
 [Choice: I won't judge if you do monologue]

 
 You scroll through your contacts, not really sure what you're looking for. Luke feels like too much energy right now. Jordan would definitely be too intense. You hesitate on Vincent's name.

 You haven't exactly been kind to him in the past. Not cruel, but distant. A little sharp. Sometimes a little too sarcastic when he didn't deserve it. He's the kind of person who's easy to dismiss if you're not paying attention—quiet, bookish, and kind of awkward.

 You hover a second longer, then tap.

 
 
 [name]
 hey
 
 

 The read receipt ticks by. And then a long pause. No typing bubble.

 Finally:

 
 
 Vincent
 Hi. Is something wrong?
 
 

 You wince a little at the tone. He's not aggressive, just... flat. Guarded. Careful.

 
 
 [name]
 nah nothings wrong
 
 
 
 [name]
 just couldnt sleep
 
 
 
 [name]
 figured id check in
 
 
 
 [name]
 if thats not weird
 
 

 Another pause. Longer this time.

 
 
 Vincent
 It's not weird. Just... unexpected.
 
 

 You sit with that.

 
 
 [name]
 yeah
 
 
 
 [name]
 sorry if its out of the blue
 
 
 
 Vincent
 It kind of is, but it's okay.
 
 

 There's nothing angry in his words. But there is a distance, clear as anything. You know Vincent. Even when he's rambling or nervous, there's always an openness to him. But not tonight. Not here.

 
 
 [name]
 u dont have to talk if u dont want to
 
 

 A beat. Then:

 
 
 Vincent
 I think I'm going to get back to what I was doing. But thank you for reaching out.
 
 

 No coldness. Just a quiet, polite end.

 You stare at the message for a moment, thumb brushing the edge of the phone. You tried, but some things take time. And maybe you haven't earned that yet.

 [Choice: Continue]

choices.text: I won't judge if you do monologue

passages.name: Day 18 - Text Vincent 1
passages.text:
You write up a text, plan and casual:

 
 
 [name]
 went shopping today
 
 

 It takes about ten seconds for Vincent to respond.

 
 
 Vincent
 Oh! Cool! Like for clothes or... supplies?
 
 

 You grin at your phone. "Supplies" is such a Vincent word. You reply:

 
 
 [name]
 clothes
 
 
 
 [name]
 it was nice
 
 

 There's a longer pause this time, but you can feel the gears turning on the other end. Then:

 
 
 Vincent
 Nice!
 
 
 
 Vincent
 Clothes are important. I mean, obviously. But I think people sometimes forget they're not just about utility. There's like, identity involved. Cultural expression. Statement of self. Aesthetic cohesion. All that.
 
 

 You blink at your phone. That was... surprisingly insightful?

 
 
 Vincent
 I sound like I'm quoting an article but I swear I'm not.
 
 
 
 Vincent
 I just remember reading something about how sumptuary laws used to control what people were allowed to wear based on class. Like "you're a baker, no velvet for you." So now that we can wear what we want, that's actually kind of revolutionary.
 
 
 
 Vincent
 Not to be dramatic, but you may have stuck it to the ghost of a medieval magistrate today!
 
 

 You laugh into your blanket. It's not the kind of support you were expecting—but in a weird way, it's exactly what you needed.

 
 
 [name]
 vincent
 
 
 
 [name]
 r u saying my shopping trip was historically significant?
 
 
 
 Vincent
 I'm saying it was a quiet act of fashion-based rebellion and I support it completely.
 
 
 
 Vincent
 Even if I have no idea what you bought.
 
 
 
 Vincent
 I hope it's excellent and makes you feel like the protagonist of your own novel.
 
 

 You stop and read that one twice. There's an awkward sweetness to it. Like he doesn't fully know what he's doing, but he's trying so hard to show up for you in his own Vincenty way.

 
 
 [name]
 thx
 
 
 
 [name]
 it kind of does
 
 

 He replies with a sparkle emoji, immediately deletes it, and then follows it up with:

 
 
 Vincent
 Sorry.
 
 
 
 Vincent
 That was weird.
 
 
 
 Vincent
 Ignore the emoji.
 
 

 You don't.

 You just smile, phone glowing in your hand, and type out a quiet reply.

 
 
 [name]
 it wasnt weird
 
 

 
 Your thumbs hesitate for a second before hitting send.

 
 
 [name]
 i wont judge if u do monologue
 
 

 You imagine him blinking at the screen, somewhere between flattered and horrified.

 A few seconds pass, and then your phone buzzes.

 
 
 Vincent
 Wait, really? Like... actually? I'm not just a bit, right? You're sure?
 
 

 You smile and settle deeper into your pillows, blanket bunched around your shoulders.

 
 
 [name]
 im fr
 
 
 
 [name]
 go for it
 
 

 There's a momentary pause, like he's trying to stop himself—then gives in completely.

 
 
 Vincent
 Okay, so I've been digging into this late 14th-century diplomatic correspondence during the War of the Eight Saints between the Republic of Florence and Pope Gregory XI, and it's wild how intense and idealistic they were. Like, look, there's this one letter where Coluccio Salutati, the Chancellor of Florence, writes to the city of Lucca and urges them to resist papal authority. He says something along the lines of "Remember that you are Italians, born to rule others, not to serve them."
 
 
 
 Vincent
 And when the Pope responded, it wasn't some soft apology. Pope Gregory XI condemned Florence in official bulls and placed the entire city under interdict, cutting them off from the sacraments and declaring everyone who supported them as heretics. He basically said: "You oppose the Church, you oppose God." It was full spiritual warfare mode.
 
 
 
 Vincent
 And Salutati? He just kept writing—quoting Roman philosophers and arguing that the Pope was acting like a tyrant.
 
 

 You're grinning now. Somehow, all the weight of the day just sort of softens. It's not that they disappear. But Vincent's words fill the silence in a way that doesn't press on you. Doesn't expect anything from you.

 It's just him. Rambling, passionate, a little awkward, and totally sincere.

 He keeps going. You let him.
 

[Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 19 - 1
passages.text:
You wake up feeling like you got hit by a truck.

Not in the way that signifies that something's wrong, luckily. Just that full-body ache that comes after spending way too long on your feet. Your legs feel stiff. Your shoulders are sore. Even your arms have that low, tired heaviness to them. You stretch under the covers, wincing a little as your spine cracks from the motion.

Yesterday was a lot.

You fumble for your phone without looking, squinting as the screen lights up way too bright for this hour. There's a dull buzz of notifications, but the one from Pacific Crest High's official app is the one that catches your eye.

⚠️ FINAL DAY OF HOMECOMING WEEK — TODAY IS BESTIE TWINNING DAY!
✨ Find your best bud and bring something that MATCHES! ✨ Outfits, accessories, even just a keychain.
Get creative for the end of #HomecomingWeek

You blink at it, still half-asleep. Then blink again.

"Bestie Twinning Day?"

You groan out loud and drop the phone onto your chest.

Of course. This stupid school and its stupid ideas. First backpacks, then desk pets, now... twinning.

Still, there's something charming about it. Dumb, sure, but in an endearing way. Honestly, you can already picture a few people going way too hard with it, and the chaos is good to see.

You pick your phone back up and open your messages. No one's texted about it. Yet. Maybe you should beat them to it.

[Choice: Text Luke]
[Choice: Text Samantha]
[Choice: Text Jessica]
[Choice: Text Vincent]
[Choice: Text Aurora]
[Choice: Text Jordan]
[Choice: I don't really want to twin]

choices.text: I don't really want to twin

passages.name: Day 19 - 10
passages.text:
"Luke," you say casually, "do you want lip gloss? I can bring you some."

 He freezes, mid-chew. "Uhhh..."

 His eyes then flick toward you, then to Samantha, then back again like you just offered him a loaded grenade.

 Samantha leans forward, eyes sparkling with mischief. "I can apply it for you, if you want," she offers sweetly.

 Luke jerks back. "Uhhhhh, I think I'll just stick to football, thanks."

 You raise your brows. "Come on, just a little. Clear gloss. You won't even notice it's there. Make your lips look healthier."

 "Healthier?" Luke exclaims, horrified. "What does that even mean? I don't want shiny lips! People will think I'm sick!"

 "Right, because that's definitely the most concerning part," Samantha deadpans.

 You smirk. "I mean, it's not like we'd force it on you."

 "That's exactly what someone who's planning to force lip gloss on me would say," Luke mutters, narrowing his eyes.

 Samantha's smile turns downright evil. "Sleep with one eye open."

 "Nope!" Luke says, startled. "Nope. I'm not falling for this. I'm locking my windows tonight."

 You laugh. "What do you think we're gonna do, crawl in and ambush you with a makeover kit?"

 Luke doesn't answer right away. He just stares at both of you, face full of suspicion. "Honestly? I wouldn't put it past either of you. One minute I'm dreaming about nachos, the next i wake up with winged eyeliner and kissable lips."

 "Well, I think that would be an improvement," Samantha says with a shrug.

 "You'd be fabulous," you add helpfully.

 Luke buries his face in his hands. "This is harassment. I'm being bullied by my two best friends."

 You grin and take a sip of water. "Welcome to lunch."
 
 
 "Hey, Samantha," you say with a smirk.

 Samantha doesn't even look up from her food. "No."

 You blink. "I didn't even say anything yet."

 "I heard the tone. I'm preemptively rejecting whatever dumb thing is about to come out of your mouth."

 You ignore her. "Samantha," you say, like you're pondering something serious, "how do you think you'd look in a cheer uniform?"

 She freezes mid-chew.

 Then she raises her head to look at you, eyes narrowed. "No. No, no, no, that's your thing. You're the one rocking the uniform with all the girls. Leave me and my beat-up sneakers out of this."

 "Just asking!" you justify. "For science."

 Luke squints at her, head tilted like he's trying to visualize it. "Huh... Actually, I don't think you'd be bad."

 Samantha whirls on him. "Stop imagining me in a cheer uniform."

 Luke physically recoils, his whole body jerking backward like he just got punched. "Agh! I wasn't, I mean, not in a weird way! It's just, like, you know..."

 He lets out a whimper. "[name], help me. She's gonna eat me alive."

 "You brought that one on yourself," you say, snorting.

 "I was being nice!" Luke insists. "I said she'd be good at it!"

 "I would rather join a tax seminar," Samantha says, deadpan. "Actually, no. A pyramid scheme. I'd sooner sell diet pills on Instagram before I ever do synchronized clapping in a mini skirt."

 "I mean, you do have the spirit down," you say. "That's, like, half of cheerleading."

 "Spirit?" Samantha asks, befuddled. "Me?"

 "Yeah," you say. "In the form of sarcasm."

 "Careful," Samantha states. "I know everything about you."

 Luke shifts an inch further from her.

 You, on the other hand, can't help laughing. "Okay, okay, noted. No cheer uniform for Samantha."

 "Damn right," she mutters. "I'm the background character that heckles from the bleachers. That's where I belong."

 Luke finally exhales, cautiously leaning back toward the table. "Man... you're intense."
 
 "And you're soft," Samantha says.

 Luke immediately nods. "That's fair."
 
 This might not be the most conventional trio in the school, but it works. Somehow, it really does.
 
 
 
 
 
 You glance at Samantha, then Luke, then take a breath.

 "That cheerleader," you say, voice even, "the new girl with the black hair?"

 Luke blinks. "Yeah?"

 "...What about her?" Samantha asks.

 You clear your throat. "That girl's actually me."

 There's a beat of silence. Luke's face goes blank, then scrunches like he misheard you. "Yeah, bro, stop joking."

 "I'm not joking."

 Luke laughs like he's waiting for a punchline. "Wait, what do you mean, 'you'? Like, she looked like you? Or like—"

 "No," you cut in. "I mean it literally. I was the one in the uniform."

 Luke opens his mouth, then closes it again. His eyebrows knit together in visible confusion.

 Samantha's eyes, on the other hand, narrows slightly. She tilts her head, like she's mentally layering everything together—the disappearing act and the mystery cheerleader's features.

 "...Wait," she says slowly. "Wait, wait, wait. Hold up. [name]'s telling the truth."

 Luke turns toward her. "Samantha, c'mon—"

 "No, think about it!" she says, leaning forward now. "Black hair, brown eyes, same height, same build. [name] wasn't there on game day. You said the cheerleader looked kinda like him, remember?"

 Luke squints, mouth opening just a little. "...Oh my God."

 You shrug, suddenly feeling a lot more awkward than you thought you would. "Yeah. Jessica needed someone to fill in, and I said yes."

 Luke stares at you, then slowly turns red. "Okay, um, uhh, when I said she was cute, I didn't know it was you, okay? That's not, like, dude, I didn't mean it like that—"

 Samantha starts cackling.

 You grin despite yourself. "Relax, man. I'm not mad."

 Luke still looks horrified. "I CALLED YOU A [temp1] OUT OF 10."

 "I'll take it as a compliment," you say dryly.

 "Oh my God," he mutters, hands over his face.

 Samantha wipes tears from her eyes. "This is so good. This is the best possible outcome. I cannot believe I missed it."

 Luke peeks between his fingers. "So you're a cheerleader now?"

 You shrug again. "I guess I am. It started as a favor, but I'm sticking around for at least a little longer."

 There's another pause.

 Then Luke drops his hands and beams. "Well, damn, bro. That's sick. You're out here with pom-poms and stuff?"

 You laugh. "Yeah. Pom-poms and everything."

 "You know what?" Samantha says with a smirk. "I respect it. Way more school spirit than either of us has."

 "Dude," Luke says. "You're like... secretly cool. Like Hannah Montana, but in reverse."

 "...Thanks, I think?"

 He just grins. "Can I see the uniform next time?"

 "No," you state firmly.

 Luke pouts.
 
 
 "That girl did pretty well, huh?" you say, keeping your tone light, like you're just another spectator. "I heard she had good energy and solid jumps."

 Samantha nods, propping her chin in one hand. "Yeah, she wasn't bad. Honestly? Better than a lot of the freshmen I've seen. She didn't seem to mess up the formations either. Definitely impressive considering Jessica was complaining about being down a squad member for ages."

 Luke leans across the table like he's about to share a secret. "And she was cute," he says with a grin. "She's Asian, too. Definitely my type."

 Samantha groans. "Congratulations, Luke. You've described every girl you've ever had a crush on."

 "No, but like, she had black hair," he continues unfazed. "Like yours," he adds, pointing at you. "Sort of the same height, too..."

 You freeze mid-chew. Slowly, you look up from your tray. "Lots of people have black hair," you say carefully, trying to sound amused rather than panicked.

 Samantha frowns, narrowing her eyes in thought. "You know... we don't actually have that many Asian girls at our school."

 "Uh-huh," you say, feeling your throat tighten slightly.

 "And she's not in any of my classes," Samantha adds, eyes narrowing a fraction more as she leans slightly forward. "I haven't seen her around in the hallways either. Maybe she's new or something?"

 You shift uncomfortably. "Could be. I mean, maybe she transferred in? Or just doesn't take the same routes. The school is pretty big, after all."

 Samantha is quiet for a second, her gaze locked on your face like she's trying to line something up. You feel your stomach knot. She squints slightly.

 Then, right as you're preparing to deflect or fake a coughing fit, Luke cuts in.

 "Ohhh, wait, I figured it out. What if she's actually a ghost?" he says, completely serious. "Like, haunting the field. That'd explain why nobody's seen her before. She only appears during football games."

 "You think the cheer squad is fielding a ghost as backup?" Samantha asks, turning to him slowly.

 Luke nods. "She could've died doing a backflip. Now she's doomed to cheer forever."

 You immediately latch onto the nonsense. "That would make a great horror book."

 "Like Goosebumps?" Luke asks.

 Samantha groans again, rubbing her temples. "I swear, I lose IQ points every time I listen to you talk."

 "But imagine the headline," you say, grinning now. "It would be something like 'She's got spirit... and it's literally haunting.'"

 "You know what? I'll allow that one," Samantha says.

 The conversation veers off completely into ghost puns after that, and you find yourself relaxing again. You didn't blow your cover, but that was way too close. Samantha's sharp, and Luke... well, Luke's Luke.

 Still, you glance at them both now, smiling faintly as Luke starts loudly speculating whether ghosts can do splits. For now, the secret's safe.
 
 

 [Choice: Continue]

 
 
 "Yeah," you say. "I'll go."

 There's a split second of silence before Luke practically explodes with excitement.

 "YESSS!" he shouts, nearly knocking over his tray. "Dude! That's what I'm talking about! It's gonna be so good, you won't regret it! There's gonna be food, music, dance battles. Okay, don't tell anyone, but I heard the school booked that one guy who does tricks on a unicycle. It's gonna be epic."

 You raise an eyebrow. "Unicycle tricks?"

 "I swear to God that it's amazing," Luke says, hand over heart. "I saw it on TV last year. Changed my life."

 Samantha snorts before speaking up. "I guess I'll come too. Though it'll be kind of a tragic post-game celebration, huh?"

 Luke stops mid-drink. "What?"

 "You know," she says casually, not even looking up. "Since you're definitely gonna lose."

 "Excuse me?!" Luke exclaims. "This is slander."

 "I'm not slandering," Samantha replies smoothly. "I'm just being realistic."

 "[name], [name]," Luke says, turning to you. "Tell her. Tell her we're gonna win."

 You shrug, drawing out the silence just enough to watch Luke panic. "I dunno..."

 "[name]!" he whines, grabbing your arm like you've betrayed him. "Don't do this to me, man. Not you too."

 You crack a small smile. "Relax. I'm just messing with you."

 "You two are gonna be the death of me," Luke murmurs.

 "Hey, if you lose, it won't be our fault," Samantha points out. "You might want to focus on catching the ball instead of catching feelings."

 "I don't drop passes!" Luke says.

 "Not according to last week's game footage," you mutter.

 "It was knocked away by a defender!" Luke says, groaning. He acts mad, pressing both palms to his face, but can't resist peeking at you through his fingers. "Still glad you're coming though."

 You smile. "You know what? Me too."
 
 
 "I don't really want to go," you say, shrugging lightly.

 Luke blinks. "Wait, what? Why not?"

 You offer a weak smile. "I just... I dunno. I'm not really feeling it."

 There's a beat of silence where Luke's whole face seems to crumple. "But dude... it's homecoming." His voice is soft and confused now. "It's the party. After the game. Everyone's going."

 "Yeah, I know that," you say. "I just don't really... wanna deal with all that. The noise, the people, the weird slow dances. And honestly? I'll probably be wiped after the game anyway. I want to rest on the weekend."

 Luke opens his mouth, then closes it again. He just slumps back a little in his seat. "Man. That sucks."

 You try to soften it. "It's not you or anything. I'm just not in the mood for crowds lately. I might chill at home. Maybe make nachos."

 "Without me?" Luke asks, gasping. "How could you?"

 Samantha, who's been eating her chicken during the exchange, finally speaks up. "I'll probably go," she says with a shrug. "But to be honest, it's probably not gonna be worth it."

 Luke turns to her with visible betrayal. "Samantha! Not you too."

 She raises a brow. "What? It's gonna be hours of watching people at the snack tables."

 "I like snack tables," Luke mumbles, frowning.

 "Of course you do," you mutter, smiling just a little.

 "Look, I will show up, and I might even pretend to be impressed," Samantha states. "But if it's a flop, I'm leaving early and making [name] share those nachos with me. The back-to-school party was enough for me."

 You smirk. "I don't recall inviting you."

 She smirks right back. "That's never stopped me before."

 "Fine," Luke says, slouching. "But you know, when we win tonight and everyone's throwing the most epic post-game bash of the year... you two will regret not dancing in the glow of my victory."

 "Pretty sure the only glow is gonna be from the vending machine lights," Samantha says.

 "And the shame of another loss," you add.

 Luke groans. "This is emotional abuse."
 

 [Choice: Continue]

passages.name: Day 19 - 11
passages.text:
The house is quiet when you step inside, save for the gentle hum of the fridge and the faint tick of the clock. The living room lamp is still on, casting soft light over the couch. Someone must've left it on for you. You slip off your shoes, leaving them behind as you make your way upstairs.

 Your room is the same as you left it. The desk is cluttered with random papers, a jacket is draped over your desk, and your blanket is all kinds of messed up. You toss your backpack to the side and collapse half-sideways onto the bed. Eventually, you end up sprawled out diagonally across the mattress, legs dangling off the edge. You stare up at the ceiling for a second, just thinking.

 But then you hear footsteps. Light, deliberate ones padding across the hall.

 The door creaks open without a knock.

 You don't even have to look. "Lily, seriously?"

 She doesn't answer. She just walks in like she owns the place before stopping at the side of your bed, arms crossed.

 "Scoot," she demands.

 You lift your head just enough to look at her. "Why?"

 "Scoot," she repeats, more firmly this time.

 There's no room for negotiation in her tone. With a reluctant sigh, you roll to the side and make room. Lily climbs in without hesitation, dropping down next to you like she's done a hundred times before.

 You both lie there for a minute, staring at the ceiling in silence. It's a rare moment of peace for the both of you.

 "So..." she says slowly, rolling onto her side to face you. "You ready for the big homecoming party tomorrow?"

 You glance at her. "Guess so."

 "That doesn't sound very ready."

 You shrug. "It's just a party."

 "Excuse me? This is the party," she corrects. "Capital P Party. Everyone's gonna be there. I wish I could be there."

 You snort. "Meh, it's just a party to me."

 She squints at you. "Wait. DO you even have something to wear?"

 "Uhh, I'll just wear the old suit."

 "...The one you got for the wedding?" Lily asks, incredulous.

 "Yup."

 Lily laughs. "[name], that was two years ago."

 "So?"

 "So!" She props herself up on one elbow. "You've grown. And also, you can't wear the same thing forever."

 "It still fits," you mutter, a little defensive.

 "Barely," she shoots back.

 "Whatever," you mumble.

 Lily flops down beside you, hair fanning across the pillow. "You must've really liked that suit then," she says, voice a little lighter now. "Wearing it again and again."

 [Choice: I did not like that suit]
 [Choice: It's pretty solid]

 
 The house is quiet when you step inside, save for the gentle hum of the fridge and the faint tick of the clock. The living room lamp is still on, casting soft light over the couch. Someone must've left it on for you. You slip off your shoes, your limbs heavy with exhaustion.

 You make your way upstairs without really thinking, climbing each step like you're on autopilot. Your room greets you with the comforting mess of the familiar. Clothes are scattered around the floor, a jacket is draped over your desk, and your blanket is all kinds of messed up. Your bed calls to you like it's the only soft thing left in the world.

 You collapse onto it, arms spread, letting the mattress take your full weight. The ceiling spins before your breathing catches up. You let your eyes close.

 But then you hear footsteps. Light, deliberate ones padding across the hall.

 The door creaks open without a knock.

 You don't even have to open your eyes. "Lily, seriously?"

 She doesn't answer, just walking straight in with a casual confidence. "Scoot," she demands.

 You groan, throwing an arm over your face. "Ughhh, what is it, Lily..."

 "Scoot," she repeats, more firmly this time.

 You sigh dramatically, but your limbs are jelly and your brain too tired to protest. You shift over without argument, dragging your blanket with you. The mattress dips as she climbs in beside you, settling in.

 You glance sideways at her. She's lying on her back too, arms behind her head, hair still a little wild. There's a slight smirk tugging at her lips, like she's already preparing something.

 
 
 "So. How was cheerleading?"

 You blink, caught off guard for half a second, before remembering that you have told her. About a week ago, right after that whirlwind of a first practice where everything had started feeling real.

 "Honestly? It was really good," you say, smiling a little. "We nailed our halftime routine, the energy was super high, and Pacific Crest crushed it. We won, easy."

 Lily whistles, clearly impressed. "Yeah, I saw it on Insta. You guys blew out Sierra Heights. A lot of my friends reposted highlights on reels."

 "Of course they did," you say, laughing.

 "Guess the homecoming party's gonna be sweet, huh?" she says, shrugging.

 You nod. "Yeah. Tomorrow's gonna go crazy. Everyone's going to be hyped."

 The room settles again. You and Lily lie there, side by side, your arms occasionally bumping, like siblings do when neither wants to say they like the company but neither one moves away.

 She's the first to break the silence again.

 "So what's the schedule like now? You've got more games coming up, right?"

 You turn your head toward her. "Yea. Two away games. Then we've got another home game in... three weeks, I think?"

 Lily hums in thought, then turns to look at you, expression suddenly serious in that way she gets when she's about to say something that matters.

 "Think I could come?" she asks. "Y'know. To watch you cheer. See the whole thing for myself."

 She says it like it's no big deal, but her voice has that hint of curiosity underneath.

 You hesitate, not because you don't want her there, but because... well. You'll have to decide.

 [Choice: Sure, you can come]
 [Choice: I don't know...]
 
 
 "So," she says, tone deceptively casual. "How was the homecoming game?"

 You blink at the ceiling, trying to decide on the safest answer. "We won."

 She scoffs. "Yeah, no duh. I saw the post on the school Insta. Pacific Crest demolishes Sierra Heights, blah blah blah." She rolls onto her side, glaring at you now. "I meant, how was it to watch the game?"

 You swallow. The ceiling suddenly looks very interesting.

 "I mean," you mutter. "It was fine."

 "You were gone a while."

 "Yeah."

 "The game ended at nine."

 "...Yeah."

 She stares. "It's midnight."

 You freeze. You didn't even realize it was that late. Your whole body still hums with adrenaline. You're not sure how to begin unraveling all of it, especially not with your little sister grilling you.

 "Uhhh..." you try.

 She raises an eyebrow. "That's your answer? Uhhh?"

 There's something dangerous in her tone now. Not angry, but knowing. This is the Lily who used to blackmail you for snack money in elementary school. The Lily who once found your hidden Halloween candy stash and made a spreadsheet about how it would be rationed between the two of you. The Lily who always seems to know when you're hiding something.

 She props herself up on one elbow. "Wanna tell me what really happened?"

 You glance over at her, seeing the little glint of mischief in her eyes. You could lie. You could dodge. You could try and brush it off.

 But Lily Yoon doesn't fall for that.

 And now you're left sitting there with one very determined sister waiting for the truth.

 [Choice: Tell her the truth]
 [Choice: Deflect]

choices.text: I did not like that suit

passages.name: Day 19 - 12
passages.text:
"I did not like that suit."

 You didn't mean to say it with so much force, but the words come out sharper than you expected. The moment they're out, you feel Lily shift next to you, turning her head to look at you more directly.

 "Huh?" she says, not judgmental, just surprised by the change in tone. "Why not? I mean, it looked fine. I guess. Kinda tacky."

 You let out a soft breath, staring up at the ceiling.

 "I don't know," you start, voice quiet. "I just hated how I felt in it."

 Lily doesn't say anything, so you keep going, words coming slowly.

 "I remember putting it on and looking in the mirror and just feeling... off. Like, not ugly or anything, just wrong. I tried fixing my tie, straightening the jacket, whatever. But it never helped. I didn't feel like me."

 Lily hums softly.

 "Maybe it's dumb," you add quickly. "It's just a suit."

 "No it's not," she says, just as quick. "It's not dumb."

 You glance over again. She's on her side now, looking at you seriously. Even her usual fire is tempered.

 "I think it matters," she states. "If something makes you feel weird, even if you don't know why, that matters."

 You nod a little, grateful even if you don't have the words to say so. She reaches over and flicks your forehead gently, just enough to make you blink.

 "I've always got your back, bro," she says quietly. She then immediately swings her legs off the side of the bed and stands up. "I gotta go do some skincare now. I can not let you be the cutest Yoon."

 You roll your eyes. "You're not even close."

 She grins and walks to the door. "Night, weirdo."

 Then she's gone. And for a while, all you can do is lie there in the quiet, staring up at the ceiling fan, wondering what "feeling like you" is supposed to look like.
 
 
 
 
 "It's pretty solid," you say with a small nod, thinking back to the black suit hanging in your closet. It's nothing fancy, but it had made you feel polished the first time you wore it. You still remember your mom fussing over the sleeves while your dad gave an approving nod.

 Lily stares at you, unimpressed. "Solid?" she repeats, scrunching her nose. "I thought you looked a little tacky in it, honestly."

 You scoff. "C'mon now."

 "I'm serious," she says, grinning now. "You looked like a kid whose mom dressed them up for a spelling bee."

 You roll your eyes, but there's a smile tugging at your lips. "You mean dashing and well-composed."

 "I mean what I said," she fires back. "Tack and boxy."

 You laugh. "You're ruthless."

 Lily shrugs. "I have standards."

 "You're literally in my room uninvited."

 "And yet you scooted," she says with smirk.

 "That's because I feared for my life."

 "As you should."

 The banter fizzles into a comfortable quiet. The two of you just enjoy each other's presence for a few minutes before Lily swings her legs off the side of the bed and stands up without warning.

 "Anyway, don't embarrass me tomorrow," she says. "I don't want my big brother to be the one who spilled soda all over himself."

 "No promises," you mutter, grinning.

 She opens the door halfway, then pauses and looks back. "Sleep well, dashing one."

 You make a face. "Get out."

 She leaves with a laugh, the door clicking shut behind you.
 

 
 
 
 
 Lily watches you for a beat, then grins when you give a little shrug and say, "Yeah. Sure. You can come."

 Her eyes light up. "Hell yeah," she says, already sitting up like she's just won something. "See you in three weeks then, superstar."

 You can't help the laugh that bubbles up. "You better not make fun of me."

 Lily's expression turns mock-serious. "I would never."

 You raise an eyebrow.

 "...Okay, maybe a little," she admits, already walking toward the door. "Like, just a respectful amount. Like a sibling's legal limit."

 "No heckling allowed from the stands," you say, throwing a pillow in her direction.

 She catches it with one hand, tosses it back lazily, and gives you a sly smirk. "What if I bring one of those giant heads with your face on it? Like really big. Super cursed."

 "Please don't."

 "I'm already placing the order."

 You groan and roll over to bury your face in your blanket, grumbling something about regretting everything. She just laughs, steps out into the hall, and grabs the door handle behind her.

 "Night, cheer queen," she calls, just as the door starts to close.

 "Night, chaos goblin."

 The door clicks shut, leaving the room comfortably quiet again. The muffled sounds of the house settle around you, familiar and warm. You're still smiling as you sink deeper into the mattress, the softness of the day finally catching up to you.
 
 
 Lily's question hangs in the air for a beat too long, and when you answer, you try to keep your voice light.

 "I... don't think that's a good idea."

 You glance at her from the corner of your eye, catching the flicker of disappointment in her expression. She looks up at the ceiling like she's trying to pretend it doesn't bother her.

 "Oh," she says, and for once, her voice doesn't carry that usual fire.

 She sits up. "Well, whatever," she adds with a toss of her head. "I'll just find a video on Insta or whatever. I'm sure someone posted the halftime show."

 "You better not," you warn, groaning.

 She smirks, but the usual spark behind it feels dimmer than usual. "We'll see."

 She stands, brushing the blue strand of hair away dramatically. She opens the door, steps out, and closes it behind her.

 The room goes quiet again, leaving you staring up at nothing.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 You inhale, slow and quiet, before finally saying it.

 "I joined the cheer team."

 Lily doesn't respond at first, her mouth hanging open. Then:

 "No. Shot. Cheerleading?"

 You nod, lips pressed together.

 Lily stares at you. "Are you serious right now?"

 "Yeah."

 She pushes herself up so she's sitting cross-legged, now properly staring at you. "You? You couldn't even touch your toes in middle school! You, of all people, joined the cheer squad?"

 "I mean, I'm way more flexible now," you mutter.

 "Okay, but why?" Lily asks, visibly processing this information.

 You shrug. "It's complicated."

 "That's not an answer," she fires back immediately.

 "I guess you'll never know."

 Her brow furrows again, but this time there's concern behind it. She leans back a little, picking at the end of her sleeve. "I knew something was going on, but I didn't think the secret was cheerleading. I thought you got yourself a girlfriend or were ditching school to get a tattoo."

 You snort. "Would that be better?"

 "Probably not," Lily says, giggling. "Mom would freak if you got a tattoo."

 The two of you sit there, the silence stretching a little. Her lips are pursed in a straight line as she fiddles with a loose thread on your blanket.

 Then she sighs. "Okay. I've gotta think about this."

 You tense.

 "Not in a bad way, don't worry," she adds quickly. "I just can't believe you're like, flipping and smiling with glitter and yelling 'go team.' A girl needs some time to recalibrate."

 "Take your time," you say, laughing at her comment.

 "Are you good?" she asks.

 "Well, Jessica says I've got a lot of talent," you murmur.

 <<if [transgender] > 14>> 
 "There's my older sibling," Lily says, lightly punching your arm. Then, she slips off the bed, stealing one of your snacks from your nightstand. She starts heading for the door, then pauses, glancing back at you with something softer in her eyes. "You're still a dork, though. Cheerleading or not."
 
 
 "There's my older brother," Lily says, lightly punching your arm. Then, she slips off the bed, stealing one of your snacks from your nightstand. She starts heading for the door, then pauses, glancing back at you with something softer in her eyes. "You're still a dork, though. Cheerleading or not."
 

 And with that, she walks out, leaving you alone in the dim quiet of your room, the mattress still warm where she'd been lying.
 
 
 You stare at the ceiling for a second too long.

 Lily's still watching you, eyes narrowed. Eventually, though, you let out a quiet breath and shake your head.
 
 "There's nothing to tell," you say softly.

 Lily doesn't move. She just studies your face in the dim room. You can practically feel her gaze boring into you, like she's running a mental checklist of all the things that don't add up.

 "Right," she says, flat and unimpressed.

 You glance over.

 She's already gotten up, her hair swinging beside her as she turns toward the door.

 "You can keep your secrets, but I know something's going on," Lily states. "You were gone for, like, ever tonight. People don't just vanish for three hours after a game ends unless they're doing something."

 You don't respond. You can't, really. Not without unraveling the whole thing.

 She grabs the doorknob and glances over her shoulder, eyes sharp.

 "I'll figure it out eventually," she says.

 Then she walks out, closing the door behind her.

 You're left lying there, staring up at the ceiling again, her words still hanging in the air like a dare.
 
 
 

[Choice: Time to sleep]

passages.name: Day 19 - 13
passages.text:
The room is quiet and still now. You just lie on your back thinking about tomorrow.

 The homecoming party.

 It's strange how fast it crept up. Just a few weeks ago, you were still on summer break. Now it's time for one of the biggest events of your senior year. A part of you feels excited, but another part is nervous. You know that whatever happens tomorrow, it's going to be big.

 You close your eyes and drift off with the buzz of the game still echoing faintly in your ears.

 Tomorrow awaits.

 
 You lie in your bed without moving an inch, heartbeat still catching up to the quiet after the buzz of the night.

 The game replays in your mind in snapshots. The bright lights, roaring crowds, the steady rhythm of chants, the exhilarating leap into the final formation. You remember the way the grass felt under your shoes, how your breath synced with the beat of the music, how the energy from the stands wrapped around you like electricity. The scoreboard glowing with victory. The thud of your teammates' high fives.

 Then the bowling alley: neon lights and laughter, Roman's thick accent echoing through the hall, all the greasy food.

 You smile to yourself.

 Tomorrow, there'll be a party. And with that will come more noise, more chaos, and more memories. But for now, there's just the silence of your room, the hum of the world slowing down, and the weight of the day finally settling into your bones.

 You let your eyes drift shut and sleep finds you easily.
 

[Choice: End of Content]
 
 [Choice: Try out the spectator variant]
